sentence: Captain John Smith, in his "Description of New England" (1614) deplores the lack of exploration: "Thus, you can see, from this 2000 miles more than half is still known to any purpose: not as much as the borders of the sea are still certainly divided.

name: maine
sentence: As for the good and true substances of the Earth, we are for the most part still totally ignorant of them, vnlesse it bee the parts around the bay of Chisapeack and Sagadahock: but here and there we have touched or haue seen a little bit the edges of these great dominions, which stretch them in Maine, God knows how many thousand miles;" Note that his description of the continent of North America is "the Maine".

name: maine
sentence: The word "hand" was often a shortcut to the word "mainland" (as in "The Spanish Hand")

name: maine
sentence: Attempts to discover the history of the name of Maine began with the "History of the Maine District" of James Sullivan in 1795.

name: maine
sentence: He argued without merit that the Province of Maine was a compliment to the Queen of Charles I, Henrietta Maria, who once "owned" the Province of Maine in France.

name: maine
sentence: The historians of Maine quoted it until the biography of this queen of Agnes Strickland in 1845, establishing that she had no connection with the province; moreover, King Charles I married Henrietta Maria in 1625, three years after the appearance of the name Maine.

name: maine
sentence: A new theory put forward by Carol B. Smith Fisher in 2002 postulates that Sir Ferdinando Gorges chose the name in 1622 to honor the village where his ancestors lived for the first time in England, rather than the province of France.

name: maine
sentence: "MAINE" appears in the Book Domesday of 1086 with reference to Dorset County, which is today Broadmayne, just southeast of Dorchester.

name: maine
sentence: The general opinion among British researchers of place names is that Mayne in Dorset is Brytonic, corresponding to the modern Welsh "maen", plural "hand" or "meini".

name: maine
sentence: Some spellings are: MAINE 1086, MEINE 1200, MEINES 1204, MAYNE 1236.

name: maine
sentence: Today, the village is known as Broadmayne, which is primitive Welsh or brytonic, "hand" meaning rock or stone, considered a reference to the many large sarsen stones still present around the Little Mayne farm, half a mile northeast of the village of Broadmayne.

name: maine
sentence: The first known registration of the name appears in a land charter of 10 August 1622 to Sir Ferdinando Gorges and to Captain John Mason, veterans of the British Royal Navy, who were granted a vast territory in the present Maine which Mason and Gorges "intended to appoint the province of Maine".

name: maine
sentence: Mason had served with the Royal Navy in the Orkney Islands, where the main island is called Mainland, a possible diversion of the name for these English sailors.

name: maine
sentence: In 1623 English naval captain Christopher Levett, exploring the coast of New England, wrote: "The first place on which I set my foot in New England was the island of Shoals, being Ilands [sic] in the sea, over two Leagues of the Mayne."

name: maine
sentence: Initially, several sections along the coast of New England were called Maine or Maine (cf.

name: maine
sentence: Spanish Hand).

name: maine
sentence: A charter reconfirmed and strengthened on April 3, 1639, by the King of England Charles I, entrusted Sir Ferdinando Gorges with increased powers over his new province and declared that it "will be forever called and named the PROVINCE OR COUNTY OF MAINE, and not by any other name or name whatsoever..." Maine is the only American state whose name has only one syllable.

name: maine
sentence: The first inhabitants of the territory that is now Maine were the Algonquian Wabanaki, including Passamaquoddy, Maliseet, Penobscot, Androscoggin and Kennebec.

name: maine
sentence: During the last War of King Philip, many of these peoples merged in one form or another to become the Wabanaki Confederation, assisting the Wampanoag of Massachusetts and the Mahican of New York.

name: maine
sentence: Subsequently, many of these people were driven out of their natural territories, but most of the tribes of Maine continued, without change, until the American Revolution.

name: maine
sentence: Before that, however, most of these people were considered to be separate nations.

name: maine
sentence: Many had adapted to life in permanent Iroquois-inspired settlements, while those along the coast tended to be semi-nomadic, moving from establishment to establishment over an annual cycle.

name: maine
sentence: They usually winter inland and head to the coasts in summer.

name: maine
sentence: European contact with what is now known as Maine may have started around 1200 CE when Norwegians interacted with the native Penobscot in the present county of Hancock, probably through trade.

name: maine
sentence: If confirmed, it would make Maine the site of Europe's first fall in the United States.

name: maine
sentence: About 200 years earlier, colonies in Iceland and Greenland, Norwegians first identified America and attempted to settle in areas like Newfoundland, but failed to establish a permanent settlement.

name: maine
sentence: Archaeological evidence suggests that Greenlanders returned to North America for centuries after the initial discovery to trade and collect wood, with the most relevant evidence being Maine Penny, an 11th-century Norwegian piece found in an Amerindian excavation site in 1954.

name: maine
sentence: The first European colony confirmed in modern Maine was in 1604 on Île Sainte-Croix, led by French explorer Pierre Dugua, Sieur de Mons.

name: maine
sentence: His party included Samuel de Champlain, a known explorer.

name: maine
sentence: The French named the whole region of Acadia, including the part that later became the state of Maine.

name: maine
sentence: The Plymouth Company established the first English colony in Maine at Popham Colony in 1607, the same year as the Jamestown settlement in Virginia.

name: maine
sentence: Popham settlers returned to Britain after 14 months.

name: maine
sentence: The French established two Jesuit missions: one on Penobscot Bay in 1609 and the other on Desert Mountain Island in 1613.

name: maine
sentence: That same year, Claude de La Tour founded Castine.

name: maine
sentence: In 1625 Charles de Saint-Étienne de la Tour erected Fort Pentagouet to protect Castine.

name: maine
sentence: The coastal zones of eastern Maine first became the province of Maine in 1622.

name: maine
sentence: The western part of Maine north of the Kennebec River was more sparsely populated and was known in the 17th century as the territory of Sagadahock.

name: maine
sentence: A second colony was attempted in 1623 by British explorer and naval captain Christopher Levett in a place called York, where he had received 6,000 acres (24 km2) by King Charles I of England.

name: maine
sentence: It's a failure, too.

name: maine
sentence: The central Maine was once inhabited by the Androscoggins tribe of the Abenaki nation, also known as Arosaguntacook.

name: maine
sentence: They were expelled from the area in 1690 during the War of King William.

name: maine
sentence: They were resettled in St. Francis, Canada, which was destroyed by Rogers' Rangers in 1759, and is now Odanak.

name: maine
sentence: The other Abenaki tribes suffered several serious defeats, especially during the Dummer War, with the capture of Norridgewock in 1724 and the defeat of the Pequawket in 1725, which greatly reduced their numbers.

name: maine
sentence: They finally withdrew to Canada, where they settled in Bécancour and Sillery, then in Saint-François, along with other southern refugee tribes.

name: maine
sentence: Within its present boundaries, the province was part of the Massachusetts Bay colony in 1652.

name: maine
sentence: Maine was much fought by the French, the English and the Allies during the 17th and 18th centuries, who carried out raids against each other, taking captives for ransom or, in some cases, adoption by Amerindian tribes.

name: maine
sentence: A notable example was the raid by Abenaki on York in early 1692, where about 100 English settlers were killed and 80 others were taken hostage.

name: maine
sentence: The Abenakis took prisoners during the Massachusetts raids in the Queen Anne's War of the early 1700s at Kahnewake, a Catholic Mohawk village near Montreal, where some were adopted and others redeemed.

name: maine
sentence: After the British defeated the French in Acadia in the 1740s, the territory of the Penobscot River fell under the nominal authority of the province of Nova Scotia and, with present-day New Brunswick, formed Sunbury County, Nova Scotia, with its general session court in Campobello.

name: maine
sentence: American and British forces opposed the territory of Maine during the American Revolution and the War of 1812, with the British occupying East Maine in both conflicts via the colony of New Ireland.

name: maine
sentence: The territory of Maine was confirmed as part of Massachusetts when the United States was formed as a result of the Paris Treaty ending the revolution, although the final border with British North America was only established with the Treaty of Webster–Ashburton of 1842.

name: maine
sentence: The Maine was physically separated from the rest of Massachusetts.

name: maine
sentence: Long-standing disagreements over land speculation and settlements led the residents of Maine and their allies in Massachusetts to impose a vote of 1807 in the Massachusetts Assembly to allow Maine to separate

name: maine
sentence: During the War of 1812, the pro-British merchants of Massachusetts opposed the war and refused to defend Maine from British invaders.

name: maine
sentence: In 1819, Massachusetts agreed to allow secession, sanctioned by the expanding voters of the region the following year.

name: maine
sentence: The formal secession and formation of the State of Maine as the 23rd State took place on 15 March 1820, within the framework of the Missouri compromise, which geographically limited the spread of slavery and allowed admission to the State of Missouri the following year, keeping a balance between slavery and free states.

name: maine
sentence: The original capital of the state of Maine was Portland, the largest city in Maine, until it was moved to the centre of Augusta in 1832.

name: maine
sentence: The principal office of the Supreme Court of Maine remains in Portland.

name: maine
sentence: Maine's 20th Voluntary Infantry Regiment, under the command of Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, prevented the Union Army from being flanked at Little Round Top by the Confederate Army during the Battle of Gettysburg.

name: maine
sentence: Four ships of the U.S. Navy were named USMaine, the most famous armoured cruiser USMaine (ACR-1), whose shipwreck by an explosion on 15 Feb. 1898 precipitated the war of Spain and America.

name: maine
sentence: To the south and east is the Atlantic Ocean, and to the north and north-east is New Brunswick, a province of Canada.

name: maine
sentence: The province of Quebec is located to the northwest.

name: maine
sentence: Maine is the northernmost state of New England and the largest, accounting for nearly half of the total area of the region.

name: maine
sentence: Maine is the only state that borders exactly another US state (New Hampshire).

name: maine
sentence: Maine is the easternmost state of the United States, both in its extreme points and in its geographical center.

name: maine
sentence: The city of Lubec is the most organized settlement in the eastern United States.

name: maine
sentence: Its Quoddy Head Lighthouse is also the closest location in the United States of Africa and Europe.

name: maine
sentence: Estcourt Station is the northernmost point of Maine and the northernmost point of New England.

name: maine
sentence: Lake Moosehead du Maine is the largest lake in New England, since Lake Champlain is located between Vermont, New York and Quebec.

name: maine
sentence: A number of other lakes in Maine, such as South Twin Lake, are described by Thoreau in the Maine Woods (1864).

name: maine
sentence: Mt. Katahdin is the northern terminus of the Appalachian Trail, which extends south to Mount Springer, Georgia, and the southern terminus of the new Appalachian International Trail, which, when completed, will travel to Belle Isle, Newfoundland and Labrador.

name: maine
sentence: Machias Seal Island and North Rock, off the east coast of the state, are claimed by both Canada and the U.S. City of Cutler, and are located in one of the four areas between the two countries whose sovereignty is still in dispute, but it is the only disputed area containing land.

name: maine
sentence: In this easternmost region of the Bay of Fundy, there is also the old sow, the largest tidal whirlwind in the Western Hemisphere.

name: maine
sentence: Maine is the least populated of the United States east of Mississippi.

name: maine
sentence: It is known as the Pine Tree State; more than 80% of its land is forested or unclaimed, the most forested of an American state.

name: maine
sentence: In the forested areas of the interior there are many uninhabited lands, some of which have no formal political organization in local units (a rarity in New England).

name: maine
sentence: Northwest Aroostook, Maine, an unorganized territory in the northern part of the state, for example, has an area of 668 square miles (6,910 km2) and a population of 10, or a person for 267 square miles (690 km2).

name: maine
sentence: Maine occurs in the biome of mixed and broad-leaved temperate forests.

name: maine
sentence: Land near the south and central coast of the Atlantic is covered with oaks mixed with the coastal forests of the northeast.

name: maine
sentence: The rest of the state, including the North Wood, is covered by the forests of New England and Acadia.

name: maine
sentence: Le Maine has nearly 400 kilometres of coast (and 5,600 kilometres) of tidal coastline.

name: maine
sentence: West Quoddy Head, Lubec, Maine, is the most easterly point of the earth in the 48 contiguous states.

name: maine
sentence: Along the famous rocky coast of Maine are lighthouses, beaches, fishing villages and thousands of offshore islands, including the Shoals islands that cross the New Hampshire border.

name: maine
sentence: There are rocks, cliffs and many bays and entrances.

name: maine
sentence: The interior is lakes, rivers, forests and mountains.

name: maine
sentence: This visual contrast of the wooded slopes sweeping to the sea was summed up by American poet Edna St. Vincent Millay of Rockland and Camden, Maine, in "Renascence":

name: maine
sentence: Geologists describe this type of landscape as a "wild coast," where sea-level rise has invaded ancient lands, creating bays of valleys and islands from mountain peaks.

name: maine
sentence: A rise in land due to the melting of strong glacial ice caused a slight rebound in the underlying rocks; however, this rise in land was not sufficient to eliminate all the effects of sea-level rise and its invasion of old land characteristics.

name: maine
sentence: Much of Maine's geomorphology was created by extended glacial activity at the end of the last glacial era.

name: maine
sentence: Key glacial features include the Strait of Somes and the Bubble Rock, both part of Acadia National Park on Mount Desert Island.

name: maine
sentence: Cut by glaciers, the Strait of Somes is considered the only fjord on the east coast and reaches depths of 175 feet (50 m).

name: maine
sentence: Extreme depth and steep fall allow large ships to navigate almost the entire length of sound.

name: maine
sentence: These features have also made it attractive for boat builders, such as the prestigious Hinckley yachts.

name: maine
sentence: Bubble Rock, a glacial erratic, is a large rock perched on the edge of Mount Bubble in Acadia National Park.

name: maine
sentence: By analyzing the type of granite, geologists discovered that the glaciers carried Bubble Rock to its current location from near Lucerne, 48 km away.

name: maine
sentence: The Iapetus Suture crosses the north and west of the state, being submarine by the former Laurentian terrane, and the south and east by the Avalonian terrane.

name: maine
sentence: Acadia National Park is the only National Park in New England.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has a damp continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfb), with warm and sometimes humid summers, and long, cold and very snowy winters.

name: maine
sentence: Winters are particularly severe in the northern and western parts of Maine, while coastal areas are slightly moderated by the Atlantic Ocean, resulting in milder winters and cooler summers than inland areas.

name: maine
sentence: Day peaks are generally between 75 and 80°F (24 and 27°C) in the state as a whole in July, with night hollows in the high 50°F (about 15°C).

name: maine
sentence: January temperatures range from 30°F (−1°C) on the south coast to 0°F (−18°C) at night, on average, in the extreme north.

name: maine
sentence: The record state temperature is 105°F (41°C), set in July 1911, at North Bridgton.Precipitation in Maine is evenly distributed throughout the year, but with a slight summer maximum in north/northwest Maine and a slight peak of end of fall or beginning of winter along the coast due to "no'esters" or intense cold season rains and snow storms.

name: maine
sentence: In coastal Maine, the late spring and summer months are usually the driest, a rarity in the eastern United States.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has fewer storm days than any other state east of the Rocky Mountains, most of them being on average less than 20 storm days per year.

name: maine
sentence: The tornadoes are rare in Maine, with the state having an average of less than four per year, although this number is increasing.

name: maine
sentence: The most severe thunderstorms and tornadoes occur in the Sebago Lakes & Foothills area of the state.

name: maine
sentence: Maine rarely sees the effect of tropical cyclones, since they tend to pass well to the east and south or are greatly weakened when they reach Maine.

name: maine
sentence: In January 2009, a new record low state temperature was set at Big Black River at -50°F (−46°C), which binds New England's record.

name: maine
sentence: Annual precipitation ranges from 909 mm (35.8 in) in Presque Island to 1,441 mm (56.7 in) in Acadia National Park.

name: maine
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the Maine population was 1,344,212 as at 1 July 2019, an increase of 1.19% compared to the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: maine
sentence: The population density of the state is 41.3 persons per square mile, making it the least densely populated state east of Mississippi.

name: maine
sentence: In 2010, Maine was also the most rural state in the Union, with only 38.7% of the state population living in urban areas.

name: maine
sentence: As explained in detail in the section "Geography", there are large expanses of uninhabited land in some remote parts of the interior of the state, particularly in the woods of the North Maine.

name: maine
sentence: The average population centre of Maine is located in Kennebec County, just east of Augusta.

name: maine
sentence: The Greater Portland metropolitan area is the most densely populated with nearly 40% of the population of Maine.

name: maine
sentence: This region covers three counties and includes many farms and forested areas; in 2016, the population of Portland itself was 66,937.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has experienced a very slow rate of population growth since the 1990 census.

name: maine
sentence: The modest population growth in the state has been concentrated in the southern coastal counties.

name: maine
sentence: However, the northern and more rural regions of the state have experienced a slight population decline in recent years.

name: maine
sentence: According to the 2010 census, Maine has the highest percentage of non-Hispanic whites in any state, or 94.4% of the total population.

name: maine
sentence: In 2011, 89.0% of all births in the state were made to non-Hispanic white parents.

name: maine
sentence: Maine also has the second largest residential population.

name: maine
sentence: The table below shows the racial composition of the Maine population from 2016 onwards.

name: maine
sentence: According to the 2016 U.S. Community Survey, 1.5% of Maine's population was of Hispanic or Latin origin (of any race): Mexican (0.4%), Puerto Rican (0.4%), Cuban (0.1%) and other Hispanic or Latin origin (0.6%).

name: maine
sentence: The five largest groups of ancestry are English (20.7 per cent), Irish (17.3 per cent), French (15.7 per cent), German (8.1 per cent) and American (7.8 per cent).

name: maine
sentence: The people quoting they are Americans are of mostly English origin, but have ancestors who have been in the area for so long (often since the 1600s) that they simply choose to identify themselves as Americans.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has the highest percentage of French Americans from all states.

name: maine
sentence: Most of them are of Canadian origin, but in some cases they have lived there since before the American Revolutionary War.

name: maine
sentence: There are particularly high concentrations in the northern part of Maine in Aroostook County, which is part of a cultural region known as Acadia that crosses the New Brunswick border.

name: maine
sentence: In addition to the Acadian population of the north, many French came from Quebec as immigrants between 1840 and 1930.

name: maine
sentence: The upper part of the Saint John River valley was once part of the so-called Madawaska Republic, before the boundary was decided in the Webster-Ashburton Treaty of 1842.

name: maine
sentence: More than a quarter of the population of Lewiston, Waterville and Biddeford are French-American.

name: maine
sentence: Most of the residents of the Mid Coast and Down East sections belong primarily to British heritage.

name: maine
sentence: Smaller numbers of other groups, including Irish, Italian and Polish, have settled throughout the state since the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

name: maine
sentence: Maine does not have an official language, but the most commonly spoken language in the state is English.

name: maine
sentence: According to the 2000 Census, 92.25 per cent of residents of Maine aged five and over spoke only English at home.

name: maine
sentence: Francophones are the largest linguistic minority in the state; census figures show that Maine has the highest percentage of people speaking French in any state: 5.28% of households in Maine are Francophones, compared with 4.68% in Louisiana, which is the second highest state.

name: maine
sentence: Although rarely spoken, Spanish is the third most common language in Maine, after both English and French.

sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the religious affiliations of Maine in 2010 were as follows:

sentence: The Catholic Church was the largest religious institution with 202,106 members; the United Methodist Church had 28,329 members; the United Church of Christ had 22,747 members.

sentence: The Economic Analysis Bureau estimates that Maine's total gross domestic product in 2010 was $52 billion.

name: maine
sentence: Maine agricultural production includes poultry, eggs, dairy products, livestock, wild blueberries, apples, maple syrup and maple sugar.

name: maine
sentence: Aroostook County is known for its potato crops.

name: maine
sentence: Commercial fishing, once a pillar of the state economy, maintains a presence, particularly lobster and bottom fishing.

name: maine
sentence: Although lobster is the main sea fish in Maine, oyster and seaweed harvests are on the rise.

name: maine
sentence: In 2015, 14% of the total reserves of northeast oysters were from Maine.

name: maine
sentence: In 2017, Maine's marine algal production was estimated to be $20 million per year.

name: maine
sentence: The Maine shrimp industry is waiting for government.

name: maine
sentence: With a declining northern shrimp population, Maine fishers are no longer permitted to fish and sell shrimp.

name: maine
sentence: Deductions began in 2014 and are expected to continue until 2021.

name: maine
sentence: Aquifers and sources in the Western Maine are an important source of bottled water.

name: maine
sentence: Maine's industrial products consist mainly of paper, lumber and wood products, electronic equipment, leather products, food, textiles and biotechnology.

name: maine
sentence: Shipbuilding and construction are also essential, with the work of Bath Iron in Bath and Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in Kittery.

name: maine
sentence: Brunswick Landing, formerly the Brunswick Naval Air Station, is also in Maine.

name: maine
sentence: Formerly an important base of support for the U.S. Navy, the BRAC campaign began the closure of the naval air station, despite a government-funded effort to upgrade its facilities.

name: maine
sentence: The former base has since been transformed into a civilian business park, as well as a new satellite campus for Southern Maine Community College.

name: maine
sentence: Maine is the first American producer of low-leaved blueberries (Vaccinium angustifolium).

name: maine
sentence: The USDA 2012 preliminary data also indicate that Maine was the largest blueberry producer in the major blueberry-producing states, with 91,100,000 lbs.

name: maine
sentence: These data include both low (wild) blueberries and high (cultivated) blueberries: Vaccinium corymbosum.

name: maine
sentence: The largest toothpick plant in the United States was located in Strong, Maine.

name: maine
sentence: Strong Wood Products produces 20 million toothpicks a day.

name: maine
sentence: It was closed in May 2003.

name: maine
sentence: Tourism and outdoor recreation play an important and increasingly important role in the Maine economy.

name: maine
sentence: The state is a popular destination for sport hunting (especially deer, moose and bears), sport fishing, snowmobile, skiing, boating, camping and hiking, among other activities.

name: maine
sentence: Historically, the ports of Maine have played an essential role in national transport.

name: maine
sentence: From the 1880s, Portland's rail link and ice-free harbour became Canada's main winter port, until the aggressive development of Halifax, Nova Scotia, in the mid 1900s.

name: maine
sentence: In 2013, 12,039,600 short tons entered and exited Portland by sea, placing it at 45th place in the U.S. water ports.

name: maine
sentence: Portland Maine's Portland International Jetport has recently been expanded, providing the state with increased air traffic from carriers such as JetBlue and Southwest Airlines.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has very few large Crown-owned companies and this number has decreased as a result of consolidations and mergers, particularly in the pulp and paper industry.

name: maine
sentence: The largest companies with headquarters in Maine include Fairchild Semiconductor in southern Portland, IDEXX Laboratories in Westbrook, Hannaford Bros. Co., Scarborough, TD Bank, Portland, L.L. Bean, Freeport and Cole Haan, Yarmouth.

name: maine
sentence: Maine is also home to Jackson Laboratory, the world's largest non-profit mammalian genetic research laboratory and the world's largest supplier of genetically pure mice.

name: maine
sentence: In Maine, the income tax structure consists of two tranches, 6.5 per cent and 7.95 per cent of personal income.

name: maine
sentence: Prior to July 2013, Maine had four square brackets: 2, 4.5, 7 and 8.5 per cent.

name: maine
sentence: Maine's general sales tax is 5.5 per cent.

name: maine
sentence: The government is also charging nine per cent on accommodation and prepared food and ten per cent on short-term car rental.

name: maine
sentence: Commercial blueberry vendors, a staple food in Maine, are required to keep records of their transactions and pay the 1.5 cents per pound ($1.50 per 100 pounds) of the fruit sold each season.

name: maine
sentence: All real and tangible personal property situated in the State of Maine may be taxed, unless expressly exempted by law.

name: maine
sentence: Property taxes are administered by the local assessor in cities and incorporated cities, while property taxes in non-organized territories are administered by the State tax assessor.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has a long-standing tradition of sheltering many shipbuilding companies.

name: maine
sentence: In the 18th and 19th centuries, Maine housed numerous shipyards that produced wooden sailboats.

name: maine
sentence: The main function of these vessels was to carry either cargo or passengers abroad.

name: maine
sentence: One of these sites was located in the historical district of Pennellville, in what is now Brunswick, Maine.

name: maine
sentence: This court, owned by the Pennell family, was typical of the many family shipbuilding businesses of the period.

name: maine
sentence: Other examples of shipbuilding families are Skolfields and Morses.

name: maine
sentence: During the 18th and 19th centuries, such wooden shipbuilding was an important part of the economy.

name: maine
sentence: Maine receives a passenger jet service at its two largest airports, Portland International Jetport in Portland and Bangor International Airport in Bangor.

name: maine
sentence: Both are served daily by many major airlines to destinations like New York, Atlanta and Orlando.

name: maine
sentence: Essential Air Service also subsidizes service at a number of small Maine airports, bringing small turboprop aircraft to regional airports such as Augusta State Airport, Hancock County-Bar Harbor Airport, Knox County Regional Airport and North Maine Regional Airport at Presque Isle.

name: maine
sentence: These airports are served by regional providers such as Cape Air with Cessna 402s, PenAir with Saab 340s and CommutAir with Embraer ERJ 145.

name: maine
sentence: Many small airports are dispersed in Maine, serving only general air traffic.

name: maine
sentence: Eastport Municipal Airport, for example, is a city-owned public airport with 1,200 general aviation aircraft operating annually from single-engine and ultra-light aircraft.

name: maine
sentence: Interstate 95 (I-95) crosses Maine, and its branch is I-295 and its spurs I-195, I-395 and I-495 (the Falmouth Spur) unsigned.

name: maine
sentence: In addition, the US Route 1 (US 1) starts at Fort Kent and goes to Florida.

name: maine
sentence: The eastern terminus of the eastern section of the U.S. 2 begins in Houlton, near the border of New Brunswick, Canada, to Rousses Point, New York, U.S. 11.

name: maine
sentence: US 2A connects Old Town and Orono, primarily serving the University of Maine campus.

name: maine
sentence: The United States 201 and the United States 202 pass through the State.

name: maine
sentence: US 2, Maine State Route 6 (SR 6) and SR 9 are often used by truckers and other motorists from the Maritime provinces on their way to other destinations in the United States or as a short cut to central Canada.

name: maine
sentence: The Downeaster passenger train, operated by Amtrak, provides a passenger service between Brunswick and the North Station of Boston, with stops at Freeport, Portland, Old Orchard Beach, Saco and Wells.

sentence: Rich Catholic planters built chapels on their lands to practice their religion in relative secrecy.

name: maryland
sentence: In the 18th century, lay priests and leaders claimed the Jesuit-owned farms of Maryland as personal property and bequeathed them to avoid legal restrictions on property belonging to religious organizations.

name: maryland
sentence: The Royal Charter granted Maryland the lands north of the Potomac River until the 40th parallel.

name: maryland
sentence: A problem arose when Charles II granted a charter for Pennsylvania.

name: maryland
sentence: The subsidy defined the southern border of Pennsylvania as identical to the northern border of Maryland, the 40th parallel.

name: maryland
sentence: But the grant indicated that Charles II and William Penn assumed that the 40th parallel would pass near New Castle, Delaware when it fell north of Philadelphia, the site of which Penn had already chosen the capital of his colony.

name: maryland
sentence: Negotiations followed after the discovery of the problem in 1681.

name: maryland
sentence: A compromise proposed by Charles II in 1682 was undermined by the fact that Penn received the additional award of what is now Delaware.

name: maryland
sentence: Penn successfully argued that the Maryland Charter, Lord Baltimore, applied only to unoccupied lands, and that Dutch colonization at Delaware predates its charter.

name: maryland
sentence: The dispute remained unresolved for nearly a century, pursued by the descendants of William Penn and Lord Baltimore, the Calvert family, which controlled Maryland, and the Penn family, which controlled Pennsylvania.

name: maryland
sentence: The border dispute with Pennsylvania led to the Cresap War in the 1730s.

name: maryland
sentence: The hostilities broke out in 1730 and intensified in the first half of the decade, culminating in the deployment of military forces by Maryland in 1736 and Pennsylvania in 1737.

name: maryland
sentence: The armed phase of the conflict ended in May 1738 with the intervention of King George II, who imposed the negotiation of a cease-fire.

name: maryland
sentence: A provisional agreement had been in place in 1732.

name: maryland
sentence: The negotiations continued until a final agreement was signed in 1760.

name: maryland
sentence: The agreement defined the boundary between Maryland and Pennsylvania as the line of latitude now known as the Mason–Dixon line.

name: maryland
sentence: The border of Maryland with Delaware rests on a transpennine line and the circle of twelve miles around the new castle.

name: maryland
sentence: Most of the English settlers arrived in Maryland as contracted servants, and had to fulfill a mandate of several years as workers to pay for their passage.

name: maryland
sentence: In the early years, the line between contract servants and African slaves or workers was fluid, and white and black workers generally lived and worked together, and formed unions.

name: maryland
sentence: Mixed-bred children born to white mothers are considered free by the principle of partus sequitur ventrem, whereby children take on the social status of their mother, a principle of the Slave Law which was adopted in all colonies, after Virginia in 1662.

name: maryland
sentence: During the colonial period, families of free people of colour were formed most often by unions of white women and African men.

name: maryland
sentence: Many free black families migrated to Delaware, where land was cheaper.

name: maryland
sentence: As the flow of contract workers to the colony declined with the improvement of economic conditions in England, the planters of Maryland imported thousands of other hardened slaves and lineages of racial castes.

name: maryland
sentence: The growth and prosperity of the economy was based on slave labour, first devoted to tobacco production as a basic crop.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland was one of the thirteen colonies that rebelled against British rule during the American Revolution.

name: maryland
sentence: Towards the end of the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), on 2 February 1781, Maryland became the last and 13th state to approve the ratification of the statutes of the Confederation and the perpetual Union, first proposed in 1776 and adopted by the Second Continental Congress in 1778, which made the United States a united, sovereign and national State.

name: maryland
sentence: It also became the seventh State admitted to the Union after ratifying the new Federal Constitution in 1788.

name: maryland
sentence: In December 1790 Maryland donated lands selected by First President George Washington to the federal government for the creation of Washington's new national capital, D.C.

name: maryland
sentence: Land was provided along the north shore of the Potomac River from the counties of Montgomery and Prince George, as well as Fairfax and Alexandria County on the south shore of the Potomac River in Virginia; however, land donated by the Commonwealth of Virginia was later returned to that state by the District of Columbia retrocession in 1846.

name: maryland
sentence: Influenced by a changing economy, revolutionary ideals and preaching by ministers, many planters in Maryland liberated their slaves within 20 years of the revolutionary war.

name: maryland
sentence: Throughout the Upper South, the free black population rose from less than 1% before the war to 14% in 1810.

name: maryland
sentence: Harriet Tubman was born a slave during this time in Dorchester County, Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: During the War of 1812, the British army attempted to capture Baltimore, which was protected by Fort McHenry.

name: maryland
sentence: During this bombing, the song "Star Spangled Banner" was written by Francis Scott Key; it was then adopted as a national anthem.

name: maryland
sentence: The national road (US Hwy 40 today) was authorised in 1817 and extends from Baltimore to Saint-Louis, the first federal road.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore and Ohio Railroad (B&O) is the first chartered railway in the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: It opened its first track section for regular operation in 1830 between Baltimore and Ellicott City, and in 1852 became the first railway line to reach the Ohio River from the east coast.

name: maryland
sentence: The state remained with the Union during the civil war, largely because of demography and federal intervention.

name: maryland
sentence: The 1860 census, held shortly before the outbreak of the civil war, showed that 49% of the African Americans in Maryland were free Blacks.

name: maryland
sentence: Governor Thomas Holliday Hicks suspended the state's legislature and, in order to help secure the election of a new governor and legislature in favour of union, President Abraham Lincoln arrested a number of his slavery-loving politicians, including Baltimore Mayor George William Brown; suspended several civil liberties, including habeas corpus; and ordered the installation of artillery on the Federal Hill overlooking Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: Historians are debating the constitutionality of these acts in times of war, and the suspension of civil liberties is later found illegal by the Supreme Court of the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: In April 1861, federal units and state regiments were attacked as they passed through Baltimore, causing the Baltimore riot in 1861, the first bloodbath of the civil war.

name: maryland
sentence: Of the 115 000 men in Maryland who joined the army during the civil war, 85,000, or 77%, joined the Union army, while the others joined the Confederate army.

name: maryland
sentence: The Battle of Antietam on September 17, 1862, near Sharpsburg, was the most important and important battle in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Although tactical, the battle was considered a strategic victory for the Union and a turning point in the war.

name: maryland
sentence: A new state constitution in 1864 abolished slavery and Maryland was first recognized as a "free state" in that context.

name: maryland
sentence: Following the adoption of constitutional amendments granting the right to vote to men who were released in 1867, the state extended the vote to non-white men.

name: maryland
sentence: The Democratic Party quickly regained power in the Republican state.

name: maryland
sentence: The Democrats replaced the Constitution of 1864 by the Constitution of 1867.

name: maryland
sentence: After the reconstruction ended in 1877, the Democrats developed ways to deprive blacks of their right to vote, first through physical intimidation and electoral fraud, then through constitutional amendments and laws.

name: maryland
sentence: Blacks and immigrants, however, resisted the Democratic Party's efforts to emancipate the State.

name: maryland
sentence: The Blacks of Maryland were part of a biracial republican coalition elected to the state government in 1896–04 and represented 20% of the electorate.

name: maryland
sentence: Compared with some other states, Blacks were better established before and after the civil war.

name: maryland
sentence: Nearly half of the black population was liberated before the war, and some had accumulated property.

name: maryland
sentence: Half the population lives in the city.

name: maryland
sentence: Literacy was high among blacks and, as democrats designed ways to exclude them, suffrage campaigns helped to reach out to blacks and teach them how to resist.

name: maryland
sentence: Whites effectively imposed racial segregation in public institutions and Jim Crow's laws, which lasted until federal civil rights legislation was enacted in the mid-1960s.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore experienced significant growth during the industrial revolution, largely thanks to its seaport and good rail links, attracting the European immigrant workforce.

name: maryland
sentence: Many manufacturing companies were created in the Baltimore region after the Civil War.

name: maryland
sentence: Businessmen from Baltimore, including Johns Hopkins, Enoch Pratt, George Peabody and Henry Walters, have founded important institutions in the city that bear their names, including a university, library, music school and art museum.

name: maryland
sentence: Cumberland is the second largest city in Maryland in the 19th century.

name: maryland
sentence: Supply in the vicinity of natural resources and railways has encouraged its growth into a large manufacturing centre.

name: maryland
sentence: The progressive era of the late 19th and early 20th centuries brought about political reforms.

name: maryland
sentence: In a series of laws passed between 1892 and 1908, reformers worked for standard state-issued ballots (rather than those distributed and marked by parties); obtained closed polling stations to prevent party workers from assisting voters; launched primary elections to prevent party bosses from selecting candidates; and had registered candidates without party symbols, which discouraged illiterates from participating.

name: maryland
sentence: These measures targeted poorly educated whites and blacks.

name: maryland
sentence: The Blacks resisted such efforts, with groups of votes leading the education of voters.The Blacks defeated three efforts to refuse them, making alliances with immigrants to resist various democratic campaigns.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1905, 1907 and 1911, bills on the abandonment of the right to vote were rejected, largely because of the black opposition.

name: maryland
sentence: Blacks accounted for 20 per cent of the electorate and immigrants 15 per cent, and legislators had difficulty designing requirements against blacks who also did not disadvantage immigrants.

name: maryland
sentence: The progressive era has also brought reforms to the working conditions of Maryland's labour force.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1902, the State regulated conditions in mines; prohibited child workers under the age of 12; prescribed compulsory school attendance; and promulgated the first national workers' compensation law.

name: maryland
sentence: The Workers' Compensation Act was overturned by the courts, but was revised and finally enacted in 1910.

name: maryland
sentence: The Great Baltimore Fire of 1904 burned for over 30 hours, destroying 1,526 buildings and covering 70 blocks.

name: maryland
sentence: More than 1,231 firefighters worked to control the fire.

name: maryland
sentence: With the nation's entry into World War I in 1917, new military bases such as Camp Meade, Aberdeen's Proving Field and Edgewood's Arsenal were established.

name: maryland
sentence: Existing facilities, including Fort McHenry, have been significantly expanded.

name: maryland
sentence: After Georgian MP William D. Upshaw openly criticized Maryland in 1923 for not passing prohibition laws, Baltimore Sun's editor, Hamilton Owens, invented the nickname "Free State" for Maryland in this context, which was popularized by H. L. Mencken in a series of newspaper editorials.

name: maryland
sentence: The urban and rural communities of Maryland had different experiences during the Great Depression.

name: maryland
sentence: The "Bonus Army" walked across the state in 1932 on its way to Washington, D.C. Maryland introduced its first income tax in 1937 to generate revenues for schools and well-being.

name: maryland
sentence: The service of passenger and freight steamboats, formerly important in Chesapeake Bay and its numerous tributaries, ended in 1962.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore was an important centre of war production during the Second World War.

name: maryland
sentence: The largest operations were the Bethlehem Steel Fairfield Yard, which built Liberty ships, and Glenn Martin, an aircraft manufacturer.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland experienced population growth following World War II.

name: maryland
sentence: Beginning in the 1960s, while suburban growth was taking place around Washington, D.C. and Baltimore, the state began to adopt a more mid-Atlantic culture, contrary to the traditional southern and tidewater culture that once dominated most of the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Agricultural sectors have given way to residential communities, some of which have been carefully planned, such as Columbia, St. Charles and Montgomery Village.

name: maryland
sentence: At the same time, the interstate road network was built throughout the state, in particular I-95, I-695 and the Capital Beltway Road, which changed travel patterns.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1952, the eastern and western halves of Maryland were first connected by the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, which replaced a nearby ferry service.

name: maryland
sentence: The regions of Maryland experienced economic changes following the Second World War.

name: maryland
sentence: Heavy production decreased in Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: In the four westernmost counties of Maryland, employment in industry, railways and the coal industry has declined.

name: maryland
sentence: On the Lower East Shore, family farms were bought out by major concerns and large poultry farms and vegetable farming became widespread.

name: maryland
sentence: In southern Maryland, tobacco farming has almost disappeared as a result of the development of the suburbs and a tobacco buying program by the state in the 1990s.

name: maryland
sentence: In an effort to reverse the depopulation caused by the loss of workers' industries, Baltimore undertook urban renewal projects in the 1960s with Charles Center and the Baltimore World Trade Center.

name: maryland
sentence: Some have led to the break-up of intact residential neighbourhoods, resulting in social volatility, and some older residential neighbourhoods around the harbour have had renovated units and have become popular with new populations.

name: maryland
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the Maryland population was 6,045,680 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 4.71% since the 2010 U.S. Census and an increase of 2,962 over the previous year.

name: maryland
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 269,166 (464,251 births minus 275,093 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 116,713 people to the State.

name: maryland
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 129,730 persons, and internal migration resulted in a net loss of 13,017 persons.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland population centre is located on the county line between Anne Arundel County and Howard County, in the unincorporated community of Jessup.

name: maryland
sentence: The history of Maryland as a border state has led her to present the characteristics of the northern and southern parts of the United States.

name: maryland
sentence: In general, the rural western Maryland between the Panhandle of West Virginia and Pennsylvania has an Appalachian culture; the regions of the south shore and east of Maryland embody a South culture, while the densely populated central Maryland — radiating outwards from Baltimore and Washington, D.C. — is more common than that of the northeast.The U.S. Census Bureau designates Maryland as one of the states of the South Atlantic, but is generally associated with the States of the Middle Atlantic and/or the Northeast of the United States by other federal agencies, the media and some residents.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2011, 58.0 per cent of the population of Maryland under 1 year of age were from minorities.

name: maryland
sentence: Note: Births in the table do not add up because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, resulting in a higher overall number.

name: maryland
sentence: Spanish (including Spanish Creole) is the second most spoken language in Maryland, after English.

name: maryland
sentence: The third and fourth most widely spoken languages are French (including Patois and Cajun) and Chinese.

name: maryland
sentence: Other commonly spoken languages include various African languages, Korean, German, Tagalog, Russian, Vietnamese, Italian, various Asian languages, Persian, Hindi, and other Indic languages, Greek and Arabic.

name: maryland
sentence: The majority of Maryland's population lives in the central area of the state, in the Baltimore metropolitan area and in the Washington metropolitan area, both of which are part of the Baltimore-Washington metropolitan area.The majority of Maryland's population is concentrated in the cities and suburbs surrounding Washington, D.C., as well as in and around the most populated city of Maryland, Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: Historically, these and many other cities in Maryland have developed along the autumn line, the line along which rivers, streams and streams are interrupted by rapids and/or waterfalls.

name: maryland
sentence: The capital of Maryland, Annapolis, is an exception to this pattern, as it lies along the banks of the Severn River near the point where it flows into Chesapeake Bay.

name: maryland
sentence: The east coast is less populated and more rural, as are the counties of western Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: The two counties west of Maryland, Allegany and Garrett, are mountainous and sparsely populated, more like Western Virginia and Appalachia than the rest of the state.

name: maryland
sentence: The east and west of Maryland, however, are dotted with cities of regional importance, such as Ocean City, Princess Anne and Salisbury on the East Coast and Cumberland, Frostburg and Hancock in West Maryland.The south Maryland is still somewhat rural, but Washington's suburbs have been intruding significantly since the 1960s; major local population centres include Lexington Park, Prince Frederick, California and Waldorf.

name: maryland
sentence: In 1970, the Census Bureau reported that the population of Maryland was 17.8 percent African Americans and 80.4 percent non-Hispanic whites.

name: maryland
sentence: African-Americans make up an important part of the state's population, nearly 30% in 2010.

name: maryland
sentence: Most are descendants of people transported to the region as slaves to West Africa, and many are of mixed race, including of European and Amerindian descent.

name: maryland
sentence: African American concentrations live in Baltimore City, Prince George County, a suburb of Washington, D.C., where many work; Charles County, western Baltimore County, and the southern east coast.

name: maryland
sentence: New people of African descent include 20th-century immigrants and immigrants from Nigeria, especially the Igbo and Yoruba tribes.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is also home to people from other African and Caribbean nations.

name: maryland
sentence: Many immigrants from the Horn of Africa settled in Maryland, where large communities exist in the suburbs of Washington, D.C. (especially Montgomery County and Prince George County) and in the city of Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: The Greater Washington area has the largest population of Ethiopians outside Africa.

name: maryland
sentence: The Ethiopian Greater DC community was historically based in Washington, D.C.'s Adams Morgan and Shaw neighbourhoods, but as the community developed, many Ethiopians settled in Silver Spring.

name: maryland
sentence: The Washington Metropolitan Area, D.C., is also home to large Eritrean and Somali communities.

name: maryland
sentence: The main cases reported by Maryland residents are: German (15%), Irish (11%), English (8%), United States (7%), Italian (6%) and Polish (3%).

name: maryland
sentence: Irish American populations are found throughout the Baltimore region, as well as in the northern and eastern suburbs of Washington, Maryland (descendants of those who moved to the suburbs of previously predominantly Irish neighbourhoods), as well as in Western Maryland, where Irish immigrant workers contributed to the construction of the B & O Railroad.

name: maryland
sentence: Smaller but much older Irish populations are found in southern Maryland, some of whose roots date back to the first colony of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: However, the population remains very culturally active and annual festivals are held.

name: maryland
sentence: A significant percentage of the population of East and South Maryland are descendants of American British ancestry.

name: maryland
sentence: The east coast was established by Protestants, mainly Methodists and the southern counties were initially established by English Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: The western and northern parts of Maryland have a large German-American population.

name: maryland
sentence: The most recent European immigrants of the late 19th and early 20th centuries first settled in Baltimore, attracted by its industrial jobs.

name: maryland
sentence: Many of their ethnic Italian, Polish, Czech, Lithuanian and Greek descendants still live in the area.

name: maryland
sentence: Large ethnic minorities include Eastern Europeans such as Croats, Belarussians, Russians and Ukrainians.

name: maryland
sentence: The share of European immigrants born in Eastern Europe rose significantly between 1990 and 2010.

name: maryland
sentence: After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia, many immigrants from Eastern Europe came to the United States, 12 per cent of whom currently reside in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Hispanic 20th-century immigrants settled in Aspen Hill, Hyattsville/Langley Park, Glenmont/Wheaton, Bladensburg, Riverdale Park, Gaithersburg, and Highlandtown and Greektown in East Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: El Salvadorans are the largest Hispanic group in Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: The Mexicans, Puerto Ricans and Hondurans are other Hispanic groups with large populations in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Although the Salvadoran population is more concentrated in the Washington, D.C. region, and the Puerto Rican population is more concentrated in the Baltimore region, all other major Hispanic groups in the State are also dispersed between these two areas.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has one of the most diverse Hispanic populations in the country, with large populations from various Caribbean and Central American nations.

name: maryland
sentence: Asian Americans are concentrated in the suburbs surrounding Washington, D.C. and Howard County, with American Korean and Taiwanese communities in Rockville, Gaithersburg, Germantown and an American Filipino community in Fort Washington.

name: maryland
sentence: Many American Indians live in the state, especially in central Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: Attracting educated Asians and Africans to professional jobs in the region, Maryland has the fifth proportion of racial minorities in the country.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2006, 645,744 persons were considered to have been born abroad, mainly from Latin America and Asia.

name: maryland
sentence: About 4 per cent are undocumented immigrants.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is also home to a large Korean population.

name: maryland
sentence: In fact, 1.7% are Korean, while on the whole almost 6.0% are Asian.

name: maryland
sentence: According to the analysis of the Williams Institute of the 2010 U.S. Census, 12,538 same-sex couples live in Maryland, representing 5.8 same-sex couples per 1,000 households.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2019, non-Hispanic white Americans accounted for 49.8% of Maryland's population (White Americans, including White Hispanics, were 57.3%), making Maryland a minority majority state.

name: maryland
sentence: 50.2% of Maryland's population is non-white and/or Hispanic/latino, the highest percentage of all East Coast states and the highest percentage after the minority majority states of Hawaii, New Mexico, Texas, California and Nevada.

name: maryland
sentence: By 2031, it is expected that minorities will become the majority of Maryland's eligible voting residents.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has always played an important role in the American Catholic tradition because the English colony of Maryland was designed by George Calvert as a refuge for English Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore was the seat of the first Catholic bishop in the United States (1789), and Emmitsburg was the place of residence and burial for the first American citizen to be canonized, St. Elizabeth Ann Seton.

name: maryland
sentence: Georgetown University, the first Catholic University, was founded in 1789 in what was then part of Maryland.

name: maryland
sentence: The basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary in Baltimore was the first Roman Catholic cathedral built in the United States, and the Archbishop of Baltimore is, although without formal primacy, the quasi-primate of the United States, and often a cardinal.

name: maryland
sentence: Among the immigrants of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries of Eastern and Southern Europe were many Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: Despite its historical importance to the Catholic Church in the United States, the percentage of Catholics in Maryland is below the national average of 20%.

name: maryland
sentence: Demographically, both Protestants and those who don't identify any religion are more numerous than Catholics.

name: maryland
sentence: According to Pew Research Center, 69 percent of Maryland's population identifies as Christian.

name: maryland
sentence: Almost 52% of adults are Protestants.

name: maryland
sentence: After Protestantism, Catholicism is the second largest religious affiliation, accounting for 15% of the population.

name: maryland
sentence: Amish/Menonite communities are located in the counties of St. Mary's, Garrett, and Cecil.

name: maryland
sentence: Judaism is Maryland's largest non-Christian religion with 241,000 adherents, or four per cent of the total population.

name: maryland
sentence: The Jews are numerous in Montgomery County and in Pikesville and Oies Mills, northwest of Baltimore.

name: maryland
sentence: The number of Jewish Americans living in Montgomery County is estimated at 81,500, or about 10 per cent of the total population.

name: maryland
sentence: The world headquarters of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church and the Ahmadiyya Muslim National Headquarters are located in Silver Spring, just outside the District of Columbia.

name: maryland
sentence: The Economic Analysis Bureau estimates that Maryland's gross domestic product in 2016 was $382.4 billion.

name: maryland
sentence: However, Maryland used the real progress indicator, an indicator of well-being, to guide state development, rather than relying solely on growth indicators such as GDP.

name: maryland
sentence: According to the U.S. Census Bureau, Maryland's households are currently the richest in the country, with a median income of $72,483 in 2013, placing them ahead of New Jersey and Connecticut, the second and third respectively.

name: maryland
sentence: Two of Maryland's counties, Howard and Montgomery, are the richest second and eleventh counties in the country, respectively.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has the most millionaires per capita in 2013, a ratio of 7.7 per cent.

name: maryland
sentence: Moreover, the poverty rate of 7.8 per cent of the State is the lowest in the country.

name: maryland
sentence: In 2006, personal income per capita was $43,500, or one fifth of the country.

name: maryland
sentence: In February 2018, the state's unemployment rate was 4.2%.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland's economy benefits from the proximity of the state to the federal government in Washington, D.C., with a focus on technical and administrative tasks for the defence and aeronautics industry and biological research laboratories, as well as the staffing of the satellite government headquarters in the Baltimore/Washington area, suburb and outlying areas.

name: maryland
sentence: The Ft. Meade is the headquarters of the Defense Information Systems Agency, the United States Cyber Command, and the National Security Agency/Central Security Service.

name: maryland
sentence: In addition, a number of educational and medical research establishments are located in the State.

name: maryland
sentence: In fact, the various components of Johns Hopkins University and its medical research centres are now the largest employer in the Baltimore area.

name: maryland
sentence: Overall, white-collar technical and administrative workers account for 25 per cent of Maryland's workforce, due in part to the fact that neighbouring Maryland is part of the Washington metropolitan area where employment in federal government offices is relatively high.

name: maryland
sentence: Manufacturing, although large in dollar terms, is highly diversified, with no subsector contributing more than 20 per cent of the total.

name: maryland
sentence: Typical manufacturing forms include electronics, computer equipment and chemicals.

name: maryland
sentence: The previously powerful primary metals subsector, which used to include what was then the largest steel plant in the world at Sparrows Point, still exists, but it is driven by foreign competition, bankruptcies and mergers.

name: maryland
sentence: During World War II, the Glenn Martin Company (now part of Lockheed Martin) employed approximately 40,000 people.

name: maryland
sentence: Mining other than building materials is virtually limited to coal, which is located in the mountainous western part of the State.

name: maryland
sentence: Brownstone quarries in the east, which gave Baltimore and Washington much of their characteristic architecture in the mid-19th century, were once a predominant natural resource.

name: maryland
sentence: Historically, there were small gold mining operations in Maryland, some near Washington, but they no longer exist.

name: maryland
sentence: One of the main service activities is transportation, which focuses on the port of Baltimore and its associated rail and road access.

name: maryland
sentence: The port was ranked 17th in the United States in terms of tonnage in 2008.

name: maryland
sentence: Although the port deals with a wide variety of products, the most typical imports are raw materials and bulk products, such as iron ore, oil, sugar and fertilizers, often distributed to manufacturing centres relatively close to the inner Midwest by good land transport.

name: maryland
sentence: The port also receives several brands of imported motor vehicles and is the number one car port in the United States

name: maryland
sentence: Baltimore City is one of the 15 largest ports in the nation, and was one of the six main American ports that were part of the February 2006 controversy over the Dubai Ports World Agreement.

name: maryland
sentence: Overall, the state is highly industrialized, with a booming economy and influential technology centres.

name: maryland
sentence: Its computer industries are among the most sophisticated in the United States and the federal government has invested a great deal in the region.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is home to many major military bases and dozens of high-level government jobs.

name: maryland
sentence: The Chesapeake and Delaware Canal is a 23 km canal that connects the Delaware River with the waters of Chesapeake Bay, and in particular the port of Baltimore, which carries 40 percent of the port's maritime traffic.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has a major food production sector.

name: maryland
sentence: Much of this is commercial fishing, centred in Chesapeake Bay, but also off the short Atlantic coast.

name: maryland
sentence: The largest catches by species are blue crab, oysters, striped bass and menhaden.

name: maryland
sentence: The bay is also home to overwintering waterfowl in its wildlife refuges.

name: maryland
sentence: Waterfowl supports a sport tourism sector.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland has vast tracts of fertile agricultural land in its coastal and Piedmontese areas, although land use is hampered by urbanization.

name: maryland
sentence: Agriculture is oriented towards dairy farming (especially in foothills and piedmonts) for large milk heads in neighbouring cities and perishable specialty horticultural crops, such as cucumbers, watermelons, sweet corn, tomatoes, watermelons, squash and peas (Source: USDA Crop Profiles).

name: maryland
sentence: The counties south of the western shore of Chesapeake Bay are warm enough to support a commercial tobacco growing area, which has existed since the early colonial era, but which declined sharply after a takeover by the state government in the 1990s.

name: maryland
sentence: There is also a large automated chicken rearing sector in the south-eastern part of the State.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland food processing plants are the most important type of manufacturing by value in the state.

name: maryland
sentence: Maryland is a major centre for life science research and development.

name: maryland

sentence: The northeast is expected to warm faster than the world average; by 2035, the northeast is expected to be warmer on average at more than 3.6°F (2°C) than in the pre-industrial era.

name: massachusetts

name: massachusetts
sentence: The change in temperature also results in a change in precipitation patterns and an increase in precipitation.

name: massachusetts
sentence: To this end, average precipitation in the northeastern United States increased by 10 per cent between 1895 and 2011, and the number of high precipitation events increased by 70 per cent during this period.

name: massachusetts
sentence: These patterns of increased rainfall are concentrated in winter and spring.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Increased temperatures and increased precipitation will result in earlier snowmelts and drier soils during the summer months.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Climate change in Massachusetts will bring about a significant change in the environment and built ecosystems.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In Boston alone, the costs of climate change storms will result in damage of $5 to $100 billion.

name: massachusetts

name: massachusetts
sentence: Warmer temperatures will also disrupt the migration of birds and the flowering of flora.

name: massachusetts
sentence: To ensure that the Commonwealth does not warm up more than 1.5°C of pre-industrialization levels, the state will strive to achieve zero net emissions and an overall reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 85% by 2050.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The State of Massachusetts has developed a plethora of incentives to encourage the implementation of renewable energy, household appliances and efficient domestic facilities.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Mass Save was created in collaboration with the state by Berkshire Gas, Blackstone Gas Company, Cape Light Compact, Eversource, Liberty Utilities, National Grid and Unitil to provide homeowners and tenants with incentives to renovate their homes with efficient HVAC equipment and other household appliances.

name: massachusetts
sentence: For example, up to $100 off can be obtained for upgrading an ENERGY STAR-certified smart or programmable thermostat.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other appliances, such as water heaters, air conditioners, washers and dryers, as well as heat pumps, are eligible for additional rebates.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The concept of Mass Save was created in 2008 by the adoption of the Green Communities Act 2008 during Deval Patrick's term of office.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The main objective of the Green Communities Act was to reduce fossil fuel consumption in the state and to encourage the adoption of new and more efficient technologies.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Among other things, one of the consequences of this law has been the obligation for public service program administrators to invest in energy saving, as opposed to the purchase and production of additional energy when economically feasible.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In Massachusetts, eleven program administrators, including NSTAR, National Grid, Western Massachusetts Electric, Cape Light Compact, Till and Berkshire Gas, jointly hold the program rights, together with the Ministry of Energy Resources (DOER) and the Advisory Council on Energy Efficiency (CCEE).

name: massachusetts
sentence: Mass Save also conducts home energy assessments at no cost so that homeowners, tenants and small business owners can learn about improving home energy efficiency and finding opportunities to save money and energy.

name: massachusetts
sentence: During the home evaluation, Mass Save provides ENERGY STAR certified LED bulbs, power bands, low-flow shower heads, faucet aerators and efficient thermostats for free.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In addition, air leaks will be detected in the house or building and corrected, and recommendations will be made for additional insulation to reduce the loss of heated or cooled air.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Reductions of 75% or more are available on these insulation enhancements.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Due to the COVID-19, Mass Save is currently conducting remote assessments.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Residents can plan a remote assessment using the program's website or telephone line.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The State Revenue Service provides incentives for the installation of solar panels.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In addition to the federal residential renewable energy credit, residents of Massachusetts may qualify for a tax credit of up to 15%.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Once installed, tables are eligible for net counting.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Some municipalities will offer up to $1.20 per watt, up to 50 percent of the cost of the system on photovoltaic networks of 25 kW or less.

sentence: The Massachusetts Department of Energy also offers low interest rate fixed-rate financing with loan support for low-income residents.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The programme is currently due to end on 31 December 2020.

name: massachusetts
sentence: As part of the Massachusetts Ministry of Energy's efforts to encourage the use of renewable energies, the MOR-EV or Massachusetts Offers Debates for Electric Vehicles initiative was created.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Under this incentive measure, residents may be entitled to a government incentive of up to $2,500 for the purchase or rental of an electric vehicle or $1,500 for the purchase or rental of a plug-in hybrid vehicle.

name: massachusetts
sentence: This rebate is in addition to the U.S. Department of Energy's tax credits for the purchase of plug-in electric and hybrid vehicles.

name: massachusetts
sentence: For income-eligible residents, Mass Save has partnered with Massachusetts Community Action Program and LEAN (Low-Income Energy Affordability Network) organizations to provide housing modernization assistance to residents, which will allow for more efficient use of energy.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Residents may be entitled to a replacement of their heating system, insulation system, appliances and thermostats if they meet the income requirements set out on the Mass Save website.

name: massachusetts
sentence: For residents with more than 5 family residential buildings, there are additional limited income benefits available through the LEAN.

name: massachusetts
sentence: If at least 50% of the building's residents are eligible for low income, energy efficiency improvements, such as those available through Mass Save, are available.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Residential structures managed by not-for-profit organizations, for gainful activities or housing organizations can benefit from these programs.

sentence: In 2020, voters approved two voting measures, one aimed at increasing the limit on money from gas and oil sales from government-owned land that could benefit public parks, and the other at requiring a search or seizure warrant for electronic data and communications.

name: michigan
sentence: The Government of the State is decentralized between three levels: the State as a whole, the county and the canton.

name: michigan
sentence: The counties are administrative divisions of the State, and the cantons are administrative divisions of a county.

name: michigan
sentence: Both exercise the authority of the State, located to meet the special needs of their courts, as provided for in the law of the State.

name: michigan
sentence: There were 83 counties in Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: Cities, state universities and villages have varying degrees of administrative authority.

name: michigan
sentence: Cities of origin may in general do anything that is not prohibited by law.

name: michigan
sentence: The fifteen state universities have a broad power and can do anything within the parameters of their status as educational institutions which are not prohibited by the constitution of the State.

name: michigan
sentence: The villages, on the other hand, have a limited membership rule and are not entirely autonomous of the county and canton in which they are located.

name: michigan
sentence: There are two types of townships in Michigan: the township of general law and the charter.

name: michigan
sentence: The charter canton status was created by the Legislature in 1947 and grants additional powers and a wired administration in order to ensure greater protection against annexation by a city.

name: michigan
sentence: As of April 2001, there were 127 chartered townships in Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: In general, charter cantons have much of the same powers as a city, but without the same level of obligations.

name: michigan
sentence: For example, a charter township may have its own fire department, water and sewer service, police service, etc., as well as a city, but it is not required to have these things, while cities must provide these services.

name: michigan
sentence: Charter Townships may choose to use county-wide services, such as the deputies of the county sheriff's office instead of a home-based prescription force.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan consists of two peninsulas separated by the Strait of Mackinac.

name: michigan
sentence: The 45th parallel north crosses the state, marked by road signs and the Polar-Equator trail, along a line comprising Mission Point Light near Traverse City, the towns of Gaylord and Alpena in the Lower Peninsula and Menominee in the Upper Peninsula.

name: michigan
sentence: With the exception of two small areas drained by the Mississippi River by the Wisconsin River on the upper peninsula and the Kankakee-Illinois River on the lower peninsula, Michigan is drained by the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence watershed and is the only state where most of its lands are drained.

name: michigan
sentence: No state point is located more than six miles (9.7 km) from a natural water source or more than 85 miles (137 km) from a Great Lakes coastline.

name: michigan
sentence: The Great Lakes bordering Michigan from east to west are Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, and Lake Superior.

name: michigan
sentence: The state is limited to the south by the states of Ohio and Indiana, sharing the boundaries of lands and waters with both.

name: michigan
sentence: The western boundaries of Michigan are almost entirely bounded, from south to north, with Illinois and Wisconsin in Lake Michigan; then a land boundary with Wisconsin and the upper peninsula, which is primarily bounded by the Menominee and Montreal rivers; then water boundaries again, in Lake Superior, with Wisconsin and Minnesota to the west, captured by the Canadian province of Ontario to the north and east.

name: michigan
sentence: The high forested peninsula is relatively mountainous to the west.

name: michigan
sentence: Porcupine Mountains, which are part of one of the oldest mountain ranges in the world, reach an altitude of nearly 2,000 feet (610 m) above sea level and form the watershed between streams flowing into Lake Superior and Lake Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has the second longest shore of any condition – 3288 miles (5,292 km), including 1,056 miles (1,699 km) of island shoreline.

name: michigan
sentence: The state has many large islands, the main of which are North Manitou and South Manitou, Beaver and Fox in Lake Michigan, Royal Island and Grande Isle in Lake Superior, Marquette Islands, White Woods and Mackinac in Lake Huron and Neebish Islands, Sugar and Drummond in the St. Mary's River.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has about 150 lighthouses, most of which are American states.

name: michigan

sentence: They were built to project light at night and serve as a point of reference during the day to safely guide passenger ships and cargo ships travelling in the Great Lakes.
