sentence: See Lighthouses in the U.S.

name: michigan
sentence: The rivers in the state are generally small, short and shallow, and few are navigable.

name: michigan
sentence: The main rivers are the Detroit River, the St. Marys River and the St. Clair River, which connect the Great Lakes; the Au Sable River, Cheboygan and Saginaw, which flow through Lake Huron; the Ontonagon and Tahquamenon River, which flow through Lake Superior; and the Saint Joseph, Kalamazoo, Grand, Muskegon, Manistee and Escanaba River, which flow through Lake Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: There are 11,037 inland lakes, representing a total of 3,380 km2 of inland water of 1,305 square miles, in addition to 38,575 square miles (99,910 km2) of Great Lakes water.

name: michigan
sentence: No points in Michigan are more than six miles (9.7 km) from an inland lake or more than 85 miles (137 km) from one of the Great Lakes.

name: michigan
sentence: The State is home to several areas maintained by the National Parks Service, including Royal Island National Park in Lake Superior, approximately 48 km southeast of Thunder Bay, Ontario.

name: michigan
sentence: Other national protected areas include Keweenaw National Historic Park, Roches-photos National Side Lake, Sleeping Dunes National Side Lake, Huron National Forest, Manist National Forest, Hiawatha National Forest, Ottawa National Forest, and Father Marquette National Memorial.

name: michigan
sentence: The largest section of the northern country's national scenography trail crosses Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: With 78 state parks, 19 state recreation areas and six state forests, Michigan has the largest state park and state forest system in any state.

name: michigan
sentence: These parks and forests include Holland State Park, Mackinac Island State Park, Sable State Forest and Mackinaw State Forest.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has a continental climate, although there are two distinct areas.

name: michigan
sentence: The southern and central parts of the Lower Peninsula (south of Saginaw Bay and the Grand Rapids region southward) have a warmer climate (climate classification Köppen Dfa) with warm summers and cold winters.

name: michigan
sentence: The northern part of the Lower Peninsula and the whole of the Upper Peninsula have a more severe climate (Köppen Dfb), with warm summers, but shorter and longer, cold to very cold winters.

name: michigan
sentence: Some of the average state temperatures are below the freeze from December to February, and until early March in remote northern areas.

name: michigan
sentence: During winter until mid-February, the state is often subject to heavy snowfall.

name: michigan
sentence: The average condition ranges from 30 to 40 inches (76 to 102 cm) of precipitation per year; however, some areas of the lower northern and upper peninsula have an average of almost 160 inches (4,100 mm) of snowfall per year.

name: michigan
sentence: The highest temperature recorded by Michigan was 112°F (44°C) at Mio on July 13, 1936, and the coldest temperature recorded was −51°F (−46°C) at Vanderbilt on February 9, 1934.

name: michigan
sentence: The government conducts an average of 30 days of stormy activity per year.

name: michigan
sentence: These can be serious, especially in the southern part of the state.

name: michigan
sentence: The State has an average of 17 tornadoes a year, which are more frequent in the southernmost part of the State.

name: michigan
sentence: The parts of the southern border have been almost as vulnerable historically as the states to the west and in the Tornado gangway.

name: michigan
sentence: For this reason, many communities in the very southern regions of the state have tornado sirens to warn the inhabitants to approach tornadoes.

name: michigan
sentence: Further north, in central Michigan, northern Michigan, and the upper peninsula, tornadoes are rare.

name: michigan
sentence: The state's geological formation is very varied, the Michigan Basin being the largest formation.

name: michigan
sentence: Primary blocks are found throughout the upper peninsula (mainly of primitive origin), while secondary deposits cover the entire lower peninsula.

name: michigan
sentence: The upper peninsula has lower Silurian sandstones, limestone, copper and iron-bearing rocks, which correspond to Canada's Huron system.

name: michigan
sentence: The central portion of the Lower Peninsula contains measurements of coal and rocks from the Pennsylvania period.

name: michigan
sentence: Devonian and sub-carboniferous deposits are scattered throughout the state.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan rarely experiences earthquakes, so far mainly smaller earthquakes that do not cause significant damage.

name: michigan
sentence: An earthquake of 4.6 magnitude hit in August 1947.

name: michigan
sentence: More recently, an earthquake of 4.2 magnitude occurred on Saturday, May 2, 2015, shortly after noon, approximately five miles south of Galesburg, Michigan (9 miles southeast of Kalamazoo) in central Michigan, approximately 140 miles west of Detroit, according to the US Geological Survey's Earthquake Information Centre, Colorado.

name: michigan
sentence: According to Governor Rick Snyder's office, no major damage has been reported.

name: michigan
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that Michigan's population was 9,986,857 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 1.04 per cent over the 2010 U.S. Census of 9,883,635.

name: michigan
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 177,254 people (i.e. 1,043,213 births minus 865,959 deaths) and a decrease due to net migration of 73,053 people.

name: michigan
sentence: Immigration resulted in a net increase of 193,031 people and migration within the United States resulted in a net decrease of 266,084 people.

name: michigan
sentence: The population centre of Michigan is located in Shiawassee County, in the southeast corner of the civil township of Bennington, which is northwest of the village of Morrice.

sentence: According to the 2010 American Community Survey for the U.S. Census, the state had 592,212 foreign-born inhabitants, or 6.0 per cent of the total.

name: michigan
sentence: The Roman Catholic Church has six dioceses and an Archdiocese in Michigan; Gaylord, Grand Rapids, Kalamazoo, Lansing, Marquette, Saginaw and Detroit.

name: michigan
sentence: According to the 2010 survey of the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the Roman Catholic Church is the largest denomination by the number of adherents, with 1,717,296 members.

name: michigan

name: michigan
sentence: The parish of Sainte-Anne in Detroit, founded in 1701 by Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac, is the second Roman Catholic parish in the United States.

name: michigan
sentence: On March 8, 1833, the Holy See officially established a diocese in the territory of Michigan, which included all Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Dakotas east of the Mississippi River.

name: michigan
sentence: When Michigan became a state in 1837, the boundary of the diocese of Detroit was redesigned to coincide with that of the state; the other dioceses were later carved into the diocese of Detroit but remained in the ecclesiastical province of Detroit.

name: michigan
sentence: In 2010, the largest Protestant denominations were the united Methodist Church with 228,521 members; followed by the Lutheran-Synod Church of Missouri with 219618 and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 120,598 members.

sentence: The Reformed Christian Church in North America had nearly 100,000 members and over 230 congregations in Michigan.

Michigan is the third largest producer of Christmas trees with 60,520 acres (245 km2) of land devoted to Christmas tree development.

sentence: Michigan was the second largest in the United States in 2004 for new facilities and expansions.

sentence: In August 2009, the Michigan and Detroit automotive industry received $1.36 billion in subsidies from the U.S. Department of Energy for the manufacture of electric vehicle technologies that are expected to generate 6,800 immediate jobs and employ 40,000 people in the state by 2020.

sentence: From 2007 to 2009, Michigan ranked third in the U.S. for its new facilities and expansions.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan's personal income tax is a flat rate of 4.25%.

name: michigan
sentence: In addition, 22 cities impose income taxes; rates are set at 1 per cent for residents and 0.5 per cent for non-residents in all but four cities.

name: michigan
sentence: The State of Michigan's sales tax is 6%, although items such as food and medicines are exempt.

name: michigan
sentence: Property taxes are assessed at the local level, but the local valuation of each owner contributes to the state's education tax at six factories (a rate of $6 per $1,000 of land value).

name: michigan
sentence: Property taxes are subject to appeal to local review committees and must be approved by the local electorate in order to exceed the millage rates prescribed by state law and local charters.

name: michigan
sentence: In 2011, the government repealed its business tax and replaced it with a corporate income tax of 6%, which significantly reduced business taxes.

name: michigan
sentence: Section IX of the Michigan Constitution also sets limits on the amount of tax that the state may impose.

name: michigan
sentence: A 6% user tax is levied on goods purchased outside the State (which are introduced and used in the State), on par with sales tax.

name: michigan
sentence: The use tax applies to Internet sales/purchases outside Michigan and is equivalent to sales tax.

name: michigan
sentence: A wide variety of commodity, fruit and vegetable crops are grown in Michigan, making it the second largest country in the United States in the diversity of its agriculture.

name: michigan
sentence: There are 54,800 farms using 10 million acres (40,000 km2) of land that sold $6.49 billion worth of commodities in 2010.

sentence: There were 78,000 sheep, one million cattle, one million pigs and more than three million chickens in the state's livestock.

sentence: Forests, lakes and thousands of kilometers of beaches are major attractions.

sentence: Montana is a state in the northwestern United States of America.

name: montana
sentence: It is bordered by Idaho to the west, North Dakota and South Dakota to the east, Wyoming to the south and the Canadian provinces of Alberta, British Columbia and Saskatchewan to the north.

name: montana
sentence: It is the fourth largest state by region, the eighth smallest populous state, and the third least dense densely populated state.

name: montana
sentence: The western half of Montana contains numerous mountain ranges, while half is characterized by prairie terrain and western badlands, with more (although smaller) mountain ranges throughout the state.

name: montana
sentence: In total, 77 named chains are part of the Rocky Mountains.

name: montana
sentence: Montana has no official nickname, but several unofficial names, including "Big Sky Country", "The Treasure State", "Land of the Shining Mountains", and "The Last Best Place".

name: montana
sentence: The economy is mainly based on agriculture, including livestock and grain farming.

name: montana
sentence: Other significant economic resources include oil, gas, coal, mining and lumber.

name: montana
sentence: The health, service and government sectors are also important to the government economy.

name: montana
sentence: The fastest growing area in Montana is tourism, with nearly 13 million annual tourists visiting Glacier National Park, Yellowstone National Park, Beartooth Highway, Flathead Lake, Big Sky Resort and other attractions.

name: montana
sentence: The name Montana comes from the Spanish word montaña, which in turn comes from the Latin word montanea, which means "mountain" or more widely "mountainous country".

name: montana
sentence: Montaña del Norte is the name given by the first Spanish explorers to the whole western mountainous region.

name: montana
sentence: The name Montana was added in 1863 to a bill of the United States House Committee on Territories (then chaired by James Ashley of Ohio) for the territory that was to become the territory of Idaho.

name: montana
sentence: The name was changed by representatives Henry Wilson (Massachusetts) and Benjamin F. Harding (Oregon), who complained Montana had "no sense".

name: montana
sentence: When Ashley introduced a bill to establish a temporary government in 1864 for a new territory to be dug out of Idaho, he again chose Montana's territory.

name: montana
sentence: This time, Rep. Samuel Cox, also from Ohio, objected to the name.

name: montana
sentence: Cox complained that the name was a bad name given most of the territory was not mountainous and a Native American name would be more appropriate than a Spanish name.

name: montana
sentence: Other names such as Shoshone were suggested, but the Territorial Committee decided that they could appoint him as they wished, so that the original name of Montana had been adopted.

name: montana
sentence: Montana is one of eight mountain states, located north of the region known as the western United States.

sentence: It is bordered by North Dakota and South Dakota to the east.

name: montana
sentence: Wyoming is to the south, Idaho to the west and to the southwest, and the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan are to the north, making it the only state to establish a border between three Canadian provinces.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a state in the northeastern United States of America.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bordered by Massachusetts in the south, Vermont in the west, Maine and Atlantic in the east, and the Canadian province of Quebec in the north.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the 5th smallest by region and the 10th least populated state of the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Concord is the national capital, while Manchester is the biggest city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has no general sales tax, or income tax other than interest and dividends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire primary is the first primary in the U.S. presidential election cycle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its license plates bear the motto of the State, "Live Free or Die".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The nickname of the State, "The Granitic State", refers to its vast granite formations and quarries.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In January 1776 it became the first colony in British North America to establish a government independent of the authority of the Kingdom of Great Britain; it was the first to establish its own state constitution.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Six months later, it became one of the first 13 colonies that signed the United States Declaration of Independence and, in June 1788, it was the ninth state to ratify the United States Constitution, which gave effect to that document.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, New Hampshire was an important centre for textile manufacturing, footwear manufacturing and paper, with Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester at a time being the largest textile cotton factory in the world.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many mills were located along various rivers in the state, particularly the Merrimack and Connecticut rivers.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many French Canadians migrated to New Hampshire to work the mills in the late 19th and early 20th centuries; New Hampshire still ranks second among the states by the percentage of people claiming French American ancestry, with 24.5% of the state identifying itself as such.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Manufacturing centres such as Manchester, Nashua and Berlin were hit hard in the 1930s and 1940s as large manufacturing industries left New England and settled in the southern United States or abroad, reflecting national trends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 1950s and 1960s, defence contractors moved into many former mills, such as Sanders Associates in Nashua; the population of southern New Hampshire increased from the 1980s as major roads connecting the area to Greater Boston and established several sleeping communities in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With some of the highest ski mountains on the East Coast, New Hampshire's major recreational attractions include skiing, snowmobiles and other winter sports, hiking and mountaineering (Monadnock Mountain in the southwest corner of the state is one of the most climbing mountains in the United States), autumn foliage observation, summer cottages along many lakes and the sea coast, motorsports at the New Hampshire Motor Speedway, and Moto Week, a popular motorcycle rally held in Weirs Beach in June.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountain National Forest connects the Vermont and Maine parts of the Appalachian Trail and has the automatic Mount Washington Road, where visitors can drive to the top of Mount Washington (1,917 metres).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state was named after the south of the English county of Hampshire by Captain John Mason.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is part of the New England region, in six states.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bounded by Quebec, Canada, north and northwest; Maine and Atlantic to the east; Massachusetts to the south; and Vermont to the west.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The main areas of New Hampshire are the Northern Great Woods, the White Mountains, the Lakes Region, the Seacoast, the Merrimack Valley, the Monadnock Region, and the Dartmouth-Lake Sunapee Region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coast of all coastal states in the United States, 29 km long, sometimes only 33 km.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains range in New Hampshire extends over the north-central part of the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range includes Mount Washington, the highest in the northeastern United States, the site of the highest second wind speed ever recorded, and Mount Adams and Mount Jefferson.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With strong winds of hurricanes every three days on average, more than a hundred deaths recorded among visitors, and visible krumholtz (dwarfs, matt trees like a bonsai carpet), the climate on the upper part of Mount Washington inspired the meteorological observatory on the summit to pretend that the region has the "worst time in the world".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains house the rock formation called the Old Mountain Man, a profile similar to that of Franconia Notch, until the disintegration of the formation in May 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Even after its loss, the old man remains a lasting symbol for the state, seen on state road signs, car registration plates, and many governmental and private entities around New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the southwestern corner of New Hampshire, Mount Monadnock gave its name to a class of earth forms — a monadnock — indicating, in geomorphology, any isolated, resistant peak that rises from a less resilient plain.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The major rivers include the Merrimack River (177 km) which crosses the lower half of the north-south state before passing through Massachusetts and reaching the sea at Newburyport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its tributaries are the Contoocook River, the Pemigewasset River, and the Winnipeasukee River.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 660 km-long Connecticut River, which begins at Connecticut Lakes in New Hampshire and flows south to Connecticut, defines the western boundary with Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state border is not at the centre of this river, as is usually the case, but at the low line on the Vermont side; that is, the entire river along the Vermont border (guard areas where water levels have been raised by dam) is located in New Hampshire.

sentence: New Hampshire is situated in the biome of mixed and broad-leaved temperate forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a humid continental climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Dfa in some areas of the south, Dfb in most of the state and subarctic Dfc in some areas of the north of the highlands), with warm and humid summers and long, cold and snowy winters.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Precipitation is distributed fairly equitably throughout the year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The climate in the southeast is moderated by the Atlantic Ocean and the winters are on average relatively milder (for New Hampshire), while the northern and inner parts have colder temperatures and lower humidity.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Winters are cold and snowy throughout the state, and particularly severe in the northern and mountain regions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual snowfall varies from 60 inches (150 cm) to more than 100 inches (250 cm) on a state-wide basis.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The average of diurnal peaks between the mid-1970s and the lower 1980s (24–28 °C) in the state as a whole in July, with nocturnal troughs in the mid-50s to the lower 1960s (13–15 °C).

sentence: January temperatures range from an average height of 34°F (1°C) on the coast to minimum night temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) at extreme north and high altitudes.

sentence: Average annual precipitation at the state level is about 40 inches (100 cm) and some variations occur in the White Mountains due to differences in altitude and annual snowfall.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The highest temperature recorded by New Hampshire was 106°F (41°C) at Nashua on 4 July 1911, while the lowest recorded temperature was -47°F (−44°C) at the top of Mount Washington on 29 January 1934.

sentence: Extreme snow is often associated with a nor'easter, such as the 78's Blizzard and the 1993 Blizzard, when several feet accumulate through parts of the state over 24 to 48 hours.

sentence: Lighter snowfalls of several inches occur frequently throughout the winter, often associated with an Alberta clipper.

name: new_hampshire

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has an average of less than 20 days of thunderstorms per year and two tornadoes occur annually across the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A Pew survey showed that the religious affiliations of New Hampshire residents were as follows: Protestants 30%, Catholics 26%, LDS (Mormon) 1%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2%, and non-religious 36%.

sentence: A survey suggests that people in New Hampshire and Vermont are less likely than other Americans to attend weekly services and only 54% say they are "absolutely certain that there is a God" compared to 71% in the rest of the nation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire and Vermont are also at the lowest levels among states engaged in religion.

sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the largest denominations are the Catholic Church with 311028 members; the United Church of Christ with 26321 members; and the Methodist Church with 18029 members.

sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Hampshire's total revenue in 2018 was $86 billion, ranking 40th in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its agricultural production is dairy products, nurseries, cattle, apples and eggs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its industrial products are machines, electrical equipment, rubber and plastic products, and tourism is a major component of the economy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has undergone a major change in its economic base during the 20th century.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, the base was made up of traditional New England textiles, footwear manufacturing and small machine shops, taking advantage of low-wage labour from nearby small farms and Quebec regions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Today, of the total value of the state's manufacturing dollar, these sectors only contribute two per cent to textiles, two per cent to leather goods and nine per cent to machining.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They have experienced a sharp decline due to obsolete factories and the attractiveness of cheaper wages in the southern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire today has a broad and growing economy, with a state GDP growth rate of 2.2% in 2018.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The government's main economic sectors in 2018, based on its contribution to GDP, are: 15% of real estate and leasing; 13% of professional business services; 12% of manufacturing industry; 10% of government and government services; and 9% of health and social services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state budget for 2018 was $5.97 billion, including $1.79 billion in federal funds.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The question of taxation is controversial in New Hampshire, which has a property tax (under municipal control) but no sales tax or income tax.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has lower taxes on meals, housing, vehicles, business and investment income, and tolls on state roads.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, New Hampshire's energy use and per capita energy consumption are among the lowest in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Seabrook Nuclear Generating Station, near Portsmouth, is the largest nuclear reactor in New England and supplied 57% of New Hampshire's electricity generation and 27% of its electricity consumption in 2017.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016 and 2017, New Hampshire obtained a larger share of its wind power production than coal-fired power plants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Approximately 32% of New Hampshire's electricity consumption comes from renewable resources (including nuclear, hydro, wind and other renewable resources).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was a net exporter of electricity, exporting 63 trillion British thermal units (18 TWh).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's residential electricity consumption is low compared to the national average, partly because demand for air conditioning is low during the generally mild summer months and because few households use electricity as a primary energy source for home heating.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nearly half of New Hampshire's households use fuel oil for winter heating, which is one of the largest shares in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has renewable energy potential such as wind, hydro and wood.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has no general sales tax or personal income tax (the State taxes, at a rate of 5%, income from dividends and interest), and the legislator has exercised tax restrictions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Efforts to diversify the general economy of the State have continued.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The absence of a general tax system in New Hampshire has resulted in the state's local communities having some of the highest property taxes in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the overall tax burden of the State is relatively low; in 2010, New Hampshire ranked 44th among the states for the combined average tax burden of the State and local authorities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's workforce accounts for 90 per cent of non-agricultural employment, 18 per cent in trade, transport and public services, 17 per cent in education and health care, 12 per cent in government, 11 per cent in professional and commercial services, and 10 per cent in recreation and hospitality.

sentence: New Hampshire is a state that controls alcoholic beverages and, through the State Alcohol Commission, takes $100 million from the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Hampshire of 1783 is the supreme law of the State, followed by the revised annotated New Hampshire Statutes and the Administrative Code of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They are roughly similar to the U.S. Federal Constitution, the U.S. Code and the Code of Federal Regulations respectively.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a bifurcated executive power, composed of the governor and a five-member executive council that votes on government contracts worth more than $5,000 and that "advises and consents" to the governor's appointments to important government positions such as department heads, all judicial functions and all requests for pardons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire does not have a Lieutenant Governor; the Speaker acts as an "interim Governor" whenever the Governor is unable to perform his or her duties.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has 10 counties and 234 cities and towns.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a "Dillon Rule" state, which means that the state retains all powers that are not specifically granted to municipalities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite this, the legislative branch is strongly in favour of local control, particularly with regard to land use regulation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The municipalities of New Hampshire are classified as cities, which differ essentially in form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most cities generally operate according to the form of government of municipal assemblies, where registered voters in the city act as municipal legislatures, and a selection council acts as the city's executive.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The major cities and the thirteen cities of the state operate either in the form of a council, in the form of a council or in the form of a council.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is no difference, from the point of view of the state government, between cities and cities, apart from the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All state statutes treat all municipalities in the same manner.

sentence: New Hampshire has a small number of unincorporated areas known as grants, locations, purchases or townships.

sentence: These sites are limited to the lack of self-government, and services are generally provided by neighbouring cities or by the county or state if necessary.

sentence: In the past, New Hampshire often voted Republican.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Between 1856 and 1988, New Hampshire voted six times for the democratic presidential post: Woodrow Wilson (twice), Franklin D. Roosevelt (three times), and Lyndon B. Johnson (one time).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: From 1992, New Hampshire became a swing state in national and local elections and, at that time, supported the Democrats in all presidential elections, with the exception of 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It was the only state in the country to move from the support of Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 election to that of his democratic opponent in the 2004 election, when John Kerry, senator of nearby Massachusetts, won the state.

sentence: The Democrats dominated the elections in New Hampshire in 2006 and 2008.

sentence: In 2006, the Democrats won both seats in Congress (elected Carol Shea-Porter in the first district and Paul Hodes in the second), re-elected Governor John Lynch, and won a majority on the Executive Council and in both chambers for the first time since 1911.

sentence: In 2008, the Democrats retained their majorities, their government and their seats in Congress; and former Governor Jeanne Shaheen beat outgoing Republican John E. Sununu for the U.S. senator in a reshuffle of the 2002 competition.

sentence: The 2008 elections resulted in women holding a majority of 13 of the 24 seats in New Hampshire Senatte, a first for any legislative body in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2010, the Republicans made historic gains in New Hampshire, capturing veto-proof majorities in the state's legislature, taking the five seats on the Executive Council, electing a new American senator, Kelly Ayotte, winning both seats in the US Chamber, and reducing the margin of victory of outgoing Governor John Lynch over his 2006 and 2008 victories.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the northeastern part of the United States in the Middle Atlantic region.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by New York State, to the east, south-east and south by the Atlantic Ocean, to the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania, and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 residents in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, and the biggest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of the counties in New Jersey are located in the combined statistical regions of New York City or Philadelphia; therefore, the largest metropolitan area in the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was first inhabited by Native Americans for at least 2,800 years, the Lenape being the dominant group at the time of the arrival of Europeans in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European colonies of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The English then took control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey – after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey – and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several major battles during the American Revolutionary War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, the factories of the "six major" cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the country's industrial revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeastern megapolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the twenty-first century, the state's economy became increasingly diverse, while its multicultural population began to return to more urban environments within the state, surpassing the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all US states, with 9.76% of households, or more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million, meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, it was the second poorest state in the United States by median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public school system ranks consistently among or among the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey is bordered by North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the North American-Africa collision gave rise to the Appalachian Mountains.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, the ice age led to glaciers reaching New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as many rivers, marshes and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Originally, New Jersey was established by Amerindians, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is Lenape's name for the country that is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in corn farming to supplement their hunting and harvesting activities in the area surrounding the Delaware River, the lower Hudson River and the western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Lenape society was divided into matrilineal clans based on common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: Turtle, Turkey, and Wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first met the Dutch in the early 17th century, and their main relationship with Europeans was the fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first Europeans to claim land from New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherlands consisted of parts of the modern states of the Middle Atlantic.

name: new_jersey

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most of the daily work in New Jersey courts is done by the municipal court, where simple traffic violations, minor criminal offences, and small civil cases are heard.

name: new_jersey
sentence: More serious criminal and civil cases are handled by the Superior Court for each county.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All judges of the Superior Court shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the members of the State Senate.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Each judge has an initial term of seven years, after which he or she may be reappointed until the age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's judicial system is unusual in that it still has separate courts of law and fairness, like its neighbour Delaware, but unlike most other American states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court of New Jersey is divided into Law and Chancery Divisions at trial level; the Law Division hears both criminal and civil cases where the plaintiff's main remedy is damages, while the Chancery Division hears family cases, civil suits where the plaintiff's main remedy is a fair remedy, and trials under review.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court also has an Appeal Division, which operates as the State Intermediate Court of Appeal.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Superior Court are assigned by the Chief Justice to the Appeals Division.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There is also a Tax Court, which is a court with limited jurisdiction.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Tax Court hear appeals from tax decisions of the Tax County Councils.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They also have before them appeals concerning decisions rendered by the Director of the Taxation Division on matters such as state income, sales taxes and business taxes, and property refunds.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Appeals from decisions of the Tax Court shall be heard by the Appeal Division of the Superior Court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Tax Court are appointed by the Governor for initial terms of seven years and are reappointed until they reach the mandatory retirement age of 70 years.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are 12 judges of the Tax Court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is divided into 21 counties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was completely divided into counties in 1692.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the only state in the nation where elected county representatives are called "Freeholders", which governs each county on its own board of directors of the elected Freeholders.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The number of free owners in each county shall be determined by referendum and shall be composed of three, five, seven or nine members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Depending on the county, executive and legislative functions may be exercised by the board of directors of free owners elected or divided into different branches of government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 16 counties, the members of the board of directors of the selected Freeholders perform legislative and executive functions on a commission basis, each freeholder being responsible for a department or group of departments.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the other five counties (Atlantic, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Mercer), there is a directly elected county executive who performs the executive functions while the board of directors of the voting rights holders retains a legislative and supervisory role.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In counties without executive cadres, a county administrator (or county director) may be hired to provide day-to-day administration of county functions.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey currently has 565 municipalities; this number was 566 before the merger of Princeton Township and Princeton Borough to form the Municipality of Princeton on January 1, 2013.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike other states, all the land in New Jersey is part of a municipality.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2008, Governor Jon Corzine proposed to reduce state aid to all cities of less than 10,000 people in order to encourage mergers to reduce administrative costs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In May 2009, the Commission for the Reorganization and Consolidation of Local Units undertook a study on some 40 small communities in southern Jersey to determine which could be good candidates for consolidation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: From the 20th century, largely driven by reform objectives, a series of six modern forms of government were implemented.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Walsh Act, enacted in 1911 by the Legislative Assembly of New Jersey, provided for a three- or five-member non-partisanly elected commission.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The 1923 Municipal Director Act, which provided for a non-partisan council, provided for a weak mayor elected by and among council members, and introduced a government structure to manage municipal affairs with a manager appointed for day-to-day administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Faulkner Act, originally enacted in 1950 and largely amended in 1981, offers four basic plans: the mayor-counsel, the council-manager, the small municipality and the mayor-counsel-administrative.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Act offers many choices to communities that prefer strong executive and professional management of municipal affairs and provides great flexibility to allow municipalities to choose the characteristics of their government: the number of seats on the council; the seats chosen in general, by neighbourhoods or by combination of the two; staggered or concurrent mandates; and a mayor chosen by the council or directly elected by the voters.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most large municipalities and a majority of New Jersey residents are governed by municipalities with Faulkner Charters Act.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Municipalities can also formulate their own form of government and operate under a Special Charter with the approval of the Legislative Assembly of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although municipalities retain their names derived from the types of government, they may have changed for one of the modern forms of government, or even more so in the past for one of the other traditional forms, leading to municipalities whose formal names are rather flouted for the general public.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, although there are four municipalities that are officially village-type, Loch Arbour is the only one left with the form of village government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The other three villages (Ridgefield Park (now with a Walsh Act form), Ridgewood (now with a Faulkner Act Council-Manager charter) and South Orange (now with a Special Charter) all migrated to other forms of non-village.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Socially, New Jersey is considered one of the country's most liberal states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Polls indicate that 60% of the population is self-described as pro-choice, although a majority opposes the end of the quarter and the intact expansion and extraction as well as the public funding of abortion.

name: new_jersey
sentence: On October 18, 2013, the Supreme Court of New Jersey issued a unanimous interim order (7–0) authorizing same-sex marriage in the state, pending a legal appeal from Governor Chris Christie, who then withdrew this appeal hours after the first same-sex marriages took place on October 21, 2013.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey also has some of the strictest arms control laws in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These include the prohibition of assault firearms, hollow snout bullets and sling fire.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In New Jersey, there is no firearm crime less than a crime.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Black powder and BB firearms are all treated as modern firearms.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey does not recognize arms permits outside the state and aggressively enforces its own firearms laws.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although the Democratic Party was very successful throughout the state, the state had Republican governors; from 1994 to 2002, Christine Todd Whitman won twice with 47% and 49% of the votes, respectively, and in the 2009 elections Republican Chris Christie beat outgoing Democrat Jon Corzine with 48% of the vote.

sentence: The state's democratic strongholds include Camden County, Essex County (typically the most democratic county in the state – it includes Newark, the largest city in the state), Hudson County (the second strongest democratic county, including Jersey City, the second largest city in the state); Mercer County (especially around Trenton and Princeton), Middlesex County and Union County (including Elizabeth, the fourth largest city in the state).

name: new_jersey
sentence: The suburban counties of the north-west and south-east of the state are reliable republicans: Republicans have support along the coast in Ocean County and in the mountainous north-western part of the state, especially in Morris County, Sussex County and Warren County.

sentence: On 17 December 2007, Governor Jon Corzine signed a bill that would eliminate the death penalty in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the first state to pass such a law since Iowa and West Virginia eliminated executions in 1965.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico (in Spanish: Nuevo México) is a state in the southwestern United States of America, whose capital is Santa Fe, founded in 1610 as the capital of Nuevo México (which was established as a province of New Spain in 1598), while its largest city is Albuquerque with its accompanying metropolitan area.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is one of the mountain states and shares the Four Corners region with Utah, Colorado and Arizona.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is also bordered by the state of Texas to the east-southeast, Oklahoma to the north-east, and the Mexican states of Chihuahua to the south and Sonora to the south-west.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With an estimated population of 2,096,829 as of July 1, 2019, the U.S. Census Bureau estimates that New Mexico is the 36th state by population.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With a total area of 121,590 m2 (314,900 km2), it is the fifth largest and sixth least dense of the 50 States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Because of their geographical location, northern and eastern New Mexico have a colder alpine climate, while western and southern New Mexico have a warmer and arid climate.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico's economy is dependent on oil drilling, mining, dryland agriculture, livestock rearing, acequia and land-based agriculture, milling, retailing, scientific research laboratories, technological development, and the arts, particularly textiles and visual arts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 2018, its gross domestic product (GDP) was $101 billion with a per capita GDP of $45,465.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state's fiscal policy results in low to moderate taxation of personal income in relation to most U.S. states, with particular consideration for military personnel, and grants tax credits and exemptions to favourable industries.

name: new_mexico
sentence: For this reason, its film industry has increased and contributed $1.23 billion to its global economy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to its large size and economic climate, New Mexico has a large US military presence, including the White Sands missile chain.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Various United States national security agencies base their research and testing on weapons in New Mexico, such as the national laboratories Sandia and Los Alamos.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the 1940s, Project Y of the Manhattan project developed and built the country's first atomic bomb and nuclear test, Trinity.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Habited by the Amerindians for thousands of years before European exploration, it was colonized by the Spaniards in 1598 as part of the Spanish imperial vice-royalty of New Spain.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1563 he was named Nuevo México after the Aztec valley of Mexico by Spanish settlers, more than 250 years before the establishment and designation of today's country of Mexico; thus, the present state of New Mexico was not named after the country today known as Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Following Mexican independence in 1821, New Mexico became a Mexican territory with considerable autonomy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This autonomy, however, was threatened by the centralizing tendencies of the Mexican government from the 1830s, with increasing tensions that eventually led to the revolt of 1837.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The largest Hispanic and Latinic groups represented are Hispanos of New Mexico, Chicanos and Mexicans.

sentence: The new Mexican flag presents the Spanish origins of the state with the same scarlet and golden colour as the Croix de Bourgogne d'Espagne, as well as the ancient symbol of the sun of the tribe Zia, a Puebloan tribe.

sentence: New Mexico received its name long before the present nation of Mexico gained Spain's independence and adopted that name in 1821.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Although the name "Mexico" itself derives from Nahuatl, and in this language it refers to the origin in the heart of the Mexican Empire (Aztec Empire) in the valley of Mexico far from the New Mexico region, Spanish explorers also used the term "Mexico" to name the New Mexico region (Nuevo México in Spanish) in 1563.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In 1581, the Chamuscado and Rodríguez expedition named the area north of the Rio Grande "San Felipe del Nuevo México".

name: new_mexico

sentence: The average state-wide precipitation of New Mexico is 12.9 inches (330 mm) per year, with average monthly amounts peaking in summer, as in Albuquerque, and Las Cruces in the south.

sentence: Average annual temperatures may range from 65°F (18°C) in the southeast to less than 40°F (4°C) in the northern mountains.
