sentence: Albany and the Mohawk Valley also have large communities of native Italians and Irish Americans, reflecting 19th and early 20th century immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the American Community Survey, New York also had the largest Greek American population, i.e. 148,637 people (0.7% of the state).

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo and western New York, German Americans are the largest ancestry.

name: new_york
sentence: In the northern country of New York, French Canadians represent the main ethnic group, given the proximity of the region to Quebec.

name: new_york
sentence: Americans of English ancestry are present throughout New York, reflecting the first colonial immigrants and later.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the most commonly spoken American English dialects in New York, in addition to American general English, were the dialect of the New York City area (including New York Latino English and Northern Jersey English), the accent of Western New England around Albany, and the English language of northern interior America in Buffalo and western New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: Up to 800 languages are spoken in New York City, making it the most linguistic city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 70.72% (12,788,233) of New York residents aged five and over reported speaking only English at home, while 14.44% (2,611,903) spoke Spanish, 2.61% (472,955) Chinese (which includes Cantonese and Mandarin), 1.2% (216,468) Russian, 1.18% (213,785) Italian, 0.79% (142,169) French Creole, 0.75% (135,789) French, 0.67% (121,917) Yiddish, 0.63% (114,574) Korean and Polish were spoken by 0.53% (95,413) of the population over five years of age.

name: new_york
sentence: A total of 29.28 per cent (5,295,016) of the New York population aged five and over reported speaking a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the American Community Survey for 2017, nearly six million residents spoke a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 1,249,541 New Yorkers spoke Spanish, 386,290 Chinese, 122,150 Russian, 63,615 Haitian Creoles, 62,219 Bengali and 60,405 Koreans.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2018, 12,756,975 people aged 5 years and over spoke English alone and 10,415,395 people aged 18 years and older spoke only English.

name: new_york
sentence: Most Spanish-speaking households are not English-speaking.

name: new_york
sentence: It is estimated that 2.7 million households with residents aged 5 years and over speak Spanish.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2018, Chinese, Slavic and French languages were the most important languages spoken by households.

name: new_york
sentence: The majority of New York's religious population is Christian (60%), followed by irreligious (27%), Judaism (7 %), Islam (2 %), Buddhism and Hinduism (1% each) and other religions (0.5%).

name: new_york
sentence: Before the 1800s Protestant sects dominated New York's religious life, although religion did not play as important a role in the public life of the New Netherlands as in New England, with its Puritan population.

name: new_york
sentence: Historically, New York served as the basis for new Christian confessions in the second great revival.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Western Christian traditions and non-Christian religions did not grow in much of the State's history because immigration came mainly from Western Europe (which was then dominated by Western Christianity and favoured by quotas in the Federal Immigration Act).

name: new_york
sentence: The Immigration and Nationality Act 1965 had abolished quotas, which had led to an increase in the number of other religious groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The Roman Catholic Church is the largest Christian denomination in New York City (31%).

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Catholic diocese is the archdiocese of the Latin Church of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Catholic diocese in the East is the Ruthenian Catholic Eparchy of Passaic of the Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church.

name: new_york
sentence: The United Methodist Church is the largest main Protestant denomination and the second most important on the whole, followed by the Episcopal Church in the United States and other active Anglican organizations.

name: new_york
sentence: The Presbyterian Church (USA), the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, and the American Baptist Churches were the following major denominations.

name: new_york
sentence: Together, the main Protestants account for 11% of the state's Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: In evangelical Protestantism, Baptists, non-denominational Protestants, and Pentecostalists were the largest groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Baptist Convention (USA) and the Progressive National Baptist Convention were the largest Protestant churches historically black in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: About 10 per cent of New York's Christians are evangelical Protestants.

name: new_york
sentence: Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Orthodox collectively represented 1% of the religious population alongside Jehovah's Witnesses and other Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Christian denominations account for 12% of the religious population.

name: new_york
sentence: Judaism is the second religion to date in 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 588,500 people practised Orthodox Judaism.

name: new_york
sentence: A little over 392,953 profess Islam.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the oldest Zoroastrian Fire Temple in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Less than 1% of New York's population practice New Age and contemporary paganism.

name: new_york
sentence: Amerindian religions are also a prominent minority.

name: new_york
sentence: Irreligious is a growing community in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: In the state as a whole, 17% do nothing in particular and 5% are atheists and agnostics.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 3.8 per cent of the adult population in the state is identified as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: This represents a total adult LGBT population of 570,388 people.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the number of same-sex couples was approximately 48,932.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the fifth state to allow homosexual marriages after New Hampshire.

name: new_york
sentence: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of New York City, said that "homosexual marriages in New York generated approximately $259 million in economic impact and $16 million in municipal revenue" in the first year after the adoption of the Equal Marriage Act.

name: new_york
sentence: Same-sex marriages in New York were legalized on 24 June 2011 and were allowed to commence 30 days later.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is also home to the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York Pride March (or gay pride parade) crosses 5th Avenue in Manhattan, ending at Greenwich Village, and rivals the Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of spectators on the sidewalks each June.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stonewall riots were a series of spontaneous and violent protests by members of the gay community against a police raid that took place in the early morning of June 28, 1969, at Stonewall Inn in the Greenwich Village neighbourhood of Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: They are widely regarded as the most important event leading to the gay liberation movement and the modern struggle for LGBT rights.

name: new_york
sentence: In June 2017, plans were announced for the first official LGBT monument commissioned by the State of New York, unlike the Stonewall National Monument, which was commissioned by the U.S. federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Monument should be built in Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near the Hudson River wharves, which have served as important historical symbols of New York's central role as a meeting place and refuge for LGBT communities.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, the state of New York planned to host the largest international celebration of LGBT pride in 2019, known as Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots.

name: new_york
sentence: In New York, the 2019 Stonewall 50–WorldPride NYC events produced by Heritage of Pride were enhanced through a partnership with the LGBT division of the I LOVE NY program and included a welcome centre during the weeks surrounding the Stonewall 50 / WorldPride events, which was open to all.

name: new_york
sentence: Other commemorative, cultural and educational arts programs on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the rebellion at Stonewall Inn took place throughout the city and around the world; Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019 was the largest celebration of LGBT pride in history, attracting approximately five million people.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn Liberation March, the largest event on transgender rights in LGBTQ history, took place on June 14, 2020, from Grand Army Plaza to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and focused on supporting the lives of black transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's gross public product in 2018 was $1.7 trillion.

name: new_york
sentence: If the state of New York were an independent nation, it would be ranked 11th in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: However, in 2013, the multi-state metropolitan statistical area, centred on the city of New York, produced a gross metropolitan product (GMP) of nearly $1.4 trillion, while in 2012, the corresponding combined statistical area produced a GMP of more than $1.7 trillion, both ranking first at the national level in a broad margin and behind the GDP of only nine countries.

name: new_york
sentence: Anchored by Wall Street in the Financial District of Lower Manhattan, New York City was called both the most economically powerful city and the first financial centre in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower Manhattan is the third largest business district in the United States and is home to the New York Stock Exchange at Wall Street and NASDAQ at 165 Broadway, representing respectively the largest and second largest stock exchanges in the world, as measured by both the average volume of daily transactions and the total market capitalization of their listed companies in 2013.

name: new_york
sentence: Wall Street investment bank charges amounted to approximately $40 billion in 2012, while in 2013, New York bank executives who manage risk management and compliance functions earned up to $324,000 per year.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal year 2013–14, the Wall Street securities industry generated 19% of New York State's tax revenues.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York remains the world's largest trading centre in the public capital and debt markets, partly because of the size and financial development of the American economy.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the leader in the management of hedge funds

name: new_york
sentence: Several investment banks and investment managers based in Manhattan are major participants in other global financial centres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the main commercial banking centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the largest media conglomerates in the world are also based in the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Manhattan had about 520 million square feet (48.1 million square feet) of office space in 2013, making it the largest office market in the United States, while Midtown Manhattan is the largest central business district in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: Silicon Alley, centered in New York, has become a metanym for the sphere encompassing the high-tech and entrepreneurship ecosystem of the New York metropolitan area; in 2015, Silicon Alley generated more than $7.3 billion in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: High-tech industries, including digital media, biotechnology, software development, game design and other areas of information technology, are growing, supported by New York's position at the terminus of several transatlantic fibre optic lines, its intellectual capital, and its growing external wireless connectivity.

name: new_york
sentence: In December 2014, New York State announced a $50 million venture capital fund to encourage companies working in biotechnology and advanced materials; according to Governor Andrew Cuomo, seed money would make it easier for entrepreneurs to market their research.

name: new_york
sentence: On December 19, 2011, then Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of Cornell University and Technion-Israel Institute of Technology to build a $2 billion college of applied science on Roosevelt Island in Manhattan to transform New York City into the world's first technological capital.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, Saratoga County, Rensselaer County, and the Hudson Valley, collectively recognized as the Eastern New York Technology Valley, have experienced significant growth in high-tech computer hardware, with major advances in nanotechnology, digital electronics design, and the manufacture of microchip integrated circuits dependent on water and electricity, including companies such as IBM and its Thomas J. Watson Research Centre, and the three foreign companies, GlobalFoundries, Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor.

name: new_york
sentence: The region's high-tech ecosystem is supported by technology-based academic institutions, including the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and SUNY Polytechnic Institute.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2015, Tech Valley, which straddles both sides of the Adirondack Northway and New York Thruway, generated more than $163 million in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: The Rochester region is important in the field of photographic processing and imaging as well as the incubation of an increasingly diverse high-tech sphere encompassing STEM domains, as well as the results of private start-up companies working with major academic institutions, including the University of Rochester and Cornell University.

name: new_york
sentence: Westchester County has developed a booming biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with over $1 billion in private investment expected to begin in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: Creative industries, which produce and disseminate knowledge and information, such as new media, digital media, film and television production, advertising, fashion, design and architecture, account for an increasing share of employment, with the City of New York having a significant competitive advantage in these industries.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2014, the State of New York offered tax incentives of up to $420 million a year for the production of films within the state, the most generous tax refund in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also attracted higher visual effects jobs by increasing its tax credit to a maximum of 35% for post-film production in Upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The filmed entertainment industry grew in New York, contributing nearly $9 billion to the New York City economy in 2015.

name: new_york
sentence: I Love New York is a slogan, logo and state song that form the basis of an advertising campaign and has been used since 1977 to promote tourism in New York State, including New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The trademark logo is owned by New York State Empire State Development.

name: new_york
sentence: The Broadway League reported that Broadway's programming sold approximately $1.27 billion in tickets for the 2013–14 season, an increase of 11.4% from $1.39 billion for the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: The 2013–14 participation was $12.21 million, an increase of 5.5% over the $11.57 million in the 2012–2013 season.

name: new_york
sentence: New York exports a wide variety of goods such as prepared foods, computers and electronics, cut diamonds and other products.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2007, the government exported a total of $71.1 billion in goods, with Canada ($15 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion) and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion) the five largest foreign export markets.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's largest imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds and timber.

name: new_york
sentence: The government also has an important manufacturing sector that includes clothing printing and production, primarily in New York; and furs, railway equipment, automotive parts and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate areas.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the country's third largest producer of grapes, and the second largest producer of wine by volume, behind California.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern hills of Finger Lakes, the Hudson Valley, the northern fork of Long Island and the south shore of Lake Erie are the main wine and wine regions of New York, with many vineyards.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 hectares of vines, generating full-time jobs for nearly 25,000 people and annual wages above $1.1 billion, and generating $4.8 billion in direct economic impact from grapes, grape juice, wine and grape products.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's agricultural industry is a major producer overall, ranking among the top five states for agricultural products, including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions and potatoes.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is the largest cabbage producer in the United States

name: new_york
sentence: The government owns about a quarter of its agricultural land and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001.

name: new_york
sentence: The south shore of Lake Ontario offers the right mix of soils and microclimates for many apple orchards, cherries, plums, pears and peaches.

name: new_york
sentence: Apples are also cultivated in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: A medium-sized commercial salt water fishery is located along the Atlantic side of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Major developments include clams, lobsters, squid and plaice.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, New York State consumed 156,370 gigawatt-hour (GWh) of electrical energy.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower-state areas (Hudson Valley, New York and Long Island) consumed 66% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: High-status regions accounted for 50% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The maximum load for 2017 was 29,699 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, resource capacity was 42,839 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYISO market monitor described the overall average electricity price as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh for 2017.

name: new_york
sentence: At the post-secondary level, the state-wide public university system is the State University of New York (SUNY).

name: new_york
sentence: The SUNY system consists of 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges and doctoral institutions, including several universities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's flagship university is Buffalo University, founded by US President Billard Fillmore.

name: new_york
sentence: Along with Buffalo University, Binghamton University is also one of the best public universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City has its own city-funded City University of New York (CUNY) system.

name: new_york
sentence: Columbia University, Cornell University and New York University are among the largest institutions of higher education in New York, all world-renowned private universities and members of the Association of American Universities, the first group of research universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Other notable private universities include Syracuse University and Fordham University.

name: new_york
sentence: The smallest private higher education institutions are Rockefeller University, Mercy College, New York Institute of Technology, Rensselaer Polytechnic, Yeshiva University and Hofstra University.

name: new_york
sentence: There are also a multitude of graduate schools in New York State, including schools of medicine, law and engineering.

name: new_york
sentence: West Point, the U.S. Army Service Academy, is located just south of Newburgh, on the west bank of the Hudson River.

name: new_york
sentence: The Federal Merchant Marine Academy is at Kings Point on Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: A number of selective private liberal arts institutions are located in New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: These include Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith College, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, Union College, and Vassar College.

name: new_york
sentence: Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the Seven Sisters elite, originally all women's schools linked to the Ivy League.

name: new_york
sentence: Barnard was affiliated with Columbia University, its neighbour in Manhattan, and Vassar became a co-educator in 1969 after refusing an offer to merge with Yale University.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also home to what is generally considered to be the best performing arts schools in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The Juilliard School, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is one of the world's largest schools of music and dance.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastman School of Music, a professional school at the University of Rochester, has been ranked first in American music schools by US News & World Report for five consecutive years.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State University accredits and establishes standards for primary, middle and secondary education in the State, while the New York State Department of Education supervises public schools and monitors their standard examinations.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Ministry of Education operates the New York City public school system.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination, the State passed a law enabling communities to establish separate schools for children of African-American origin.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1900 the state passed another law requiring the integration of schools.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal year 2013, New York spent more money on public education per student than any other state, according to the U.S. Census Bureau statistics.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has one of the largest and oldest transport infrastructure in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: The engineering problems posed by the complex terrain of the State and the unique infrastructure problems of the city of New York caused by the urban crowd had to be overcome on a permanent basis.

name: new_york
sentence: The expansion of the state population followed the trail of the first rivers, first the Hudson River and the Mohawk River, then the Erie Canal.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, railways were built along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Transport (NYSDOT) is the Department of the Government of New York responsible for the establishment and operation of highways, railways, public transport systems, ports, waterways and air facilities in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYSDOT has its head office at 50 Wolf Road, Colonie, Albany County.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York and New Jersey Port Authority (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the States of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the American Congress, established in 1921 through an inter-State pact, which oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports and seaports, within the geographic jurisdiction of the port of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: This 1500 km2 port area (3,900 km2) is generally covered within a 25 km (40 km) radius of the National Monument of the Statue of Freedom.

name: new_york
sentence: The Harbour Authority is headquartered at the 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition to the well-known New York Metro system, which is confined to the city of New York, four suburban rail networks enter and leave the city: the Long Island Railway, the Metro-North Railway, the Trans-Hudson of the Port Authority and five of the New Jersey Transit railway lines.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the New York City government agency responsible for the management of much of New York's transportation infrastructure.

name: new_york
sentence: The other cities in New York have urban and regional public transport.

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority manages Buffalo Metro Rail's light rail system; in Rochester, Rochester Metro operated from 1927 to 1956, but became obsolete as the government and the federal government invested in the roads.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (NYSDMV or DMV) is the government agency responsible for the registration and inspection of motor vehicles and other motor vehicles, as well as the issuance of driving licences in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2008, NYSDMV had 11,284,546 driver's licences and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force.

name: new_york
sentence: All gasoline vehicles registered in New York State must undergo an emission inspection every 12 months to ensure that environmental quality controls prevent air pollution.

name: new_york
sentence: Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross weight of more than 8,500 pounds and registered in most counties of Downstate New York are subject to annual emission inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: All vehicles registered in New York State must be subject to an annual safety inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing passengers to easily move from one mode of transport to another.

name: new_york
sentence: One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK, which allows rail passengers to travel directly to the John F. Kennedy International Airport terminals and the New York Metro.

name: new_york
sentence: The Government of New York embodies the Government structure of the State of New York as established by the Constitution of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: It consists of three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: new_york
sentence: The Governor is the Chief Executive Officer of the State and is assisted by the Lieutenant Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: Both of them are elected on the same ticket.

name: new_york
sentence: The other elected members are the Attorney General and the Comptroller.

name: new_york
sentence: The Secretary of State, former elected official, is currently appointed by the Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The Parliament of the State of New York is bicameral and consists of the Senate of the State of New York and the Assembly of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The Assembly consists of 150 members, while the Senate varies in its membership, which currently has 63 members.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislature is empowered to make laws, subject to the power of the Governor to veto a bill.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the right of veto may be exceeded by the legislator if there is a two-thirds majority in favour of winning it in each chamber.

name: new_york
sentence: Permanent laws of a general nature are codified in the consolidated laws of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest court of appeal in the unified justice system is the Court of Appeal, while the first court of first instance is the County Court (or the Supreme Court of New York).

name: new_york
sentence: The Supreme Court also acts as an intermediate court of appeal for many cases, and local courts deal with a variety of other issues, including small disputes, traffic tickets and local zoning issues, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Courts are the most important local judicial system.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is divided into counties, cities, towns and villages, all of which are municipal corporations vis-à-vis their own governments, as well as various corporations that serve for single purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts and public utility corporations in New York State, often referred to as development authorities or corporations.

name: new_york
sentence: Each municipal corporation is given different powers of home government, in accordance with the New York Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The State also has 10 Indian reserves.

name: new_york
sentence: Several movements have taken place with regard to the secession of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Proposals include a State of Long Island, composed of everything on the island outside New York; a State called Niagara, the counties of western New York State; the counties of northern New York State called Upstate New York; making New York City a State; a proposal for a new County of Peconic in eastern Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to separate from New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The death penalty was reintroduced in 1995 under Pataki's administration, but the law was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeal ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the constitution of the State.

name: new_york
sentence: The remaining death penalty was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and death row was dissolved in 2008, pursuant to an order of Governor David Paterson.

name: new_york
sentence: Since 1963, there have been no executions in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Legislative efforts to amend the law had failed and the death penalty was no longer required at the state level, although some crimes under federal jurisdiction were punishable by the federal death penalty.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is represented by Chuck Schummer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States Senator.

name: new_york
sentence: There are twenty-seven congress districts, the third largest number of congress districts in the country, equal to Florida and behind the 53 of California and 36 of Texas.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2019, 21 districts were represented by Democratic Party members, and 6 by Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Representation was reduced by 29 in 2013 due to the slowdown in the overall population growth of the state compared to the overall national population growth.

name: new_york
sentence: New York counted 29 votes in the national presidential elections, down from its 47-vote summit between 1933 and 1953.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a significant imbalance in payments with the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the New York State Comptroller's Office, New York received 91 cents of services for every dollar it sent to the United States federal government in fiscal year 2013; New York ranked 46th in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.

name: new_york
sentence: In April 2016, the Democrats represented a plurality of voters in New York State, representing more than twice as many registered voters as any other political party.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the second half of the 20th century, New York has generally supported Democratic Party candidates in national elections.

name: new_york
sentence: Barack Obama, a democratic presidential candidate, won New York State by more than 25 percentage points in 2012 and 2008.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York, along with the other major cities of the state, including Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, are important democratic strongholds, with liberal politics.

name: new_york
sentence: However, rural areas in New York State are generally more conservative than cities and tend to favour Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Largely populated suburban areas, such as Westchester County and Long Island, have crossed the main parties since the 1980s, but most often they support the Democrats.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the largest source of political financing in the United States for both major parties.

name: new_york
sentence: Four of the country's top five postal codes for political contributions are in Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The Upper East Side postal code 10021 generated the most money for George W. Bush and Al Gore's 2000 presidential campaigns.

name: new_york
sentence: New York State has the distinction of being the State of origin of the two major parties running for three presidential elections.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1904 presidential election saw the former governor of New York and outgoing president Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, Chief Justice of the New York Court of Appeal.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1944 presidential election had Franklin D. Roosevelt, following the footsteps of his cousin Theodore as former governor of New York and outgoing president running for re-election against the current governor of New York, Thomas E. Dewey.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 2016 presidential election, the former U.S. Senator of New York Hillary Clinton, a resident of Chappaqua, was the Democratic Party candidate.

name: new_york

sentence: The White Conservative Democrats regained control of the state legislature in 1870, partly through the violence of Ku Klux Klan and terrorism in the ballot box, to suppress the black vote.

sentence: The Republicans were elected as governor until 1876, when the Red Shirts, a paramilitary organization born in 1874 and allied with the Democratic Party, helped suppress the black vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Democrats were elected to the legislature and to the post of governor, but the populists attracted displeasing voters with them.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1896, a populist-republican fusionist coalition, biracial, acquired the position of governor and passed laws that would extend the right to vote to blacks and poor whites.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The democrats regained control of the legislature in 1896 and passed laws imposing Jim Crow and racial segregation of public facilities.

sentence: Voters in the 2nd district of the North Carolina Congress elected a total of four African-American MPs in the late 19th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Political tensions were so strong that a small group of white democrats in 1898 planned to take power over the Wilmington government if their candidates were not elected.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Wilmington insurrection in 1898, more than 1,500 white men attacked the black newspaper and the neighborhood, killed many men, and fled the mayor and the white Republicans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They set up their own people and elected Alfred M. Waddell mayor, in the only coup d'état in the history of the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1899, the State Legislative Assembly adopted a new constitution, with requirements for voting taxes and literacy tests for the registration of voters who deprived most black Americans of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Exclusion from voting has a broad effect: it means that black Americans cannot serve in any jury or local office.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After a decade of white supremacy, many people have forgotten that North Carolina has never had any prosperous middle-class black Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Black citizens have no political voice in the State until after the adoption of the Federal Civil Rights Act 1964 and the Voting Rights Act 1965 to enforce their constitutional rights.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It was not until 1992 that another African-American was elected American representative of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the reconstruction period, North Carolina had become a unipartite state, dominated by the Democratic Party.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state has mainly pursued an economy based on tobacco, cotton textiles and commodity agriculture.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Large cities remained in small numbers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, an important industrial base appeared in the late 19th and early 20th centuries in the counties of the Piedmont Triad, based on cotton mills established at the autumn line.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Railways have been built to connect new industrialization cities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state was the place where the Wright brothers, near Kitty Hawk, on December 17, 1903, allowed the first flight heavier than air, controlled, motorized and successfully sustained.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the first half of the 20th century, many African-Americans left the state to go north for better opportunities in the Great Migration.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Their departure changed the demographic characteristics of several regions.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was hit hard by the Great Depression, but Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal program for cotton and tobacco helped farmers a lot.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the Second World War, the state economy grew rapidly, marked by the growth of cities such as Charlotte, Raleigh and Durham in the Piedmont region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill form the Triangle of Research, a major field of universities and advanced scientific and technical research.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the late 1960s, driven in part by the increasingly left-wing inclination of national democrats, the conservative whites began to vote for national Republican candidates and gradually for more republicans locally.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Greensboro Sit-ins played a crucial role in the Civil Rights Movement to bring full equality to Black Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since the 1970s, North Carolina has experienced a steady increase in population growth.

sentence: This growth occurred mainly in metropolitan areas within the Piedmont Crescent, such as Charlotte, Raleigh, Greensboro, Winston-Salem and Durham.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte Metro has experienced strong growth, mainly due to its financial, banking and technology industries.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The State of North Carolina, Duke University and the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, helped the Raleigh region (Research Triangle) attract an educated workforce and create more jobs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte became an important regional and national banking centre in the 1990s.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tourism has also been a boom for the North Carolina economy, as people flock to the coastal areas of the outer shores and the Appalachian mountains anchored by Asheville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is bordered to the south by South Carolina, Georgia to the southwest, Tennessee to the west, Virginia to the north and the Atlantic Ocean to the east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau places North Carolina in the South Atlantic division of the southern region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina consists of three major geographic regions: the Atlantic coastal plain, which occupies the eastern part of the state; the central Piedmont region; and the western mountainous region, which is part of the Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain consists of more specifically defined areas such as the outer shores, a chain of sandy and narrow islands separated from the continent by sounds or inlets, including the Albemarle Strait and Pamlico Strait, the tidal waters region, the home of the venous flyer, and the inland coastal plain, where long-leaved pines are native.

name: north_carolina
sentence: So many ships have been lost off Cape Hatteras that the area is known as the "Graveyard of the Atlantic"; more than a thousand ships have sunk in these waters since the records began in 1526.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The most famous of them is the Vengeance of Queen Anne (flagship of the Black Barbe pirate), which ran aground at Beaufort Inlet in 1718.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain passes to the Piedmont region along the Atlantic Seaboard fall line, the altitude at which the waterfalls appear for the first time on rivers and streams.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont region of central North Carolina is the most populated region of the state, with the six largest cities in the state per population.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It consists of a gently sloping country often broken by hills or low mountain ridges.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Small, isolated and deeply eroded mountain ranges are located in Piedmont, including the Sauratown Mountains, Pilot Mountain, Uwharrie Mountains, Crowder's Mountain, King's Pinnacle, Brossy Mountains and the South Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Piedmont ranges from about 91 metres to the east to about 1,500 feet (460 metres) to the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western part of the State is part of the range of the Appalachian Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Among the sub-areas of the Appalachians in the state are the Smoky Mountains, Blue Ridge Mountains and the Black Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Black Mountains are the highest in the eastern United States and peak at Mount Mitchell at 2684 feet (2,037 m), the highest point east of Mississippi.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has 17 large watersheds.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The five basins west of the Blue Ridge Mountains flow to the Gulf of Mexico, while the rest flow to the Atlantic Ocean.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Of the 17 basins, 11 are from the state of North Carolina, but only four are located entirely within the state border: Cap Peur, the Neuse, the White Oak and the Tar-Pamlico basin.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elevation above sea level is the main cause of temperature change throughout the state, the mountainous area being the coldest all year round.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The climate is also influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf Stream, especially in the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These influences tend to cause warmer winter temperatures along the coast, where temperatures fall only occasionally under freezing at night.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain represents an average of about 2.5 cm of snow or ice per year, and there may be no snow or ice in many years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Ocean has less influence on the climate of the Piedmont region, which has warmer summers and cooler winters than along the coast, although the average daily maximum is still less than 90°F (32°C) in most localities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina experiences severe weather in both summer and winter, with summer threatening hurricanes, tropical storms, heavy rains and floods.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The destructive hurricanes that struck North Carolina included Hurricane Fran, Hurricane Florence, Hurricane Floyd, Hurricane Hugo and Hurricane Hazel, which was the strongest storm ever struck in the state, as a category 4 in 1954.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hurricane Isabel is the most destructive of the twenty-first century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has an average of less than 20 tornadoes per year, many of which are produced by hurricanes or tropical storms along the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Storm tornadoes pose a risk, especially in the eastern part of the State.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western Piedmont is often protected by mountains, which tend to break storms as they attempt to cross; storms will often reshape in the east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A phenomenon known as a "cold-air dam" often occurs in the northwestern part of the state, which may weaken storms, but may also lead to significant ice events in the winter.

sentence: Thirty confirmed tornadoes fell, mainly in the eastern Piedmont and the Sandhills, killing at least 24 people.

sentence: Since colonial times, the residents of North Carolina have always been very Protestant – first Anglicans, then Baptists and Methodists.

sentence: University sports are also popular in North Carolina, with 18 schools competing in Division I.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) is headquartered in Greensboro, and the CCA Football Championship (Charlotte) and the CCA Men's Basketball Tournament (Greensboro) have been held most recently in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In addition, Charlotte is home to the National Junior College Athletics Association (NJCAA) head office.

name: north_carolina
sentence: College basketball is very popular in North Carolina, driven by the rivalries of Tobacco Road between CCA members in North Carolina, Duke, North Carolina State and Wake Forest.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The CCA Championship Game and the Duke's Mayo Bowl are held each year at Charlotte's Bank of America Stadium, featuring teams from the CCA and the Southeast Conference.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In addition, the state hosted the NCAA Men's Basketball Final Four on two occasions, in Greensboro in 1974 and Charlotte in 1994.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte is the city most visited in the state, attracting 28.3 million visitors in 2018.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Regional attractions include the Carolina Panthers NFL football team and Charlotte Hornets, Carowinds amusement park, Charlotte Motor Speedway, US National Whitewater Center, Discovery Place, Great Wolf Lodge, Sea Life Aquarium, Bechtler Museum of Modern Art, Billy Graham Library, Carolinas Aviation Museum, Harvey B. Gantt Center for African-American Arts + Culture, Levine Museum of the New South, McColl Center for Art + Innovation, Mint Museum and NASCAR Hall of Fame.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Each year, Appalachians attract several million tourists to the western part of the state, including the historic Biltmore estate.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The picturesque Blue Ridge Drive and Great Smoky Mountains National Park are the two most visited parks and units in the United States with over 25 million visitors in 2013.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The city of Asheville is constantly chosen as one of the best places to visit and live in the United States, known for its rich art deco architecture, mountain landscapes and outdoor activities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In Raleigh, many tourists visit the capital, the African-American cultural complex, the Raleigh Museum of Contemporary Art, Gregg Museum of Art & Design at NCSU, Haywood Hall House & Gardens, Marble Kids Museum, North Carolina Museum of Art, North Carolina Museum of History, North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, North Carolina Sports Hall of Fame, Raleigh City Museum, J.C. Raulston Arboretum, Joel Lane House, Mordecai House, Montfort Hall and the Pope House Museum.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The NHL hockey team Carolina Hurricanes is also located in the city.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Conover–Hickory area, Hickory Motor Speedway, RockBarn Golf and Spa, home of the Great Hickory Classic at Rock Barn; Catawba County Firefighters Museum and SALT Block attract many tourists to Conover.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hickory owns the Valley Hills Mall mall.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont Triad, or central state, is home to Krispy Kreme, Mayberry, Texas Pete, Lexington Barbecue Festival and Moravian cookies.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The internationally recognized North Carolina Zoo in Asheboro attracts visitors to its animals, plants and a 57-piece art collection along five miles of shaded trails in the world's largest natural habitat park.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Seagrove, in the central part of the State, attracts many tourists along the Pottery Road (NC Hwy 705).

name: north_carolina
sentence: MerleFest in Wilkesboro attracts more than 80,000 people to its four-day music festival; and Wet 'n Wild Emeralde Pointe water park in Greensboro is another attraction.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The outer shores and surrounding beaches attract millions of people each year to the Atlantic beaches.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The mainland of the northeastern part of the state, having recently adopted the name of inner banks, is also known as the Albemarle region, for the colonies of the Albemarle, some of the first colonies in the part of the Atlantic Coastal Plain in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The historical sites of the regions are connected by the historical tower of the Albemarle.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina offers a wide range of recreational activities, from swimming to beach to skiing in the mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina offers autumn colours, freshwater and saltwater fishing, hunting, bird watching, agritourism, mountain biking trails, bloating, climbing, cycling, hiking, skiing, navigation and sailing, camping, canoeing, gardens and arboretum.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has theme parks, aquariums, museums, historic sites, lighthouses, stylish theatres, concert halls and refined restaurants.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Northern Carolinians enjoy outdoor recreation using many local bike paths, 34 state parks and 14 national parks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National Park Service units include the Appalachian National Scenic Trail, Blue Ridge Drive, Cape Hatteras National Marine Shore, Cape Lookout National Marine Shore, Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site in Flat Rock, Fort Raleigh National Historic Site in Manteo, Smoky Great Mountains National Park, Guilford Courthouse National Military Park in Greensboro, Moores Creek National Battlefield near Currie in Pender County, Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail, Old Salem National Historic Site in Winston-Salem, Tears National Historic Trail and Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kill Devil Hills.

name: north_carolina
sentence: National forests include the Uwharrie National Forest in central North Carolina, the Croatian National Forest in eastern North Carolina, the Pisgah National Forest in the western mountains and the Nantahala National Forest in the southwestern part of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has artistic, musical, and culinary traditions.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The non-profit arts and culture industry generates $1.2 billion in direct economic activity in North Carolina, supporting more than 43,600 full-time equivalent jobs and generating $119 million in revenues for local governments and the state of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina created the North Carolina Museum of Art as the first large museum collection in the country to be formed by state legislation and funding and continues to bring millions to the NC economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: See also the list of museums in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the most famous artistic communities in the state is Seagrove, the capital of the artisan pottery of the United States, where artisans create artisan pottery inspired by the same traditions that began in this community more than two hundred years ago.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has a large number of outstanding jazz musicians, some of whom are among the most important in the history of the genre.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These include John Coltrane (Hamlet, High Point); Thelonious Monk (Rocky Mount); Billy Taylor (Greenville); Woody Shaw (Laurinburg); Lou Donaldson (Durham); Max Roach (Newland); Tal Farlow (Greensboro); Albert, Jimmy and Percy Heath (Wilmington); Nina Simone (Tryon); and Billy Strayhorn (Hillsborough).

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is also famous for its ancient music tradition, and many recordings were made in the early 20th century by folk song collector Bascom Lamar Lunsford.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Musicians like North Carolina Ramblers helped solidify the sound of country music in the late 1920s, while the influential bluegrass musician Doc Watson is also native to North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina and South Carolina are warm beds for traditional rural blues, especially the style known as Piedmont blues.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Ben Folds Five was born in Winston-Salem, and Ben Folds still records and resides in Chapel Hill.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The British group Pink Floyd is named, in part, in honor of Chapel Hill bluesman Floyd Council.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Triangle de recherche region has long been a centre known for folk, rock, metal, jazz and punk.

name: north_carolina
sentence: James Taylor grew up around Chapel Hill, and his 1968 song "Carolina in My Mind" was described as an unofficial anthem for the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other famous musicians from North Carolina include J. Cole, Shirley Caesar, Roberta Flack, Clyde McPhatter, Nennena Freelon, Warren Haynes, Jimmy Herring, Michael Houser, Eric Church, Future Islands, Randy Travis, Ryan Adams, Ronnie Milsap, Anthony Hamilton, The Avett Brothers and Luke Combs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Metal and punk such as Corrosion of Conformity, Between the Buried and Me, and Nightmare Sonata are from North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Producer EDM Porter Robinson is from Chapel Hill.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Clay Aiken (season 2), Fantasia Barrino (season 3), Chris Daugherty (season 5), Kellie Pickler (season 5), Bucky Covington (season 5), Anoop Desai (season 8), Scotty McCreery (season 10) and Caleb Johnson (season 13).

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina also has the largest American idol winners with Barrino, McCreery and Johnson.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the mountains, the Brevard Music Center hosts choral, operatic, orchestral and solo performances during its annual summer programme.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has five professional opera companies: Opera Carolina in Charlotte, NC Opera in Raleigh, Greensboro Opera in Greensboro, Piedmont Opera in Winston-Salem, and Asheville Lyric Opera in Asheville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Academic conservatories and universities also produce fully staged operas, such as the A. J. Fletcher Opera Institute of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, the Department of Music of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill and the UNC Greensboro.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are three high-level symphony orchestras: NC Symphony at Raleigh, Charlotte Symphony and Winston-Salem Symphony.

name: north_carolina
sentence: NC Symphony holds the Master Choir of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Carolina Ballet has its seat in Raleigh and there is also the Charlotte Ballet.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The State has three performing arts centres: DPAC in Durham, Duke Energy Center for the Performing Arts in Raleigh, and Blumenthal Arts Centers in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They feature Broadway concerts, operas, recitals and travelling musicals.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Equine artists DaBaby and J. Cole come from North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: See also North Carolina Music Hall of Fame.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has a variety of business choices.

name: north_carolina
sentence: SouthPark Mall in Charlotte is currently the largest of the Carolinas, with almost two million square feet.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other major shopping malls in Charlotte include Northlake Mall and Carolina Place Mall in the neighboring suburbs of Pineville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Other major government shopping centres include Hanes Mall in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, The Thruway Center in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, Crabtree Valley Mall, North Hills Mall and Triangle Town Center in Raleigh; Friendly Center and Four Seasons Town Centre in Greensboro; Oak Hollow Mall in High Point; Concord Mills in Concord; Valley Hills Mall in Hickory; Cross Creek Mall in Fayetteville; and The Streets in Southpoint and Northgate Mall in Durham and Independance Mall in Wilmington, North Carolina; and Tangier Outlets in Charlotte, Nags Head, Blowing Rock and Mebane, North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A North Carolina basic food is pork barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are strong regional differences and rivalries over the sauces and methods used to barbecue.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The common trend in western North Carolina is the use of high quality Boston ass.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina pork barbecue uses tomato-based sauce, and only pork shoulder (black meat) is used.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western North Carolina barbecue is commonly referred to as Lexington BBQ after the town of La Triade du Piedmont de Lexington, home to the Lexington Barbecue Festival, which attracts more than 100,000 visitors each month in October.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Eastern North Carolina pork barbecue uses vinegar and red pepper sauce and the "whole pork" is cooked, integrating both white and black meat.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Krispy Kreme, an international donut shop chain, was founded in North Carolina; the company's head office is in Winston-Salem.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Pepsi-Cola was first produced in New Bern in 1898.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A regional soda, Cheerwine, has been created and is still based in the city of Salisbury.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Despite its name, the Texas Pete hot sauce was created in North Carolina, its seat is also in Winston-Salem.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hardee's fast food chain was launched in Rocky Mount.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Another fast food chain, Bojangles, was launched in Charlotte and has its headquarters.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A popular North Carolina restaurant chain is Golden Corral.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Launched in 1973, the chain was founded in Fayetteville, whose headquarters are located in Raleigh.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The famous Mount Olive Pickle Company pickle brand was founded at Mount Olive in 1926.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Quick chain of casual burgers Hwy 55 Burgers, Shakes & Fries also makes its home in Mount Olive.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Cook Out, a popular fast food chain with burgers, hot dogs and milkshakes in a wide variety of flavors, was founded in Greensboro in 1989 and began to grow outside North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, Southern Living named Durham–Chapel Hill the "most expensive city" of the South.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Over the past decade, North Carolina has become a cultural epicentre and a haven for internationally award-winning wines (Noni Bacca Winery), internationally-recognized cheeses (Ashe County), "International Institute for Gastronomic Arts: Conquer Yanks the Truffles, January 15, 2010" international hub for truffles (Garland Truffles) and beer manufacturing, since tobacco lands have been converted into grape orchards, while state laws regulating volume alcohol (ABV) in beer have allowed a jump of six to fifteen percent.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Yadkin Valley in particular has become a market to strengthen grape production, while Asheville recently won the recognition of being named "Beer City USA".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Asheville has the highest number of breweries per capita in a city in the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Recognized and marketed brands of beer in North Carolina include Highland Brewing, Duck Rabbit Brewery, Mother Earth Brewery, Weeping Radish Brewery, Big Boss Brewing, Foothills Brewing, Carolina Brewing Company, Lonerider Brewing and White Rabbit Brewing Company.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has large grazing areas for beef and dairy cattle.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The truck farms can be found in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A trucking farm is a small farm where fruits and vegetables are grown for sale on local markets.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state's shipping, commercial fishing and timber industries are important to its economy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Services industries, including education, health care, private research and retail, are also important.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Research Triangle Park, an extensive industrial complex located in the Raleigh-Durham region, is one of the country's leading centres for electronics and medical research.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tobacco was one of the first major industries to develop after the civil war.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Many farmers were cultivating tobacco, and the invention of cigarettes made the product particularly popular.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Winston-Salem is the birthplace of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company (RJR), founded by R. J. Reynolds in 1874 as one of sixteen tobacco companies in the city.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1914, it sold 425 million camel packages per year.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Today it is the second largest tobacco company in the United States (behind the Altria Group).

name: north_carolina
sentence: RJR is an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Reynolds American Inc., which in turn is 42% owned by British American Tobacco.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Several ships have been named after the state, the most famous of the United States North Carolina in the Pacific Ocean theatre of the Second World War.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Now disused, she is part of the USNorth Carolina Battleship Memorial in Wilmington.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Another nuclear attack submarine, USNorth Carolina, was commissioned in Wilmington on May 3, 2008.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The State maintains a group of protected areas, the North Carolina State Park System, which is managed by the North Carolina Division of Parks & Recreation (NCDPR), an organization of the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NCDENR).

name: north_carolina
sentence: Fort Bragg, near Fayetteville and Southern Pines, is a large, comprehensive military base and headquarters of the 18th Airborne Corps, the 82nd Airborne Division and the Special Operations Command of the United States Army.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The air wing of Fort Bragg is Pope Field, also near Fayetteville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Jacksonville, Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune, combined with nearby bases Marine Corps Air Station (MCAS) Cherry Point, MCAS New River, Camp Geiger, Camp Johnson, Stone Bay and Courthouse Bay, is the world's largest concentration of Marines and sailors.

name: north_carolina
sentence: MCAS Cherry Point is the headquarters of 2 Maritime Aircraft Wing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Located in Goldsboro, the Seymour Johnson Air Force Base is home to 4 Wing Fighters and 916 Wing Air Refuelling.

name: north_carolina
sentence: One of the U.S. Coast Guard's busiest air stations is located at the Elizabeth City Coast Guard Air Station.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Sunny Point Military Ocean Terminal in Southport is also stationed in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On January 24, 1961, a B-52G broke out in the open air and crashed after suffering a severe loss of fuel near Goldsboro, launching two nuclear bombs without detonation.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2013, it was revealed that three security mechanisms on a bomb had failed, leaving a single low-voltage switch preventing detonation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a state in the Midwestern United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is named after the indigenous tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which make up a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in the region, the fourth least populated, and the fourth least populated in the 50 states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck, and the biggest city is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on 2 November 1889, together with its neighbouring state, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th states admitted to the Union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison changed the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For convenience, both States are officially numbered in alphabetical order.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, the natural resources of North Dakota played a major role in its economic performance, particularly with the extraction of oil from the Bakken Formation, which is located under the north-western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This has led to population growth and a reduction in unemployment, which has led North Dakota to the second lowest unemployment rate in the nation (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the highest man-made structure in the western hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the Upper Midwest of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It lies in the centre of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic center of North America is close to the city of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota, and Fargo is the largest city.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The soil is the most valuable resource in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It forms the basis of the State's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has enormous mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tons of coal with lignite.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large oil reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered in the state in 1951 and quickly became one of the most precious mineral resources in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing technologies enabled mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the formation of Bakken shale rocks in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota economy relies more on agriculture than on the economies of most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota plants process agricultural products or produce agricultural equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many state merchants are also dependent on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover almost all North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They stretch from the flat valley of the Red River to the east, through the hilly plains, to the rugged Badlands to the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main crop, wheat, is grown in almost every county.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 per cent of the country's canola and flax.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the largest domestic producer of barley and sunflower seeds and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers arrived in the North Dakota region before the 1870s because the railways had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 1870s, the North Pacific Railway began to cross the Dakota territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale agriculture also began during the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern businesses and some families have established huge wheat farms covering large tracts of land in the Red River Valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made huge profits which they were called Bonanza Farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of Bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1870, North Dakota had 2,405 people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1890 the population was 190,983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was named in honour of the Sioux people who once lived in the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux were themselves called Dakota or Lakota, which means allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of the nicknames of North Dakota is Peace Garden.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname pays tribute to the International Garden of Peace, located on the state border with Manitoba, in Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also known as the state of Flickr because of the numerous land squirrels (Richardson ground squirrels) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is found in the U.S. region known as Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Northern Red River with Minnesota to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is to the south, Montana to the west and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located near the middle of North America, with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota, which marks the "Geographic Centre of the North American Continent."

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2), including 178,712 square kilometres, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the great hilly plains as well as the northern part of the Badlands, which are to the west of Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The highest point of the state, White Butte 1506 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is abundant in fossil fuels, including natural gas, crude oil, and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Sakakawea Lake, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the garrison dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central area of the state is divided into the Drift Prairie and the Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat valley of the Red River, the bottom of glacial lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the Red River that winds north towards Lake Winnipeg, supports a large agricultural industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Devils Lake, the largest natural lake in the state, is also located in the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most of the state is covered by meadows.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees are generally found in North Dakota where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil Lake, in the McHenry County Dunes area in central North Dakota, and along the slopes of the Sheyenne Valley and Sheyenne Delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This diversified land supports nearly 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a continental climate characterized by hot summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Temperature differences are significant due to its remote interior position and being in the centre of the Northern Hemisphere, with approximately equal distances to the North Pole and equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Aboriginal peoples have lived in what is today North Dakota for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (around the eleventh century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They gathered in villages on the tributaries of the Missouri River in what was to become the western centre of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians travelled to the western plains to visit and trade with related Hidatas after the split between them, probably in the 17th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came the divisions of the Dakota people – Lakota, Santee, and Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crees of Assiniboine and Plains undertook trips southward to the Indians of the village, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current Wyoming and Montana Shoshone Indians may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as the Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of earth houses on the lower Sheyenne River (site of Biesterfeldt) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As a result of the attacks by the Cree, Assiniboine and Chippewas armed with firearms, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Indians of Sotaio lived east of the Missouri River and met the uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They quickly followed the Cheyennes across Missouri and lived among them south of Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Finally, the Cheyennes and the Sutaio became a tribe and became hunters of bison mounted with ranges primarily outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the mid-19th century, Arikara entered the future southern state and joined Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over time, several Indians entered into treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many of the treaties defined the territory of a particular tribe (see map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to reach the region was French-Canadian merchant Pierre Gaultier, Sieur de La Vérendrye, who led an exploration and trading team in the villages of Mandan in 1738.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, the area was part of the Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Europeans did not settle in the Dakota territory until the end of the 19th century, when railways opened the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of land allocation, they vigorously traded their properties, exalting the region as the ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On February 22, 1889, during the administration of President Grover Cleveland, Congress passed an omnibus bill to establish a state for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington, entitled the enabling act of 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations for the official admission of North Dakota and South Dakota into the Union on November 2, 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new states presented a dilemma that had to be admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison ordered Secretary of State James G. Blaine to mix the papers and hide them from him that he signed first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The real order was not recorded, so no one knows which Dakotas were admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, given that North Dakota appears alphabetically before South Dakota, its proclamation was first published in the At Large Statutes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The carelessness among wheat producers, particularly among Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the non-partisan League ("NPL") around the First World War.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The NPL ran candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged into the Democratic Party after World War II).

name: north_dakota
sentence: It attempted to isolate North Dakota from the power of banks and out-of-state companies.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both still exist), NPL has established a public railway line (later sold to Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-corporation laws virtually prohibited a company or bank from owning title to land in the form of agricultural land.

name: north_dakota
