name: north_dakota
sentence: Like the U.S. federal government, the political power of the state government of North Dakota is divided into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of North Dakota and the North Dakota Century Code form the formal law of the State

name: north_dakota
sentence: The executive branch is headed by the elected Governor.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current governor is Doug Burgum, a Republican who took office on 15 December 2016, after his predecessor, Jack Dalrymple, did not apply for re-election.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The present Lieutenant Governor of North Dakota is Brent Sanford, who is also the Speaker of the Senate.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The positions of Governor and Lieutenant Governor have four-year terms, which are then in preparation for elections in 2024.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Governor has a cabinet composed of appointed leaders from various government agencies, known as Commissioners.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other elected constitutional offices are the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the Auditor of State and the Treasurer of State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Legislative Assembly is a bicameral body composed of the senator and the House of Representatives.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state has 47 districts, each consisting of one senator and two representatives.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both senators and representatives are elected for a term of four years.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State's legal code is called the North Dakota Century Code.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The justice system of North Dakota is four levels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Municipal courts are at the service of cities, and most cases begin with district courts, which are courts of general jurisdiction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are 42 District Court judges in seven judicial districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Appeals from the courts of first instance and challenges to certain government decisions are heard by the North Dakota Court of Appeal, which consists of three judges.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Supreme Court, consisting of five judges, hears all appeals from the District Courts and the Court of Appeal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Historically, North Dakota was populated by the Mandan, Hidatsa, Lakota and Ojibwe, followed by the Sanish and Métis.

sentence: The income tax structure of North Dakota is slightly progressive; the five tranches of the government's income tax rates are 1.1%, 2.04%, 2.27%, 2.64% and 2.90% in 2017.

sentence: In North Dakota, the sales tax is 5% for most items.

sentence: The state allows municipalities to introduce local sales taxes and special local taxes, such as the additional sales tax of 1.75% in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crown imposes a user tax on items purchased elsewhere but used in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Property owners in North Dakota pay property taxes to their county, municipality, school district and special tax district.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Tax Foundation classifies North Dakota as the state with the 20th most favourable tax climate for business in the nation.

name: north_dakota

sentence: Of the 762,062 inhabitants of North Dakota, 56.54% live in one of the 15 most populated cities.

sentence: "The Flickr State" is one of the nicknames of North Dakota and is derived from the land squirrel of Richardson (Spermophilus richardson ii), a very common animal in the area.

sentence: The earth squirrel constantly travels its tail in a distinctive manner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1953, the law to make the land squirrel the emblem of the state was passed by the State legislator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State has 10 daily newspapers, the largest of which is the Fargo-Moorhead Forum.

sentence: The most important is the alternate weekly High Plains Reader.

sentence: The state's oldest radio station, WDAY-AM, was launched on 23 May 1922.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The three main radio markets in North Dakota are located around Fargo, Bismarck and Grand Forks, although the stations are broadcast in all regions of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has 34 AM and 88 FM radio stations.

sentence: KFGO in Fargo has the largest audience.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Television broadcasting in North Dakota began on April 3, 1953, when KCJB-TV (now KXMC-TV) began operations in Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's television media markets are Fargo-Grand Forks (117th largest in the country), including half of the eastern state, and Minot-Bismarck (152nd) which form the western half of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are currently 31 full-power television channels, distributed in 10 networks, with 17 digital sub-channels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public broadcasting in North Dakota is carried out by Prairie Public, with national television and radio networks affiliated with PBS and NPR.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public access television stations open to community programming are available on cable networks in Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo and Jamestown.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is a state in the eastern central United States of America.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th largest by region, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, is the seventh most populated and the tenth most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital of the state and the largest city is Columbus, with the metropolitan area of Columbus, Grand Cincinnati and Grand Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie in the north, Pennsylvania in the east, West Virginia in the southeast, Kentucky in the southwest, Indiana in the west and Michigan in the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeyes, and Ohions are also known as "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', meaning "good river," "great river," or "great river."

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were disputed from colonial times to the Indian wars of the northwest of the late eighteenth century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the resulting Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803 and the first under the Northwest Order.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power stations in the 20th century; although it has evolved to a more information- and service-oriented economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio consists of the executive branch, headed by the Governor, the legislative branch, consisting of the Bicameral General Assembly of Ohio, and the judiciary, headed by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio holds 16 seats in the House of Representatives of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as an oscillating state and as a gazebo during national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents from the United States came from Ohio, the most from any state; this led to receiving the moniker "Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's geographic location has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: Because Ohio connects the northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic pass through its borders along its well-developed roads.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive from 50 per cent of North America's population and 70 per cent of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing for many cargo ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio border is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and most of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania to the east, Michigan to the northwest, Lake Erie to the north, Indiana to the west, Kentucky to the south and West Virginia to the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's boundaries were defined in the enabling legislation of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but most of the river is owned by Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, according to the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and consequently West Virginia) was the north low water mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio only has this part of the river between the low-sea mark of 1792 and the current high-sea mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The border with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to a slightly northeasterly angle towards the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glacial till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as the Great Black Marsh.

name: ohio
sentence: This glaciated region in the northwest and central state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glaciated Allegheny plateau, then by another belt known as the unglaciated Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low relief, but the unglazed Allegheny Plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends in an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River from the Panhandle of West Virginia to the periphery of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, coal mining in that area, dependence on small pockets of former manufacturing establishments, and the distinctive regional dialect put this section out of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, an attempt to "address the persistent poverty and growing economic desperation of the Appalachian region".

name: ohio
sentence: This Act defines the 29 counties in Ohio as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While 1/3 of Ohio's land mass is in the Appalachian region defined by the federal government, only 12.8% of Ohio's population live there (1.476 million).

name: ohio
sentence: The main rivers of the state are the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: Rivers in the northern part of the state flow into the northern Atlantic Ocean via Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River, and rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Gulf of Mexico via Ohio and then Mississippi.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Dayton Great Flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including the downtown Dayton business district.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was established as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Grand Lac St. Marys, in the western central part of the state, was built to provide water to canals at the time of canal construction from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this stretch of water, over 52 km2, has been the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio canal projects are not the economic fiasco that similar efforts have been made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and by the end of 1910, inland canals carried much of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) throughout the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Bluegrass region of Ohio, which are located on the northern periphery of the subtropical humid climate (Cfa) and the Upland South region of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid throughout the state, while winters usually range from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: In Ohio, rainfall is moderate all year round.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the Tornado Ally.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snow storms are not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area known as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although mostly not in a subtropical climate, warmer flora and fauna-climates reach Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees with more southern ranges, such as Blackjack Oak, Quercus marilandica, are in northern Ohio just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also referring to this climate transition from subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle, and even occasionally Needle Palm are rustic landscaping materials regularly used as street, yard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed during a trip across Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this various state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to the floods that caused severe road damage, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 counties in Ohio in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113 °F (45 °C), near Gallipolis on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39 °F (−39 °C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899 during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few people have registered as being visible to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or more have taken place in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and there are numerous faults below the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The largest known earthquake in Ohio's history was the earthquake in Anna (Shelby County) on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centered in western Ohio, with a magnitude of 5.4, and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; the other of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township in Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, about 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northwest of Eastlake, under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic center of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other Ohio cities are economic and cultural centres in metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield and Youngstown are in the northeast, known for the major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timken, the top-ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions including the Cleveland Art Museum, Big Five Group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the major cities in Northwestern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwestern Ohio is known for its glass manufacturing industry and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, home to Dayton University, Dayton Ballet and the vast Wright-Patterson Air Base.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors southwestern Ohio and forms the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, as well as various Fortune 500 companies including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc. and the Fifth Third Bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan city in Ohio Appalachian, home to Hocking Hills State Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends as far as Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends as far as West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends as far as Michigan and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends as far as Pennsylvania.

name: ohio
sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: These early nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1,000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1,000 and 800 B.C., Adena's sedentary culture appeared.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn"; with hunting and gathering, this culture supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most remarkable remnant of Adena's culture is the Grand Snake Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 B.C., Adena evolved to become the people of Hopewell who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex, large-scale and technologically sophisticated earthworks are in Marietta, Newark and Circleville today.

name: ohio
sentence: It was also a prolific commercial company with a commercial network covering one third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: The Hopewells disappeared from the Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: Mississippi culture has increased as Hopewell culture has declined.

name: ohio
sentence: Many people speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say that they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the thirteenth century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with the Mississippis: the Ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: The three cultures disappeared in the seventeenth century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origins were not known.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnes may have absorbed the people of Fort Ancient.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that Monongahela has no land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The culture of Mississippi was close and exchanged much with the people of the ancient Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Valley Indians were greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, which is based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the beaver wars in the mid-17th century, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, most importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the middle of the 17th century, which largely emptied the country of Ohio from indigenous populations in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land was gradually repopulated by the predominantly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio countries were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born from the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They were still in agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: Complemented by seasonal hunts.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger global economy brought about by European entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: Aboriginal nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was also home to Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac Rebellion School massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of the Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually redeemed and convinced to leave, or ordered to leave by law, in the early 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, the French introduced a trading post system to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: From 1754 on, France and Britain fought the war of France and India.

name: ohio
sentence: Following the Paris Treaty, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Great Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris in 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of the Ohio country.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the North-West Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not allowed in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The establishment began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of U.S. Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Purchase of Symmes") claimed the southwest section, and the Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the Connecticut Western Reserve in northeastern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: The territorial surveyors at Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area of eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally included areas previously known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, Indiana's territory was created, which reduced the territory of the Northwest to about the present size of Ohio, plus the eastern half of the lower Michigan Peninsula and the eastern tip of the upper peninsula, as well as a portion of the southeast Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Western Confederation, was forced to cede a vast territory, including much of the present Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as states when their population reaches 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and had already begun the road to the state.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, the Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would be "separated and their property would be devolved to the Moravian Brothers [...] or to a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and promoting Christianity".

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served extensively in the French and Indian wars and in the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men of the early years of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of building portable fortifications, which allowed the continental army to drive the British from Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed he made Putnam his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the North-West Order, which opened the Northwest Territory to colonization.

name: ohio
sentence: This land was used to compensate for what was due to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also at Putnam's recommendation that the land be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans on the territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They settled in Marietta, Ohio, where they built a large fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the territory of the North-West would be a free territory – no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They both came from New England, and Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally bad.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States and it was extremely important to consider it as slavery-free in the decades that followed.

name: ohio
sentence: It included what became Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had those states been slave states, and their electoral votes had been returned to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: The civil war would not have happened.

name: ohio
sentence: And, even if there had finally been a civil war, the North would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam, in Puritan tradition, has played an important role in the establishment of education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio

sentence: To prevent this from happening again, the Democrats obtained the adoption of a new constitution in 1895 that effectively deprived almost all blacks and many poor whites by new requirements in terms of voting taxes, residence and literacy tests that considerably reduced the electoral roll.

sentence: As the 21st century progressed, South Carolina attracted new businesses with a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial energy or materials for finished products, no wholesale tax and no unit tax on global profits.

sentence: South Carolina has many venues for visual and performing arts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is a U.S. state located in the Midwest of the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is named after the indigenous tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which make up a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the seventeenth largest by region, but the fifth least populated, and the fifth least populated of the 50 United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As a southern part of the former Dakota Territory, South Dakota became a state on November 2, 1889, along with North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It's the 39th or 40th state admitted to the union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison changed the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the national capital and Sioux Falls, with a population of approximately 187,200, is the largest city in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered by the states of North Dakota (north), Minnesota (east), Iowa (southeast), Nebraska (south), Wyoming (west) and Montana (northwest).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state is divided by the Missouri River, dividing South Dakota into two geographically and socially distinct halves known to residents as the "East" and "West" rivers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern South Dakota is home to most of the state's population and the fertile soil of the region is used to cultivate a variety of crops.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, the ranch is the predominant agricultural activity, and the economy is more dependent on tourism and defence spending.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Most Amerindian reserves are located in the West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills, a group of low-covered mountains of Sioux-sacred pines, are located in the southwest part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mount Rushmore, a major tourist destination, is there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a temperate continental climate, with four distinct seasons and precipitation ranging from moderate in the east to semi-arid in the west.

name: south_dakota
sentence: State ecology is characterized by species typical of a North American prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have lived in the region for several millennia, with Sioux becoming dominant in the early 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At the end of the 19th century, Euro-American colonization intensified after a gold rush in the Black Hills and the construction of Eastern Railways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Encircled miners and settlers triggered a number of Indian wars, culminating in the massacre of the injured knee in 1890.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The major events of the 20th century were the Dust Bowl and the Great Depression, the increase in federal spending in the 1940s and 1950s for agriculture and defence, and the industrialization of agriculture that reduced family farming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While several Democrats have represented South Dakota for multiple terms in both chambers of Congress, the state government is largely controlled by the Republican Party, whose candidates carried South Dakota in each of the last 13 presidential elections.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Historically dominated by an agricultural economy and a rural lifestyle, South Dakota has recently sought to diversify its economy in areas to attract and retain residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The history of South Dakota and its rural character continue to have a strong influence on the culture of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is located in the north central United States and is considered part of the Midwest by the U.S. Census Bureau and is also part of the Great Plains region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Western South Dakota's culture, economy, and geography have more in common with the West than the Midwest.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a total area of 77 116 square miles (199730 km2), making the state the 17th largest in the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk Peak, formerly known as Harney Peak, with an altitude of 7242 feet (2,207 m), is the highest point in the state, while the shore of Big Stone Lake is the lowest, with an altitude of 966 feet (294 m).

sentence: South Dakota is bordered north by North Dakota

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geographic center of the United States is 27 kilometres west of Castle Rock in Butte County.

sentence: The North American inaccessibility continental pole is located between Allen and Kyle, 1024 mi (1,648 km) from the nearest coastline.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River is the largest and longest of the rivers in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Cheyenne, James, Big Sioux, and White rivers are other major rivers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota has many natural lakes, mostly created by periods of glaciation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, dams on the Missouri River create four large reservoirs: Oahe Lake, Sharpe Lake, Francis Case Lake, Lewis Lake, and Clark Lake.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is generally divided into three regions: eastern South Dakota, western South Dakota, and Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Missouri serves as a boundary in terms of geographical, social and political differences between eastern and western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geography of the Black Hills, long considered sacred by the Amerindians, differs from its environment to such an extent that it can be regarded as distinct from the rest of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sometimes the Black Hills are combined with the rest of the western South Dakota, and people often refer to the two resulting areas divided by the Missouri River, the West River and the East River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eastern South Dakota generally has higher precipitation and a lower topography than the western part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Smaller geographic areas include the Prairie Coteau, the Dissolved Till Plains and the James River Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Prairie Coteau is a plateau bordered to the east by the Minnesota River valley and to the west by the James River basin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Further to the west, the James River basin is mainly low, flat and heavily eroded land, following the flow of the James River by South Dakota from north to south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Till Plains Dissected, an area of hilly hills and fertile soil that covers much of Iowa and Nebraska, extends in the southeast corner of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The layers deposited during the Pleistocene period, starting about two million years ago, cover most of eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: These are the youngest rock and sedimentary layers of the state, the product of successive periods of glaciation that deposited a large amount of rock and soil, known as till, on the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains cover most of the western two-thirds of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, the landscape becomes more arid and rugged, consisting of hilly hills, plains, ravines and steep flat-top hills called mounds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the south, to the east of the black hills, are the Badlands of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The erosion of the Black Hills, marine skeletons fallen to the bottom of a large shallow sea that once covered the region, and volcanic materials all contribute to the geology of this region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are in the southwest part of South Dakota and extend to Wyoming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This range of low mountains covers 6,000 m2 (16 000 km2), with peaks increasing from 2,000 to 4,000 feet (600 to 1,200 m) above their bases.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are the location of Black Elk Peak (7,242 ft or 2,207 m above sea level), the highest point in South Dakota, and also the highest point in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two billion-year-old precambrian formations, the oldest rocks in the state, form the central nucleus of the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The formations of the Paleozoic era formed the outer ring of the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This region presents rocks like limestone, which were deposited here when the area formed the shoreline of an ancient inland sea.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Much of South Dakota (with the exception of the Black Hills area) is dominated by a temperate prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although grasses and crops cover most of this area, deciduous trees, such as cottonwood, elms and willows, are common near rivers and in shelter belts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state bird, the necklace pheasant, adapted well to the region after being introduced from China.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Growing populations of bald eagles spread throughout the state, especially near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Prairie rivers and lakes are home to populations of walleye, carp, pike, bass, and other species.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Missouri also contains the prehistoric spatular.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to higher elevations and precipitation levels, the ecology of the Black Hills differs significantly from that of the plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The mountains are covered with different types of pine, including ponderosa and lodgepole pines, as well as spruce.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Hills mammals include deer, elk, sheep, mountain goats, pine martens and mountain lions, while rivers and lakes contain several species of trout.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a continental climate with four distinct seasons, ranging from cold and dry winters to warm and semi-wet summers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During summers, the average state temperature is often close to 90°F (32°C), although it cools to almost 60°F (16°C) at night.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is not uncommon for South Dakota to have severe hot and dry periods in summer, with temperatures above 100°F (38°C) several times a year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Winters are cold, with high January temperatures on average below freezing, and low temperatures on average below 10°F (−12°C) in most states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 120°F (49°C) at Usta on 15 July 2006 and the lowest recorded temperature was -58°F (−50°C) at McIntosh on 17 February 1936.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Average annual precipitation in South Dakota ranges from semi-arids in the northwestern part of the state (approximately 15 inches or 380 mm) to semi-humids around the southeastern part of the state (approximately 25 inches or 640 mm), although a small lead-centered area in the black hills has the highest precipitation at almost 30 inches (760 mm) per year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The summers of South Dakota lead to frequent, sometimes severe, thunderstorms with strong winds, thunders and hail.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the State is often considered part of the Tornado gangway, and South Dakota suffers an average of 30 tornadoes each year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Severe blizzards and ice storms often occur in winter.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has several sites managed by the National Park Service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two national parks were established in the state, both in the southwestern region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wind Cave National Park, established in 1903 in the Black Hills, has a vast network of caves and a large herd of bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Badlands National Park was established in 1978 and is home to a brightly coloured eroded landscape surrounded by semi-arid grasslands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mount Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills was created in 1925.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The sculpture of four American presidents was carved on the mountain by sculptor Gutzon Borglum.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other areas managed by the National Parks Service include Jewel Cave National Monument near Custer, Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, which includes a decommissioned nuclear missile silo and a separate missile control area several miles away, and the Missouri National Recreational River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crazy Horse Memorial is a large mountainside sculpture near Mount Rushmore being built with private funds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mammouth site near Hot Springs is another private attraction in the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This is a functioning paleontological excavation that has one of the world's largest concentrations of mammoth remains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have been living in what is today South Dakota for thousands of years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first inhabitants were Paleoindian hunter-gatherers and disappeared from the area around 5000 BC.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Between 500 and 800 AD, a semi-nomadic population known as the Mound Builders lived in central and eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 14th century, there was the Crow Creek massacre, where several hundred men, women and children were killed near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As early as 1500, the Arikara (or Ree) had settled in much of the Missouri Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: European contacts with the region began in 1743 when the LaVérendrye brothers explored the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The LaVérendrye group buried a plaque near today's Pierre site, claiming the region for France as part of the Greater Louisiana.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1762 the whole region became part of the Spanish Louisiana until 1802.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of the 19th century, the Sioux had largely replaced the Arikara as the dominant group in the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1803 the United States purchased the territory of Louisiana, a region that included most of Napoleon Bonaparte's South Dakota, and President Thomas Jefferson organized a group commonly known as the Lewis and Clark Expedition to explore the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1817, an American fur trade post was established at present, Fort Pierre, which began to settle continuously in the United States in the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1855, the American army bought Fort Pierre, but abandoned it in 1857, in favour of Fort Randall in the south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At that time, American and European settlement grew rapidly, and in 1858 the Yankton Sioux signed the Treaty of 1858, giving to the United States most of the present South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Speculators founded two of the largest current cities in Southeast Dakota: Sioux Falls in 1856 and Yankton in 1859.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1861, the territory of Dakota was established by the U.S. government (it originally included North Dakota, South Dakota and parts of Montana and Wyoming).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Colonization of the region, mainly by people from the eastern United States and western and northern Europe, increased rapidly, especially after the completion of an eastern railway link with Yankton in 1873.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1874 gold was discovered in the Black Hills during a military expedition led by George A. Custer and miners and explorers began illegally entering the land promised to the Lakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Custer expedition took place despite the fact that the Sioux had received the entire western half of the current South Dakota (West River) in 1868 by the Treaty of Laramie under the Sioux Great Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux refused to grant mining rights or lands in the Black Hills, and the war broke out after the United States failed to prevent white miners and settlers from entering the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Finally, the United States won and broke the Sioux Great Reserve into five reserves, settling Lakota there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1980, the Supreme Court and Congress ordered compensation, but the Lakota still refused to accept it, insisting on the return of their lands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A growing population and political concerns (the accession of two states meant the arrival of four new senators for the Republican Party) led to the division of Dakota territory into two and President Benjamin Harrison signed proclamations in which he officially admitted South Dakota and North Dakota to union on November 2, 1889.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harrison had the papers tight to darken which was signed first and the order was not recorded.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On December 29, 1890, the massacre of the injured knee occurred on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Considered the last major armed conflict between the United States and the Lakota Sioux nation, the massacre resulted in the death of at least 146 Sioux, many of whom were women and children.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 31 American soldiers were also killed during the conflict.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 1930s, several economic and climate conditions combined with disastrous results for South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lack of rain, extremely high temperatures and inappropriate cultivation techniques produced what was known as the Dust Bowl in South Dakota and several other plain states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The fertile soil was blown into massive dust storms, and several crops were completely destroyed.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Dust Bowl's experiences, coupled with the seizure of local banks and the general economic effects of the Great Depression, have led to the release of many Dakotas from the south of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Between 1930 and 1940, the population of South Dakota declined by more than 7 per cent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Economic stability returned with the entry of the United States into the Second World War in 1941, when demand for state agricultural and industrial products increased as the country mobilized for the war.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1944, the Pick–Sloan Plan was passed by the U.S. Congress as part of the 1944 Flood Control Act, resulting in the construction of six major dams on the Missouri River, four of which are at least partially located in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Flood control, hydropower and recreational activities such as boating and fishing are carried out by dams and reservoirs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In recent decades, South Dakota has shifted from a state dominated by agriculture to a state characterized by a more diversified economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The tourism industry has grown considerably since the completion of the interstate system in the 1960s, with Black Hills becoming an increasingly important destination.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The financial services industry also began to grow in the state, with the transfer of Citibank's credit card operations from New York to Sioux Falls in 1981, a movement that was followed by several other financial companies.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the first State to eliminate interest rate ceilings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, the location of the recently closed Homestake gold mine near Lead was chosen as the site of a new underground research facility, the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the increase in the population of the State and recent economic development, many rural areas have struggled over the past 50 years with the decline of local populations and the emigration of educated young adults to the major cities of South Dakota, such as Rapid City or Sioux Falls, or to other states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mechanization and consolidation of agriculture have greatly contributed to the reduction in the number of small family farms and the resulting economic and demographic difficulties for rural cities.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the state often ranks first for its way of life, and Gallup's 2018 Well-Being Index named South Dakota the happiest and healthier state in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the population of South Dakota was 884,659 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 8.66 per cent since the 2010 U.S. census, and that only North Dakota, Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2019, South Dakota had an estimated population of 884,659, an increase of 70,479, or 8.66%, since 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 7.3% of the population of South Dakota was under the age of 5, 24% under the age of 18 and 14.3% under the age of 65.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Women constitute about 50.2 per cent of the population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At the 2000 census, South Dakota was the fifth lowest of the nation in terms of population and population density.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of South Dakota's inhabitants, 65.7 per cent were born in South Dakota, 31.4 per cent were born in another United States State, 0.6 per cent were born in Puerto Rico, parts of the United States island or were born abroad to United States parents, and 2.3 per cent were born in another country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota population centre is located in Buffalo County, in the unincorporated county seat of Gann Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, the racial composition of the population was as follows:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ethnicly, 2.7 per cent of the population of South Dakota was of Hispanic, Latin or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2011, 25.4% of the population of South Dakota under 1 years of age were minorities, meaning that there was at least one parent who was not Hispanic white.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2000, the five largest ancestry groups in South Dakota were German (40.7%), Norwegian (15.3%), Irish (10.4%), Native American (8.3%) and English (7.1%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Germans are the largest ancestry group in most parts of the state, especially in the East River (east of Missouri), although there are also large Scandinavian populations in some counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the largest population of Hutterites, a communal group of Anabaptists who emigrated from Europe in 1874, mostly from German-speaking regions.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians, largely Lakota, Dakota and Nakota (Sioux), predominate in several counties and make up 20% of the West River population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The seven major Indian reserves of the state occupy a very small area compared to the former West River reserve, which the federal government had previously allocated to the Sioux tribes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the third largest Aboriginal population in all states, behind Alaska and New Mexico.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Five of the state counties are within the boundaries of sovereign Indian reserves.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to the limitations of climate and land, and the isolation of urban areas with higher employment opportunities, the standard of living on many South Dakota reserves is often well below the national average; Ziebach County ranked as the poorest of the nation in 2009.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The unemployment rate in Fort Thompson, Crow Creek Reserve, is 70%, and 21% of households lack basic plumbing or cooking equipment.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A 1995 study by the U.S. Census Office found that 58 per cent of homes on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve did not have a telephone.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The isolation of reserves also hinders their ability to generate income from gaming casinos, an avenue that has proved profitable for many tribes closer to urban centres.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1995, the legislature passed a law to make English the "common language" of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since 2019, "the language of the Grand Sioux Nation, consisting of three dialects, Dakota, Lakota and Nakota", is an official language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2000 census, 1.90 per cent of the population aged 5 years or older speak German at home, 1.51 per cent speak Lakota or Dakota and 1.43 per cent speak Spanish.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 93.46 per cent of South Dakota residents aged 5 and over spoke English as their main language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 6.54 per cent of the population spoke a language other than English.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 2.06 % (15,292) of the population spoke Spanish, 1.39 % (10,282) spoke Dakota and 1.37% (10,140) spoke German.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other languages spoken included Vietnamese (0.16%), Chinese (0.12%) and Russian (0.10%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Over the past few decades, the population has declined in many rural areas of South Dakota, as in other states of the Great Plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The change was described as "rural flight" while family farming declined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Young people have moved to cities to find other jobs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This trend has continued in recent years, with 30 counties in South Dakota losing their population between 1990 and 2000.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Meanwhile, nine counties suffered a population loss of more than 10 per cent, with Harding County in the northwest corner of the state losing nearly 19 per cent of its population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The low birth rate and the absence of younger immigrants led to an increase in the median age of many of these counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 24 counties, at least 20% of the population is over the age of 65, compared with a national rate of 12.8%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the effect of rural flights has not been uniformly spread across South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although most rural counties and small towns have lost population, the Sioux Falls region, the largest counties along Interstate 29, the Black Hills, and many Indian reserves have all gained population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As reserves exercised greater sovereignty, some Sioux returned to them from urban areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lincoln County, near Sioux Falls, was the fastest growing seventh (percentage) county in the U.S. in 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The growth of these areas offset losses in the rest of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The total population of South Dakota continues to increase steadily, but at a slower rate than the national average.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest denominations by the number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 148,883 members, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA) with 112,649 members and the United Methodist Church (UMC) with 36,020 members.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (ELCA and UMC are specific denominations in the more general terms "Lutheran" and "Methodist", respectively.

name: south_dakota
sentence: )The results of a 2001 survey, in which South Dakotas were invited to identify their religion, include:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Government revenue in current South Dakota dollars was $39.8 billion in 2010, the fifth smallest state output in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Per capita personal income was $38,865 in 2010, ranking 25th in the United States, and 12.5 per cent of the population was below the poverty line in 2008.The list of the CNBC's Top States for Business for 2010 recognized South Dakota as the seventh best state in the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In July 2011, the state unemployment rate was 4.7%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The service industry is the major economic contributor to South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This sector includes the retail, finance and health care industries.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Citibank, which was the largest banking holding company in the United States at one time, established domestic banking operations in South Dakota in 1981 to take advantage of favourable banking rules.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Public spending is another important segment of the government economy, accounting for more than ten per cent of gross domestic product.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellsworth Air Force Base near Rapid City is the second largest employer in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Historically, agriculture has been a key component of South Dakota's economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although other industries have developed rapidly in recent decades, agricultural production remains very important for the state economy, especially in rural areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five most valuable agricultural products in South Dakota are livestock, maize, soybeans, wheat and pork.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture-related industries such as meat packaging and ethanol production also have a considerable economic impact on the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the sixth largest ethanol producer in the country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Another important sector in South Dakota's economy is tourism.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many travel to see the attractions of the state, especially those of the Black Hills area, such as the historic Deadwood, Mount Rushmore, and neighbouring national and state parks.

name: south_dakota
sentence: One of the most important tourism events in the state is the annual Moto Sturgis Rally.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five-day event attracted over 739,000 participants in 2015; as the state has a total population of 850,000.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, tourism provided about 33,000 jobs in the state and contributed more than $2 billion to the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has 83,609 miles (134556 km) of highways, roads and streets, as well as 679 miles (1,093 km) of interstate highways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two major interstates cross South Dakota: Interstate 90, which crosses the southern half of the State to the east and west; and Interstate 29, which runs north and south in the eastern part of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Corridor I-29 generally has higher population and economic growth rates than eastern South Dakota areas farther from the interstate.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Also in the state are the shorter Interstate 190, a spur in the centre of Rapid City, and 229, a loop around the south and east Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several major U.S. highways cross the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American roads 12, 14, 16, 18 and 212 run east and west, while U.S. roads 81, 83, 85 and 281 run north and south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota and Montana are the only states that share a land border that is not crossed by a paved road.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota contains two national highways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Peter Norbeck National Scenic Byway is located in the Black Hills, while the Native American Scenic Byway runs along the Missouri River in the north central part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other scenic passages include Badlands Loop Scenic Byway, Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway, and Wildlife Loop Road Scenic Byway.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Railways have played an important role in transport in South Dakota since the mid-19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Some 7,110 km of railway were built in South Dakota in the late 19th century and early 20th century, but only 3,960 km are active.

name: south_dakota
sentence: BNSF Railway is the largest railway in South Dakota, while Rapid City, Pierre and Eastern Railroad (formerly Dakota, Minnesota and East) are the other major carriers of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other state carriers include Dakota Southern Railway, Dakota and Iowa Railroad, Ellis and Eastern Railroad, Sunfloor Railroad, Canadian Pacific Railway and Sisseton Milbank Railroad.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rail transport in the state is mainly freight, but there are two historic passenger railways: Black Hills Central and Prairie Village, Herman and Milwaukee.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, South Dakota is one of two contiguous states that do not have Amtrak's service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (South Dakota is the only contiguous state that has ever had Amtrak—Wyoming used to be served by the San Francisco Zephyr and Pioneer.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest commercial airports in South Dakota in terms of passenger traffic are the Sioux Falls Regional Airport and the Rapid City Regional Airport.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Delta Air Lines, Frontier Airlines and Allegiant Airlines, as well as suburban airlines that use the affiliate brand with the major airlines, serve the two largest airports.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several other cities in the state also have commercial air services: Aberdeen Regional Airport, Pierre Regional Airport and Watertown Regional Airport, some of which are subsidized by the Essential Air Service program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Like other American states, the structure of the South Dakota government follows the same separation of powers as the federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The structure of the State Government is set out in the Constitution of South Dakota, the supreme law of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution may be amended by a majority vote of both Houses of the Legislative Assembly or by electoral initiative.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor of South Dakota occupies the executive branch of the Government of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The present governor is Kristi Noem, a Republican.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of the State gives the Governor the power to sign laws or bills on the veto adopted by the legislature of the State, to act as Commander-in-Chief of the National Guard of South Dakota, to appoint a Government, to commute criminal penalties or to pardon persons convicted of crimes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor shall be appointed for a term of four years and may not be appointed for more than two consecutive terms.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The State legislature is composed of two bodies, the 35-member Senate and the 70-member House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is divided into 35 legislative districts, with electors electing two representatives and one senator per district.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Parliament meets for an annual session which starts on the second Tuesday in January and lasts 30 days.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The judiciary is divided into several levels.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Supreme Court of the State, with four judges and one chief justice, is the highest court in the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the Supreme Court are the circuit courts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the district courts are the courts of first instance, which deal with fewer criminal and civil cases.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2005, South Dakota had the lowest total per capita tax rate in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crown does not collect personal or corporate income taxes, estate taxes or taxes on intangible personal property.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The rate of the State sales tax is 4.5%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Various localities have local levies, so in some areas the rate is 6%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The government's sales tax does not apply to Indian sales on Indian reserves, but many reserves have a contract with the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On-reserve businesses collect the tax and government refunds to Indian tribes the percentage of sales tax collected in relation to the ratio of the Indian population to the total population of the county or area affected.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ad valorem property taxes are local taxes and are an important source of financing for school systems, counties, municipalities and other local governments.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Special Tax Division of South Dakota regulates certain taxes, including taxes on cigarettes and alcohol.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is represented at the federal level by Senator John Thune, Senator Mike Rounds, and representative Dusty Johnson.

name: south_dakota
sentence: All three of them are Republicans.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is one of the seven states with only one seat in the United States House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the presidential elections in the United States, South Dakota received three out of 538 votes in the Electoral College.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As in all other states except the neighbouring Maine and Nebraska, South Dakota electoral votes are granted in a win-win system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota politics is generally dominated by the Republican Party.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since the creation of the state, republicans have won the state's electoral votes in all but five presidential elections: 1896, 1912 (by the Progressive Party of Theodore Roosevelt), 1932, 1936 and 1964.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Democratic George McGovern, from South Dakota, failed to carry his home state in 1972.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Only Alaska was worn fewer times by a democrat.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, a democrat has not won the post of governor since 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, Republicans hold a 15% advantage over Democrats and large majorities in the House of State and the Senator of State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the republican and conservative general inclinations of the state, democrats have been successful in various state-wide elections, including those involving representatives of the South Dakota Congress in Washington.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians are increasingly active in the electoral policy of states and counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2002 election, the American Indian vote brought Tim Johnson as Democratic candidate to a margin of 532 votes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Until his electoral defeat in 2004, Senator Tom Daschle was the leader of the Senators' minority (and briefly his majority leader during the senator's democratic control in 2001-2002).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other prominent Democrats in South Dakota include former presidential candidates George McGovern and Hubert Humphrey.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, South Dakota voted for Republican candidate Donald Trump against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton with a 30% margin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2018, Republican MP Kristi Noem beat Democrat Billie Sutton in the Gubernatorial election by a small margin, and Republican Dusty Johnson defeated Democrat Tim Bjorkman for his seat in the US House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Contemporary political issues in South Dakota include the costs and benefits of the state lottery, the relatively low ranking of South Dakota in education spending (especially teachers' compensation — recently, the state sales tax has been increased from 4% to 4.5% to finance an increase in teachers' remuneration), and recent legislative and electoral attempts to ban abortion in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A bill supported by the Republicans, passed in March 2019, requires all public schools to display "In God we have confidence" in a prominent place.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota culture reflects the American, rural, western and European Indian roots of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of annual events celebrating the state's ethnic and historical heritage take place around the state, such as Days of '76 in Deadwood, Czech Days in Tabor, and the annual festivities of St.Patrick and Cinco de Mayo in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The various tribes hold many annual pow wows on their reserves throughout the state, to which non-native Americans are sometimes invited.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Custer State Park holds an annual Buffalo Roundup, in which horse volunteers collect the park's herd of approximately 1,500 bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk (Lakota) was a man of medicine and heyokha, whose life lasted the transition to reserves.

name: south_dakota
sentence: His stories of the Indian War Movement and 19th-century phantom dance and his deep thoughts on personal visions and Amerindian religion formed the basis of the book Black Elk Speaks, first published in 1932.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Among several editions, a first annotated edition was released in 2008.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Paul Goble, author and illustrator of award-winning children's books, has been based at the Black Hills since 1977.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Laura Ingalls Wilder, whose semi-autobiographical books are based on her experiences as a child and young adult on the border, is one of the most well-known writers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: She drew from her life from a home near De Smet as a base for five of her novels: By the Shores of Silver Lake, The Long Winter, Little Town on the Prairie, This Happy Golden Years and The First Four Years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: These became popular in the United States when Little House on the Prairie was adapted and produced as a television series in 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rose Wilder Lane, the daughter of Wilder, was born near De Smet in 1886.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has also produced several outstanding artists.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harvey Dunn grew up in a house near Manchester at the end of the 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While Dunn worked most of his career as a commercial illustrator, his most famous works showed various scenes of border life; he completed these towards the end of his career.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Oscar Howe (Crow) was born on the Crow Creek Indian Reserve and won the fame of his watercolour paintings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Howe was one of the first Amerindian painters to adopt techniques and style strongly influenced by the abstraction movement of the mid-20th century, rather than relying on traditional Amerindian styles.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Terry Redlin, a native of Watertown, is an accomplished painter of rural and wild scenes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many of his works are on display at the Redlin Art Center in Watertown.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls is the largest city in South Dakota, with a population of 153,888 inhabitants in 2010 and a metropolitan area of 238,122 inhabitants.The city, founded in 1856, is located in the southeast corner of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Retail, finance and health care became more important in Sioux Falls, where the economy was originally focused on agro-industry and careers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City, with a population of 67,956 in 2010 and a population of 124,766 in the metropolitan area, is the second largest city in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is located at the eastern edge of the Black Hills and was founded in 1876.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City's economy is largely based on tourism and defence spending, due to the proximity to many tourist attractions in the Black Hills and Ellsworth Air Force Base.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The following eight cities in the state, in descending order of population in 2010, were Aberdeen (26,091), Brookings (22,056), Watertown (21,482), Mitchell (15,254), Yankton (14,454), Pierre (13,646), Huron (12,592) and Vermillion (10,571).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the capital of the state, and Brookings and Vermillion are the locations of the two largest universities of the state (South Dakota State University and South Dakota University, respectively).

name: south_dakota
sentence: With a population of approximately 14,000, Pierre is the second smallest state capital in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of the ten largest cities in the state, only the rapid city is located west of Missouri.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first South Dakota newspaper, the Democratic Dakota, began to appear in Yankton in 1858.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Today, the biggest newspaper in the state is the Sioux Falls Argus Leader, with a Sunday draw of 63,701 and a weekday draw of 44,334 copies.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Rapid City Journal, with a Sunday draw of 32,638 and a weekday broadcast of 27,827, is the second largest newspaper in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The other four major government newspapers are Aberdeen American News, Watertown Public Opinion, Huron Plainsman and Brookings Register.

name: south_dakota
