sentence: The state's many oil tycoons are also a popular subject of pop culture as seen in the successful television series Dallas.

name: texas
sentence: The internationally known slogan "Don't Mess with Texas" began as anti-attractive advertising.

name: texas
sentence: Since the campaign began in 1986, the term has become "a declaration of identity, a declaration by Texas Swagger".

name: texas
sentence: "Texas-size" is an expression that can be used in two ways: to describe something that is about the size of the American state of Texas, or to describe something (usually but not always from Texas) that is large compared to other objects of its type.

name: texas
sentence: Texas was the largest American state until Alaska became a state in 1959.

name: texas
sentence: The term "everything is bigger in Texas" has been used regularly since at least 1950; it was used in 1913.

name: texas
sentence: Houston is one of five U.S. cities with permanent professional resident companies in all major performing arts disciplines: Houston Grand Opera, Houston Symphony Orchestra, Houston Ballet and The Alley Theatre.

name: texas
sentence: Known for the liveliness of its visual and performing arts, the Houston Theater District, an area of 17 blocks in the heart of downtown Houston, ranks second in the country for the number of theatre seats in a concentrated area of the city centre, with 12,948 seats for live shows and 1,480 cinema seats.

name: texas
sentence: Founded in 1892, the Fort Worth Museum of Modern Art, also known as "La Moderne", is Texas's oldest art museum.

name: texas
sentence: Fort Worth also has the Kimbell Art Museum, the Amon Carter Museum, the National Cowgirl Museum and the Hall of Fame, the Will Rogers Memorial Center, and the Downtown Bass Performance Hall.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas' downtown arts district is home to artistic venues such as Dallas Art Museum, Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Centre, Margot Opera and Bill Winspear, Trammell & Margaret Crow Asian Art Collection, and Nasher Sculpture Centre.

name: texas
sentence: Deep Ellum neighbourhood within Dallas became popular in the 1920s and 1930s as the first jazz and hotspot blues in the southern United States.

name: texas
sentence: The name Deep Ellum comes from the local population that pronounces "Deep Elm" as "Deep Ellum".

name: texas
sentence: Artists such as Blind Lemon Jefferson, Robert Johnson, Huddie "Lead Belly" Ledbetter, and Bessie Smith have played in Deep Ellum clubs.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, The Live Music Capital of the World, has "more concert halls per capita than music centers like Nashville, Memphis, Los Angeles, Las Vegas and New York City."

name: texas
sentence: The city's music revolves around 6th Street nightclubs; events such as film, music and South by Southwest multimedia festival; the longest concert music program on American television, Austin City Limits; and the Austin City Limits Music Festival in Zilker Park.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, San Antonio has become "The capital of the world's Tejano music".

name: texas
sentence: The Tejano Music Awards provided a forum to raise awareness and appreciation of Tejano's music and culture.

name: texas
sentence: The second President of the Republic of Texas, Mirabeau B. Lamar, is the father of Texas Education.

name: texas
sentence: During its term of office, the state reserved three leagues of land in each county to equip public schools.

name: texas
sentence: Some 50 additional leagues of land set aside for the support of two universities will later become the basis of the State's Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: Lamar's action has laid the foundation for a Texas-wide system of public schools.

name: texas
sentence: From 2006 to 2007, Texas spent $7,275 per student, ranking below the national average of $9,389.

name: texas
sentence: The pupil-teacher ratio was 14.9 below the national average of 15.3.

name: texas
sentence: Texas instructors paid $41,744 less than the national average of $46,593.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Education Agency (TEA) administers the state's public education systems.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has more than 1,000 school districts; all districts, with the exception of the Stafford Municipal School District, are independent of the municipal government and many cross city boundaries.

name: texas
sentence: School districts have the power to impose taxes on their residents and to assert a prominent domain on private property.

name: texas
sentence: Due to the fair financing of schools by the courts for school districts, the State has a controversial tax redistribution system called the Robin Hood Plan.

name: texas
sentence: The plan transfers tax revenues from rich school districts to the poor.

name: texas
sentence: The AME has no authority over the activities of private or home-based schools.

name: texas
sentence: Students from Texas take the state of Texas Academic Readiness Assessments (STAAR) in primary and secondary school.

name: texas
sentence: STAAR evaluates students' achievements in reading, writing, mathematics, science and social studies required by the Texas Education Standards and the No Child Left Behind Act.

name: texas
sentence: The test replaced the Texas Assessment of Knowledge and Skills (TAKS) test during the 2011-2012 academic year.

name: texas
sentence: Generally prohibited in the West in general, corporal punishment in schools is not unusual in the more conservative rural areas of the state, with 28,569 students in public schools paddling at least once, according to government data for the 2011-2012 school year.

name: texas
sentence: The rate of corporal punishment at school in Texas is surpassed only by Mississippi, Alabama and Arkansas.

name: texas
sentence: The two most recognized leading universities in the state are the University of Texas in Austin and the University of A&M in Texas, ranked 21st and 41st best universities in the country according to the latest 2020 report from the Centre for World University Rankings, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Some observers also include the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas as Level 1 Lighthouses alongside UT Austin and A&M.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Higher Education Coordinating Council categorizes state public universities into three distinct components:

name: texas
sentence: Texas's Bill 588, another controversial affirmative action plan, guarantees Texas students who have graduated in the 10 per cent of their high school class automatic admission to state-funded universities.

name: texas
sentence: The bill encourages demographic diversity while seeking to avoid problems arising from the Hopwood v. Texas case (1996).

name: texas
sentence: Thirty-six (36) separate and distinct public universities exist in Texas, 32 of which belong to one of the six academic systems of the state.

name: texas
sentence: The discovery of minerals on the lands of the Permanent University Fund, particularly oil, helped fund the rapid growth of the two largest university systems in the state: the University of Texas system and the Texas A&M system.

name: texas
sentence: The other four academic systems: the University of Houston system, the University of North Texas system, the State of Texas system, and the Texas technical system are not funded by the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The Carnegie Foundation ranks four of Texas's universities as Tier 1 research institutions: the University of Texas at Austin, the University of A&M in Texas, the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas at Austin and the University of A&M in Texas are the leading universities of the University of Texas and Texas A&M University System, respectively.

name: texas
sentence: Both were established by the Texas Constitution and hold interests in the Permanent University Fund.

name: texas
sentence: The State has sought to increase the number of flagship universities by raising some of its seven institutions designated as "emerging research universities".

name: texas
sentence: The two that should emerge first are the University of Houston and the Technical University of Texas, probably in this order according to the discussions on the floor of the 82nd Texas legislature.

name: texas
sentence: The state is home to various private institutions of higher education, from liberal arts colleges to a nationally recognized high-level research university.

name: texas
sentence: Rice University in Houston is one of the largest universities of teaching and research in the United States and ranked 17th best university in the country by US News & World Report.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity University, a private university, mainly undergraduate in liberal arts in San Antonio, ranked first among the universities that awarded Bachelors and Masters degrees mainly to the Western United States for 20 consecutive years by US News.

name: texas
sentence: Private universities include Abilene Christian University, Austin College, Baylor University, Mary Hardin–Baylor University and Southwest University.

name: texas
sentence: Texas universities host three presidential libraries: George Bush's Presidential Library at A&M University in Texas, the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum at the University of Texas in Austin, and George W. Bush's Presidential Library at the South Methodist University.

name: texas
sentence: Despite the concentration of elite medical centers in the state, the Commonwealth Fund ranks Texas's health care system third among the country's worst.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ranks close to the top in the areas of access to health care, quality of care, avoidable hospital expenses, and equity among the various groups.

name: texas
sentence: The causes of the state's poor rankings include politics, high poverty and the nation's highest illegal immigration rate.

name: texas
sentence: In May 2006, Texas launched the Red Code program in response to the report, with the state accounting for 25.1 per cent of the population without health insurance, the largest proportion in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Trust for America's Health ranked Texas 15th in terms of adult obesity, with 27.2 per cent of the state population being obese.

name: texas
sentence: The 2008 survey on obesity among men ranked four cities in Texas among the 25 fattest cities in America; Houston ranked 6th, Dallas 7th, El Paso 8th and Arlington 14th.

name: texas
sentence: Texas had only one city (Austin, 21st) in the top 25 among America's "most performing cities".

name: texas
sentence: The same survey positively evaluated government obesity initiatives with a "B+".

name: texas
sentence: The State ranks forty-second in the percentage of residents who practice regular exercise according to a 2007 study.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has the highest maternal mortality rate in the developed world and the death rate of Texas women due to pregnancy-related complications doubled between 2010 and 2014, reaching 23.8 per 100,000.

name: texas
sentence: Unmatched rate in any other U.S. state or economically developed country.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has many elite research centers.

name: texas
sentence: There are nine medical schools, three dental schools and two optometry schools in the State.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) laboratories: one at the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) in Galveston, and the other at the Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research in San Antonio, the first private laboratory at BSL-4 in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center in Houston has the world's largest concentration of research and health care institutions, with 47 member institutions.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Medical Center performs the largest number of heart transplants in the world.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas Cancer Centre M.D. Anderson in Houston is a highly recognized academic institution focused on cancer patient care, research, education and prevention.

name: texas
sentence: San Antonio's South Texas Medical Center facilities rank sixth in terms of the impact of clinical medicine research in the United States.

name: texas
sentence: The University of Texas's Centre for Health Sciences is another highly ranked research and education institution in San Antonio.

name: texas
sentence: The American Heart Association and the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Centre call Dallas home.

name: texas
sentence: The institution's medical school employs the largest number of Nobel School of Medicine laureates in the world.

name: texas
sentence: The texans have had historical difficulties crossing Texas due to the large size and rugged terrain of the state.

name: texas
sentence: Texas offset by building America's largest road and rail networks.

name: texas
sentence: The regulatory authority, the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), maintains the state's vast road network, and regulates aviation and public transport.

name: texas
sentence: The state is an important transportation centre.

name: texas
sentence: From the Dallas/Fort Worth region, trucks can reach 93 per cent of the country's population in 48 hours and 37 per cent in 24 hours.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 33 foreign trade zones (FTZs), the most populous in the country.

name: texas
sentence: In 2004, a combined total of $298 billion in goods transited through Texas's TFAs.

name: texas
sentence: The first highway in Texas was the Gulf Highway, which opened in 1948 in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: In 2005, 79,535 miles (127,999 kilometres) of public highway crossed Texas (instead of 71,000 miles (114,263 kilometres) in 1984).

name: texas
sentence: To finance the recent growth of state highways, Texas has 17 toll roads (see list) with several additional toll routes proposed.

name: texas
sentence: In central Texas, the southern section of the State Highway 130 toll road has a speed limit of 85 miles per hour (137 km/h), the highest in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: All federal highways and Texas states are paved.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has 730 airports, the second largest of all states in the country.

name: texas
sentence: Larger in Texas by size and passengers served, Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW) is the second largest per region in the United States, and the fourth largest in the world with 18,076 acres (73.15 km2).

name: texas
sentence: In traffic, DFW is the busiest airport in the state, the fourth busiest airport in the United States, and the sixth busiest airport in the world.

name: texas
sentence: American Airlines Group, American / American Eagle, the largest airline in the world in number of passenger miles transported and passenger fleet size, uses DFW as its largest and largest hub.

name: texas
sentence: It ranks as the largest airline in the United States by the number of passengers transported inside the country per year and the largest airline in the world by the number of passengers transported.Southwest Airlines, headquartered in Dallas, operates in Dallas Love Field.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's second largest air facility is the George Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH) in Houston.

name: texas
sentence: It served as the largest hub for the former Continental Airlines, which was based in Houston; it serves as the largest hub for United Airlines, the third largest airline in the world, by passenger miles.

name: texas
sentence: IAH offers a service to the most Mexican destinations of all U.S. airports.

name: texas
sentence: The other five largest airports in the state serve more than three million passengers a year: Austin-Bergstrom International Airport, William P. Hobby Airport, San Antonio International Airport, Dallas Love Field and El Paso International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The smallest airport in the State to be designated as an international airport is Del Rio International Airport.

name: texas
sentence: Approximately 1,150 seaports overlook the coast of Texas with over 1,600 km of canals.

name: texas
sentence: Ports employ nearly one million people and handle an average of 317 million metric tons.

name: texas
sentence: Texas ports connect to the rest of the U.S. Atlantic coast with the Gulf section of the Intracoastal waterway.

name: texas
sentence: The port of Houston is now the most frequent port in the United States in foreign tonnage, the second in total tonnage and the tenth in world tonnage.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Ship Channel extends 160 metres wide by 22 metres deep and 80 kilometres long.

name: texas
sentence: Part of the state's cowboy tradition is derived from the large cattle roads that its herders organized in the 19th century to drive cattle to the railways and markets of Kansas, for the expedition to the east.

name: texas
sentence: Cities along the way, such as Baxter Springs, Kansas' first cow town, have developed to take care of seasonal workers and tens of thousands of cattle.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to operate in Texas was Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway, which opened in August 1853.

name: texas
sentence: The first railway to enter Texas from the north, completed in 1872, was the Missouri–Kansas–Texas railway.

name: texas
sentence: With increased access to the railway, farmers did not have to carry their cattle to the Midwest and shipped beef from Texas.

name: texas
sentence: This has led to a decline in cow city economies.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1911, Texas has led the nation for miles of railway in the state.

name: texas
sentence: The length of the Texas railways peaked in 1932 at 17,078 miles (27,484 kilometres), but decreased to 14,006 miles (35,540 kilometres) in 2000.

name: texas
sentence: While the Texas Railway Commission initially regulated the state railways, in 2005 the State reallocated these rights to TxDOT.

name: texas
sentence: In the Dallas–Fort Worth area, three public transit organizations offer rail services: Dallas Area Rapid Transit (DART), Denton County Transportation Authority (DCTA) and Trinity Metro.

name: texas
sentence: DART began operating the first light rail system in the southwest of the United States in 1996.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Railway Express (TRE) suburban rail service, which connects Fort Worth to Dallas, is provided by Trinity Metro and DART.

name: texas
sentence: Trinity Metro also operates the TEXRail suburban railway line, which links downtown Fort Worth and Northeast Tarrant County to DFW Airport.

name: texas
sentence: The A train line, operated by DCTA, serves as an extension of the DART Green line in Denton County.

name: texas
sentence: In the Austin area, the Capital Metropolitan Transportation Authority operates a suburban railway service called Capital MetroRail in the northwest suburbs.

name: texas
sentence: The Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas (METRO) operates light rail lines in the Houston area.

name: texas
sentence: Amtrak offers Texas a limited long distance rail service.

name: texas
sentence: Three regular routes serve the state: the Texas Eagle daily (Chicago–San Antonio), the semi-monthly Sunset Limited (New Orleans–Los Angeles), with stops in Texas, and the Heartland Flyer daily (Fort Worth–Oklahoma City).

name: texas
sentence: Texas could have one of the first high-speed rail lines in the country.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Central Railway Company has planned the construction of a privately financed high-speed rail line between Dallas and Houston.

name: texas
sentence: The present Constitution of Texas was adopted in 1876.

name: texas
sentence: Like many States, it explicitly provides for separation of powers.

name: texas
sentence: The State Bill of Rights is much larger than its federal bill of rights and contains Texas-specific provisions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive power that limits the governor's power, which is a weak executive power compared to other states.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of the Secretary of State, voters elect leaders independently, so candidates are directly accountable to the public, not the Governor.

name: texas
sentence: This electoral system has led to the division of certain executive powers among the parties and has reduced the governor's ability to implement a programme.

name: texas
sentence: When Republican President George W. Bush served as governor of Texas, the state had a democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

name: texas
sentence: The Executive includes the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Land Commissioner, the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Agriculture, the Texas Railway Commission, the State Council of Education and the Secretary of State.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Bicameral Legislative Assembly consists of the 150-member House of Representatives and a 31-member Senator.

name: texas
sentence: The Speaker of the House presides over the House, and the Lieutenant Governor, the Senator.

name: texas
sentence: The legislature meets in ordinary session every two years for just over a hundred days, but the governor may request extraordinary sessions as often as desired (notably, the legislature cannot meet itself).

name: texas
sentence: The financial year of the State begins on 1 September.

name: texas
sentence: Texas's judiciary is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping competencies.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has two courts of last resort: the Texas Supreme Court, for civil matters, and the Texas Criminal Court of Appeal.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of some municipal judges, partisan elections select judges at all levels of the judiciary; the Governor fills vacancies by appointment.

name: texas
sentence: Texas is remarkable for its use of capital punishment, having led the country to executions since the death penalty was restored in Gregg v. Georgia (see capital punishment in Texas).

name: texas
sentence: Texas Ranger Division of the Texas Department of Public Safety is a state-wide law enforcement agency.

name: texas
sentence: Over the years, Texas Rangers have investigated crimes ranging from murder to political corruption.

name: texas
sentence: They acted as riot police and inspectors, protected the governor of Texas, chased fugitives and acted as a paramilitary force for both the republic and the state.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Rangers were created informally by Stephen F. Austin in 1823 and officially formalized in 1835.

name: texas
sentence: The Rangers are an integral part of several important events in Texas history and some of the most well-known criminal cases in Old West history.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Constitution defines the responsibilities of county governments as agents of government.

name: texas
sentence: The so-called Commissioners, i.e. judges and judges of the courts, are elected to serve as an administrative organ.

name: texas
sentence: Most cities in the state, with more than 5,000 inhabitants, have local governments.

name: texas
sentence: The vast majority of them have charters for the forms of council-managerial government, by which voters elect the members of the council, who hire a director of a professional city as an operating officer.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1870s, White Democrats regained power in the state legislature of the biracial coalition at the end of Reconstruction.

name: texas
sentence: At the beginning of the 20th century, Parliament passed bills to impose voting taxes, followed by white primaries, which effectively deprived most blacks, poor whites and Mexican Americans.

name: texas
sentence: In the 1890s, 100,000 blacks voted in the state; in 1906, only 5,000 could vote.

name: texas
sentence: Consequently, the Democratic Party had dominated Texas politics since the beginning of the century, imposing racial segregation and white supremacy.

name: texas
sentence: It exercised power until the adoption, in the mid-1960s, of national legislation on civil rights that respected the constitutional rights of all citizens.

name: texas
sentence: Although Texas was essentially a single-party state at that time and democratic primary was considered "the real election", the Democratic Party had conservative and liberal factions, which became more pronounced after the New Deal.

name: texas
sentence: In addition, several factions of the party divided briefly in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: texas
sentence: The conservative white voters of the state began supporting the candidates for the Republican presidency in the middle of the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: After this period, they also supported the Republicans for local and state offices, and most whites became members of the Republican Party.

name: texas
sentence: The party has also attracted some minorities, but many have continued to vote for democratic candidates.

name: texas
sentence: The passage to the Republican Party is largely attributed to the fact that the Democratic Party became more and more liberal during the 20th century, and thus more and more untouchable with the average voter in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Since Texas was still a conservative state, voters turned to the GOP, which now more closely reflected their beliefs.

name: texas
sentence: Commentators also attributed the change to Republican political consultant Karl Rove, who led many political campaigns in Texas in the 1980s and 1990s.

name: texas
sentence: Other reasons cited include the court-ordered redistribution and demographic change in relation to the Sun Belt that favoured the Republican Party and conservatism.

name: texas
sentence: The 2003 Texas redistribution of Congressional districts led by Republican Tom DeLay was called by the New York Times "an extreme case of partisan Gerrymanding".

name: texas
sentence: A group of democratic legislators, the "Texas Eleven", fled the state in an effort to abuse the quorum to prevent the legislator from acting, but failed.

name: texas
sentence: The state had already undergone a redistribution after the 2000 census.

name: texas
sentence: Despite these efforts, the legislator has adopted a map strongly in favour of Republicans, based on 2000 data and ignoring the estimates of nearly one million new residents in the state since then.

name: texas
sentence: Career lawyers and analysts in the Department of Justice objected to the plan as diluting the votes of African-American and Hispanic voters, but the political appointees overstepped it and approved it.

name: texas
sentence: In League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry (2006), the National Supreme Court ruled in favour of the state (and Republicans).

name: texas
sentence: In the 2014 Texas election, the Tea Party movement made great strides, with many of the Tea Party's favourites elected to power, including Dan Patrick as Lieutenant Governor, Ken Paxton as Attorney General, as well as many other candidates including Conservative Republican Greg Abbott as Governor.

name: texas
sentence: The voters of Texas are leaning towards fiscal conservatism, while taking advantage of the huge federal investment in the state in military and other facilities obtained by the power of the South Solid in the 20th century.

name: texas
sentence: They are also tending to have socially conservative values.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1980, most of Texas's voters have supported Republican presidential candidates.

name: texas
sentence: In 2000 and 2004, Republican George W. Bush won Texas with 59.3 per cent and 60.1 per cent respectively, partly because of his status as "preferential son" as former state governor.

name: texas
sentence: John McCain won the state in 2008, but with a lower margin of victory than Bush with 55 percent of the votes.

name: texas
sentence: Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio constantly focus on democracy in local and state elections.

name: texas
sentence: The demographic evolution of the state may lead to a change in its overall political alignment, as a majority of black and Hispanic/Latino voters support the Democratic Party.

name: texas
sentence: Residents of counties along the Rio Grande closer to the Mexico-United States border, where there are many Latin American residents, generally vote for Democratic Party candidates, while most other rural and suburban areas of Texas voted for Republican Party candidates.

name: texas
sentence: Since the 2014 general election, a large majority of the members of the delegation of the U.S. House of Texas are Republicans, as well as the two United States.

name: texas
sentence: The Senators.

name: texas
sentence: At the 114th Congress of the United States, of the 36 Congress districts in Texas, 24 are held by Republicans and 11 by Democrats.

name: texas
sentence: There's a vacancy.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas senators are John Cornyn and Ted Cruz.

name: texas
sentence: Since 1994, the Texans have not elected a Democrat to a state office.

name: texas
sentence: The state's democratic voters are mainly Liberal and minority groups in Austin, Beaumont, Dallas, El Paso, Houston and San Antonio, as well as minority voters in Eastern and Southern Texas.

name: texas
sentence: Texas banned sanctuaries, but Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner promised the city won't help ICE agents.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a reputation for very severe criminal punishment for criminal offences.

name: texas
sentence: It is one of the 32 states that use capital punishment, and since the Supreme Court of the United States allowed the resumption of capital punishment in 1976, 40% of all American executions have taken place in Texas.

name: texas
sentence: In 2008, Texas had the fourth highest rate of incarceration in the United States.It also has strong self-defence laws, allowing citizens to use lethal force to defend themselves, their families or their property.

name: texas
sentence: While American football has long been regarded as "king" in the state, Texans enjoy a wide variety of sports.

name: texas
sentence: Texans can applaud a plethora of professional sports teams.

name: texas
sentence: In the Big Four professional leagues, Texas has two NFL teams (the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Texans), two major League baseball teams (the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers), three NBA teams (the San Antonio Spurs, the Houston Rockets and the Dallas Mavericks) and one National Hockey League team (the Dallas Stars).

name: texas
sentence: The Dallas–Fort Worth Metroplex is one of the twelve U.S. metropolitan areas hosting sports teams from all professional leagues of the Big Four.

name: texas
sentence: Apart from the Big Four, Texas also has a WNBA team (the Dallas Wings) and two major soccer league teams (the Houston Dynamo and FC Dallas).

name: texas
sentence: College athletics has a profound significance in Texas culture, especially in football.

name: texas
sentence: The state has 12 schools in the I-FBS Division, the largest in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's universities, Baylor Bears, Texas Longhorns, TCU Horned Frogs and Texas Tech Red Raiders, participate in the Great 12 Conference.

name: texas
sentence: Texas A&M Aggies left the Big 12 and joined the South-East Conference in 2012, which led the Big 12 to invite TCU to join; TCU was previously at the Mountain West Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Houston Cougars and the SMU Mustangs take part in the American athletic conference.

name: texas
sentence: The Bobcats of the State of Texas and the Mavericks of UT Arlington are participating in the Sun Belt conference.

name: texas
sentence: Four of the state's schools claim at least one national football championship: Texas Longhorns, Texas A&M Aggies, TCU Horned Frogs, and SMU Mustangs.

name: texas
sentence: According to an investigation by the I-A Division, the rivalry between the University of Oklahoma and the University of Texas at Austin, the Red River Shootout, ranks third in the nation.

name: texas
sentence: TCU horned frogs and SMU mustangs also share a rivalry and participate each year in the battle for the Iron Skullet.

name: texas
sentence: A fierce rivalry, the Lone Star Showdown, also exists between the two largest universities in the state, Texas A&M University and the University of Texas in Austin.

name: texas
sentence: The athletic part of the Lone Star Showdown rivalry was suspended after the Texas A&M joined the Southeast Conference.

name: texas
sentence: The University Interscholastic League (UIL) organizes most of the elementary and secondary school competitions.

name: texas
sentence: The events organized by UIL include athletics competitions (the most popular being secondary football) as well as artistic and academic topics.

name: texas
sentence: The Texans also like rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: The world's first rodeo was hosted in Pecos, Texas.

name: texas
sentence: The annual Houston Animal Show and Rodeo is the world's largest rodeo.

name: texas
sentence: It starts with hikes from several points of the state that meet in Reliant Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Southwest Exhibition and Livestock Fair in Fort Worth is the oldest rodeo in the history of the State in its annual events.

name: texas
sentence: Dallas hosts the Texas State Fair each year in Fair Park.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas Motor Speedway has been hosting NASCAR Cup and IndyCar racing since 1997.

name: texas
sentence: Since 2012, Austin's Circuit of the Americas has hosted a World Formula 1 Championship tour – the first of a permanent road circuit in the United States since the 1980 Grand Prix at Watkins Glen International – as well as Grand Prix motorcycle races, FIA World Endurance Championship and United SportsCar Championship.

name: utah
sentence: Utah (YOO-tah) is a state in the United States.

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south, and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico to the southeast.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty American states, Utah is the 13th largest by region; with a population of more than three million, it is the 30th most populous and 11th least dense.

sentence: Virginia is divided into 95 counties and 38 independent cities, the latter acting in many respects as county equivalents.

sentence: Washington, officially the State of Washington, is a state in the Northwestern Pacific region of the United States.

name: washington
sentence: Named for George Washington, the first president of the United States, the state was formed from the western part of Washington's territory, which was ceded by the British Empire in 1846, in accordance with the Oregon Treaty in the settlement of the Oregon border dispute.

name: washington
sentence: The state, which is bordered to the west by the Pacific Ocean, Oregon to the south, Idaho to the east and the Canadian province of British Columbia to the north, was admitted to the Union as the 42nd state in 1889.

sentence: Olympia is the capital of the state

name: washington
sentence: Washington is often called Washington State to distinguish it from the nation's capital, Washington, D.C.

name: washington
sentence: About 60 per cent of Washington's people live in the Seattle metropolitan area, the centre of transportation, business and industry along Puget Sound, a Pacific Ocean entrance consisting of many islands, deep fjords and glacier-drilled bays.

sentence: The rest of the state consists of deep temperate rainforests to the west; mountain ranges to the west, the centre, the north-east and the extreme south-east; and a semi-arid basin region to the east, the centre and the south, ceded to intensive agriculture.

sentence: Washington is the second most populous state on the West and West coasts of the United States, after California.

sentence: Mount Rainier, an active stratovolcan, is the highest altitude in the state, at nearly 14,411 feet (4,392 metres), and is the most topographically prominent mountain in the United States.

sentence: Washington is one of the largest producers of lumber; its rough surface is rich in Douglas-fir stands, hemlock, ponderosa pine, white pine, spruce, larch and cedar.

sentence: Livestock and livestock products contribute significantly to overall farm revenues, and commercial salmon, halibut and groundfish fisheries make a significant contribution to the government economy.

sentence: Washington has more than a thousand dams, including the Grand Coulee Dam, built for various purposes, including irrigation, electricity, flood control and water storage.

sentence: For Washington, this means that prevailing northwestern winds bring relatively fresh air and a predictable dry season.

sentence: In autumn and winter, a low pressure cyclone system takes over in the northern Pacific Ocean.

name: washington
sentence: The air that wraps inwards in the opposite direction of the clockwise makes the prevailing winds come from Washington from the southwest, bringing relatively warm and humid air masses and a predictable wet season.

name: washington
sentence: The term "Pineapple Express" is commonly used to describe the events of the atmospheric river, where repeated storm systems are led by this persistent cyclone in the tropical and quasi-tropical regions of the Pacific in the northwest Pacific.

name: washington
sentence: Although the west of Washington has a marine climate similar to many coastal cities in Europe, there are exceptions such as the events of "Big Snow" in 1880, 1881, 1893 and 1916, and the winters of "Deep Freezing" in 1883–84, 1915–1916, 1949–1950 and 1955–1956, among others.

name: washington
sentence: During these events, western Washington experienced up to 1,800 metres of snow, temperatures below 18 °C, three months of snow on the ground, and frozen lakes and rivers for weeks.

name: washington
sentence: The lowest officially recorded temperature in Seattle is 0°F (−18°C) set on January 31, 1950, but low-lying areas at about three hours from Seattle recorded low temperatures as cold as −48°F (−44°C).

sentence: South oscillation greatly influences weather during the cold season.

name: washington
sentence: During the El Niño phase, the jet enters the United States further south through California, so late autumn and winter are drier than normal with less snow.

name: washington
sentence: The La Niña phase reinforces the jet in the Pacific Northwest, so Washington has more rain and snow than the average.

name: washington
sentence: In 2006, the University of Washington's Climate Impacts Group published The Impacts of Climate Change in Washington's Economy, a preliminary assessment of the risks and opportunities presented, given the possibility of rising global temperatures and their effects on Washington's state.

name: washington
sentence: The rainfall in Washington varies considerably from east to west.

name: washington
sentence: The western part of the Olympic Peninsula receives up to 160 inches (4,100 mm) of precipitation each year, making it the wettest area of the 48 neighbouring states and a temperate tropical forest.

name: washington
sentence: Weeks can go by without a clear day.

name: washington
sentence: The western slopes of the Cascade Range receive some of the largest annual snowfalls (in some places more than 200 inches or 5,100 millimetres of water equivalent) across the country.

name: washington
sentence: In the area of the rain shadow east of the Cascades, the annual precipitation is only 6 inches (150 mm).

name: washington
sentence: Precipitation then increases eastward towards the Rocky Mountains (approximately 120 miles east of the Idaho border).

name: washington
sentence: The Olympic mountains and waterfalls aggravate this climate pattern by causing the orographical uplift of blown air masses inside the Pacific Ocean, resulting in high levels of precipitation on the wind side of the mountains and low levels on the left side.

name: washington
sentence: This happens most dramatically around the Olympic mountains and the Cascade chain.

name: washington
sentence: In both cases, slopes exposed to wind to the southwest receive high precipitation and mild and cool temperatures.

name: washington
sentence: Although the Puget Sound lowlands are known for cloud and rain in winter, the western slopes of the Cascades receive larger amounts of precipitation, often as snow at higher altitudes.

name: washington
sentence: Mount Baker, near the northern border of the state, is one of the most snowy areas in the world.

name: washington
sentence: In 1999, it established the world record for snowfall in a single season of 1,140 inches (95 feet; 29 metres).

name: washington
sentence: To the east of the Cascades, a large area experiences strong rain shadow effects.

name: washington
sentence: Semi-arid conditions occur in much of eastern Washington, with the strongest effects of rain shadow at relatively low elevations on the central Columbia Plateau, particularly in the area just east of the Columbia River, from the Snake River to the Okanagan Highlands.

name: washington
sentence: Thus, instead of rainforests, much of eastern Washington is covered with dry grassland, shrub steppe and sand dunes.

name: washington
sentence: The average annual temperature ranges from 51°F (11°C) on the Pacific coast to 40°F (4°C) in the northeast.

name: washington
sentence: The lowest temperature recorded in the state was −48°F (−44°C) at Winthrop and Mazama.

sentence: The highest temperature recorded in the state was 118°F (48°C) at Ice Harbor Dam.

name: washington
sentence: Both records were set east of the Cascades.

name: washington
sentence: Western Washington is known for its mild climate, considerable fog, frequent cloud cover, durable drizzles in winter and warm temperate summers.

name: washington
sentence: The Eastern region, which does not enjoy the general moderating effect of the Pacific Ocean, sometimes has an extreme climate.

name: washington
sentence: Winter Arctic cold fronts and summer heat waves are not uncommon.

name: washington
sentence: Temperatures in the western region were only 107°F (42°C) in Centralia, and up to 6°F (−21°C) in Longview.

name: washington
sentence: Forests cover about half of the territory of the state, mainly west of the Northern Cascades.

name: washington
sentence: Approximately two-thirds of Washington's forest area is owned by the state, 64% of which is federal land.

name: washington
sentence: Common trees and plants in the area include camassia, Douglas-fir, hemlock, penstemon, ponderosa pine, western red cedar, and many ferns.

sentence: East of Washington, the flora is very different.

name: washington

sentence: There is a greater variety of flora in both the blue mountains and the eastern Cascades.

name: washington
sentence: Native state mammals include bats, black bear, bobcat, cougar, coyote, deer, elk, grey wolf, hare, moose, mountain beaver, muskrat, opossum, pocket gopher, rabbit, raccoon, river otter, snout and tree squirrel.

name: washington
sentence: Due to the wide geographic diversity, Washington State is home to several different ecoregions, which allow for a varied range of bird species.

sentence: Catfish, lamprey and sturgeon are among the 400 freshwater fish known.

sentence: With the Cascade frog, there are several forms of snakes that define the most important reptiles and amphibians.

name: washington
sentence: Coastal bays and islands are often inhabited by abundant amounts of crustaceans and whales.

name: washington
sentence: There are five species of salmon rising in the western Washington area, from streams to spawning grounds.

name: washington
sentence: Washington has a variety of units in the National Park Service.

name: washington
sentence: These include Alta State National Park, Roosevelt Lake National Recreation Area, San Juan Islands National Wildlife Refuge, and three national parks, Olympic National Park, Northern Cascades National Park and Mount Rainier National Park.

name: washington
sentence: The three national parks were created between 1899 and 1968.

name: washington
sentence: Nearly 95 per cent (876,517 acres, 354,714 hectares, 3,547.14 square kilometres) of the Olympic National Park area has been designated "Wild Nature" under the National Nature Protection System.

name: washington

name: washington
sentence: Britain and the United States accepted what has since been described as a "joint occupation" of land west of the continental ditch to the Pacific Ocean under the Anglo-American Convention of 1818, which established the 49th parallel as the international boundary west of Lake of the Woods to the Rocky Mountains.

sentence: Marcus provided medical care to the Amerindians, but when Indian patients, who were not immune to new "European" diseases, died strikingly, while at the same time many white patients recovered, they held the "medical man" Marcus Whitman personally responsible, and murdered Whitman and twelve other white settlers in the Whitman massacre in 1847.

name: washington
sentence: Washington State is one of seven states that do not levy personal income taxes.

name: washington
sentence: The Crown also does not collect tax on corporate income or on deductibles.

name: washington
sentence: Washington companies are responsible for various other government levies, including business and occupation tax (B & O), a gross revenue tax that imposes variable rates for different types of businesses.

name: washington
sentence: The sales tax on the Washington State base is 6.5%, which is combined with a local sales tax that varies by location.

name: washington
sentence: The combined rates of public sales tax and local retail sales tax increase the taxes paid by consumers, depending on the variable rates of local sales tax, generally between 7.5% and 10%.

name: washington
sentence: In March 2017, the combined sales tax rate in Seattle and Tacoma was 10.1 per cent.

name: washington
sentence: The cities of Lynnwood and Mill Creek have the highest sales tax rate in the state at 10.5 per cent.

name: washington
sentence: These taxes apply both to services and to products.

name: washington
sentence: Most food is exempt from sales tax.

name: washington
sentence: However, prepared foods, dietary supplements and soft drinks remain taxable.

name: washington
sentence: An excise tax applies to certain products such as gasoline, cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.

name: washington
sentence: Property tax was the first tax levied in the state of Washington, and its collection accounts for about 30 per cent of the total revenue of the state and local authorities in Washington.

name: washington
sentence: It continues to be the main source of income for public schools, fire protection, libraries, parks and recreation, and other special-purpose districts.

name: washington
sentence: All real and personal property is subject to tax, unless specifically exempted by law.

name: washington
sentence: Most personal property held by individuals is exempt from taxation.

name: washington
sentence: Personal property tax applies to personal property used in the conduct of a business or other personal property not exempt by law.

name: washington
sentence: All property taxes are paid to the treasurer's office in the county in which the property is located.

name: washington
sentence: Washington does not tax intangibles such as bank accounts, shares or bonds.

name: washington
sentence: The State also does not assess the tax on retirement income received and received from another State.

name: washington
sentence: Washington doesn't collect inheritance tax.

name: washington
sentence: However, estate tax is separated from federal estate tax laws and, as a result, the Crown imposes its own estate tax.

name: washington
sentence: Washington has the 18th highest effective per capita tax rate in the United States in 2017.

name: washington
sentence: Their tax policy differs from that of neighbouring Oregon, which collects no sales tax, but imposes a personal income tax.

name: washington
sentence: This results in border economic anomalies in the metropolitan area of Portland-Vancouver.

name: washington
sentence: Other border economies exist with neighbouring B.C. and Idaho.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is a leader agricultural state.

name: washington
sentence: The following figures are from the State Department of Agriculture in Washington and the USDA, National Agricultural Statistics Service, Washington Field Office.

name: washington
sentence: For 2013, the total value of Washington's agricultural products was $10.2 billion.In 2013, Washington ranked first among the countries in the production of red raspberries (92.7 per cent of total U.S. production), hops (79.2 per cent), spicy mint oil (72.9 per cent), wrinkled seed peas (60 per cent), apples (57%), sweet cherries (50.9 per cent), pears (49.5 per cent).

name: washington
sentence: Washington is also the second largest producer of autumn potatoes (one quarter of domestic production), nectarines, apricots, grapes (all varieties), sweet corn for processing (one quarter of domestic production) and summer onions (one fifth of domestic production).

name: washington
sentence: The apple industry is of particular importance for Washington.

name: washington
sentence: Due to the favourable climate of dry and hot summers and cold winters in central Washington, the state has been leading the United States in apple production since the 1920s.

name: washington
sentence: Two regions account for the vast majority of state apple cultivation: the Wenatchee-Okanogan region (including the counties of Chelan, Okanogan, Douglas, and Grant), and the Yakima region (including the counties of Yakima, Benton, and Kittitas).

name: washington
sentence: Washington produces seven main apple varieties that are exported to more than 60 countries.

name: washington

name: west_virginia
sentence: Most of West Virginia lies in the mixed ecoregion of the Appalachian Mesophyte forests, while the high elevations along the eastern border and in the panhandle lie in the Appalachian and Blue Ridge forests.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The native vegetation of most of the state was originally a mixed forest of oaks, chestnuts, maples, beech and white pines, with American willow and sycamore along the rivers of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many of these areas are rich in biodiversity and scenic beauty, a fact appreciated by the Western Virginians, who refer to their home as almost heaven (of the song, "Take Me Home, Country Roads" by John Denver).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Prior to the song, it was known as "The Cog State" (coal, oil and gas) or "The Mountain State".

name: west_virginia
sentence: The underlying rock strata are sandstone, shale, bituminous coal beds, and limestone placed in an environment close to the coast from sediments from mountains to the east in a shallow inland sea to the west.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Some beds illustrate a coastal swampy environment, a river delta, a few shallow waters.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Sea levels rose and fell repeatedly during the Mississippi and Pennsylvania eras, giving a variety of rocky strata.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Appalachians are among the oldest on earth, having formed more than 300 million years ago.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's climate is generally a humid subtropical climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Cfa, with the exception of Dfb at higher altitudes) with hot to hot, humid and cold winters, increasing in severity with elevation.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Some areas of the southern highlands also have a temperate mountain climate (Köppen Cfb) where winter temperatures are more moderate and summer temperatures are slightly cooler.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, time is subject in all regions of the state to change.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Hardiness zones range from zone 5b in the Central Appalachian Mountains to zone 7a in the warmest areas of the lowest altitudes.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the Eastern Panhandle and Ohio Valley, temperatures are warm enough to see and cultivate subtropical plants such as Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Myrtle Crepe, Albizia julibrisin, American sweetgum, and even needle palm and minor sabal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: These plants don't thrive as well in other parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Eastern prickly pear grows well in many parts of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Average January temperatures range from approximately 26°F (−4°C) near the Cheat River to 41°F (5°C) along the portions of the Kentucky border.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The July averages range from 67°F (19°C) along the northern Potomac River to 76°F (24°C) in the western part of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is cooler in the mountains than in the lower sections of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The highest recorded temperature in the state was 112°F (44°C) at Martinsburg on 10 July 1936 and the lowest recorded temperature at -37°F (−38°C) at Lewisburg on 30 December 1917.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Annual precipitation ranges from less than 32 inches (810 mm) in the lower east to more than 56 inches (1,400 mm) in the upper parts of the line of allegiance.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The eastern valleys are less rainy because the ridges of the Allegheny mountain in the west create a partial rain shadow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Slightly more than half of the precipitation occurs between April and September.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Dense fogs are common in many valleys of the Kanawha section, especially in the Tygart Valley.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is also one of the most cloudy states in the nation, with the cities of Elkins and Beckley ranking 9th and 10th respectively in the United States for the number of cloudy days per year (more than 210).

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to the persistent cloudy sky caused by the degradation of humidity by the Alleghenies, West Virginia is also experiencing some of the most frequent precipitation in the nation, with snowshoes on average nearly 200 days a year with rain or snow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Snow usually lasts only a few days in the lower sections, but may persist for weeks in the upper mountainous regions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: An average of 34 inches (860 mm) of snow falls each year in Charleston, although in the winter of 1995-96, more than three times this amount decreased, with several cities in the state setting new snowfall records.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Average snowfall in the Highlands of Allegheny can reach up to 180 inches (4,600 mm) per year.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Violent weather is a little less common in West Virginia than in most other eastern states, and it ranks among the least tornado-like states east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the population of West Virginia was 1,792,147 on July 1, 2018, representing a 3.28 per cent decrease from the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The population centre of West Virginia is located in Braxton County, in the city of Gassaway.

sentence: In the same year, 1.2% of the West Virginia population was of Hispanic, Latin or Spanish origin (they may be of any race).

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2019, the population of West Virginia is estimated at 1,792,147, a decrease of 10,025 (0.55%) from the previous year and a decrease of 47,162 (2.55%) from the previous census.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This includes a natural decrease of 3,296 (108,292 births minus 111,588 deaths) and an increase in net migration of 14,209 in the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is the least populous state in the southeast.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 3,691 people and internal migration resulted in a net increase of 10,518 people.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Only 1.6% of the state's residents were born abroad, placing West Virginia at the top of the 50 states in this statistic.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It also has the lowest percentage of residents who speak a language other than English at home (2.6 per cent).

name: west_virginia
sentence: The five largest ancestry groups in West Virginia are: German (18.9 per cent), Irish (15.1 per cent), American (12.9 per cent), English (11.8 per cent) and Italian (4.7 per cent) In the 2000 census, persons who identified their ethnicity as simply American accounted for 18.7 per cent of the population.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A large number of people of German ancestry are present in the northeastern counties of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: People of English descent are present throughout the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many Western Virginians who identify as Irish are actually Scottish-Irish Protestants.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Data from the 2010 Census show that 16 per cent of West Virginia residents are 65 years of age or older (exceeding only 17 per cent in Florida).

sentence: Northern Panhandle and the North Central Region feel an affinity for Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

sentence: In addition, those in the Eastern Panhandle feel a connection with the suburbs of Washington, D.C. in Maryland and Virginia, and the southwestern Virginians often consider themselves to be Southerners.

sentence: One of the characteristics of religion in the Appalachian communities is the abundance of independent and unaffiliated churches, which "remain unnoticed and not counted in any census of religious life in the United States".

name: west_virginia
sentence: This sometimes leads to the belief that these communities are "without hesitation".

sentence: In 2010, the united Methodist Church had 136,000 members in 1,200 congregations.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia economy would be nominally the 62nd largest world economy behind Iraq and ahead of Croatia according to the World Bank's 2009 projections, and the 64th largest behind Iraq and ahead of Libya according to the 2009 projections of the International Monetary Fund.

name: west_virginia
sentence: According to the November 2010 report of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, the Government is planning a nominal GSP of $63.34 billion in 2009 and a real GSP of $55.04 billion.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The real GDP growth of the state in 2009 of 7% was the 7th best in the country.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia was one of only ten states in 2009 with economic growth.

name: west_virginia
sentence: While per capita income declined by 2.6 per cent nationally in 2009, the per capita income of West Virginia increased by 1.8 per cent.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In the first half of 2010, exports from West Virginia reached $3 billion, up 39.5 per cent from the previous year and from the national average of 15.7 per cent.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Morgantown was ranked by Forbes as the best #10 small town in the nation to run business in 2010.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The city is also home to West Virginia University, the 95th best public university according to US News & World Report in 2011.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The proportion of the adult population in West Virginia with a bachelor's degree is lowest in the United States, at 17.3%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The net corporate income tax rate is 6.5 per cent, while business costs are 13 per cent lower than the national average.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis reported that in 2014 West Virginia's economy grew twice as fast as the next growing state east of Mississippi, ranking third alongside Wyoming and just behind North Dakota and Texas among the fastest growing states in the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Tourism contributed $4.27 billion to the state economy and employed 44,400 people in 2010, making it one of the most important industries in the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Many tourists, especially in the eastern mountains, are attracted to the region's remarkable opportunities for outdoor recreation.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Canaan Valley is popular for winter sports, Senatorca Rocks is one of the major climbing destinations in the eastern United States, the New River Gorge/Fayetteville area attracts rock climbers as well as water rafters, and Monongahela National Forest is popular with hikers, backpackers, hunters and fishermen.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition to these outdoor activities, the state offers a number of historical and cultural attractions.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Harpers Ferry is a historic city located at the confluence of the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Harpers Ferry was the site of John Brown's 1859 raid on the Armory and the Arsenal of the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Located about halfway on the Appalachian Trail, Harpers Ferry is the base of the conservation centre of the Appalachian Trail.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Greenbrier Hotel, originally built in 1778, has long been regarded as a leading hotel, frequented by many world leaders and U.S. presidents over the years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is the site of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, which houses the Green Bank telescope.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For the 1963 Centenary of the State, it welcomed two high school graduates from each of the 50 states to the National Youth Science Camp near Bartow and has continued this tradition ever since.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The main building of the Weston State Hospital is the largest hand-cut sandstone building in the Western Hemisphere, the second largest in the world only in the Kremlin in Moscow.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Visits to the building, which is a national historic site and part of the National Civil War Trail, are available on a seasonal and year-round basis.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia has numerous popular festivals throughout the year.

name: west_virginia
sentence: One of the main resources in the West Virginia economy is coal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, West Virginia is one of the leading coal producers in the United States, after only Wyoming.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is located in the heart of Marcellus Shale Natural Gas Bed, which extends from North Tennessee to New York City in the middle of Appalachia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2017, the coal industry represented 2% of public employment.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Nearly all of the electricity produced in West Virginia comes from coal-fired power plants.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia produces a surplus of electricity and directs the nation in net interstate electricity exports.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Agriculture is also practised in West Virginia, but on a limited basis because of the mountainous terrain on a large part of the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia has the potential to generate 4,952 GWh/year from 1,883 MW of wind energy using 80-metre high wind turbines, or 8,627 GWh/year from 2,772 MW of 100-metre wind turbines, and 60,000 GWh from 40,000 MW of photovoltaics, including 3,810 MW of photovoltaics on roofs.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia personal income tax is based on federal adjusted gross income (not taxable income), as amended by certain elements of West Virginia law.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Citizens are taxed in five income brackets, ranging from 3.0% to 6.5%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The government's consumer sales tax is levied at 6% on most products, except for unprepared foods.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia counties administer and collect property tax, although property tax rates reflect levies for state, county, county education councils and municipalities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Counties may also charge a hotel occupancy tax on accommodation not within the boundaries of the city of a municipality that collects such a tax.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Municipalities may levy taxes on permits and gross revenues on businesses within the boundaries of the city and a hotel occupancy tax on accommodation in the city.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Although the Department of Taxation and Income plays an important role in the administration of this tax, less than half of the property tax collected is paid to the government.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The main beneficiaries of the property tax are the school boards of the counties.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Property taxes are paid to the sheriff of each of the 55 counties in the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Each county and municipality may impose its own property tax rates within the limits set by the Constitution of West Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Parliament sets the tax rate for the Education County Councils.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This rate is used by all education county councils throughout the state.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, the total tax rate on county education councils may differ from county to county due to excess levies.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Department of Taxation and Income oversees and otherwise assists counties and municipalities in their assessment and tax rate determination work.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The overall tax rate is a combination of the taxes levied by four state tax authorities: the state, the county, schools and municipalities.

name: west_virginia
sentence: This total tax rate varies for each of the four classes of property, which consists of personal, real and intangible property.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The property is evaluated on the basis of its use, location and value as of July 1.

name: west_virginia
sentence: WV Assessments has a free database on property tax valuations in West Virginia, covering current and past years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: All properties are revalued every 3 years

name: west_virginia
sentence: Western Virginia does not tax estates.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Due to the phasing out of the federal estate tax credit, West Virginia estate tax is not imposed on estates of deceased persons on or after January 1, 2005.

sentence: The State published a report stressing that the state's GDP indicates a rapidly growing economy, but did not address employment indicators.

sentence: In 2009–2013, the real GDP of the United States increased by 9.6% and total employment increased by 3.9%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In West Virginia during the same period, real GDP increased by about 11%, while total employment declined by 1,000 jobs, from 746,000 to 745,000.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2013, West Virginia ranked last in the country, with a employment-to-population ratio of only 50%, compared to the national average of 59%.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The state has lost 5,600 jobs in its workforce in four critical economic sectors: construction (1,900), manufacturing (1,100), retail trade (1,800) and education (800), while earning only 400 jobs in mining and forestry.

sentence: The state's civil labour force fell by 15.100.

sentence: Personal income growth in West Virginia in 2013 was only 1.5% – the lowest in the country – and about half the national average (2.6%).

name: west_virginia
sentence: Overall income growth in West Virginia over the last 30 years has been only 13%, or about one third of the national average (37%).

name: west_virginia
sentence: The wages of poor people with incomes below 1 per cent have decreased by 3 per cent from the national average, which has increased by 19 per cent.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Western Virginia's poverty rate is one of the highest in the country.

sentence: Estimates for 2017 indicate that 19% of the state's population lives in poverty, exceeding the national average of 13%.

sentence: The teachers' strike in West Virginia in 2018 prompted teachers in other states to take similar measures.

sentence: The 37th annual United Van Lines Migration Survey showed in 2013 that 60% more people left the state of the mountains than they moved in.

sentence: West Virginia's population is expected to decline by more than 19,000 by 2030, and West Virginia may lose one of its three seats in the United States House of Representatives.

sentence: West Virginia is the only state in which mortality rates exceed birth rates.

sentence: In 2010–2013, about 21,000 babies per year were born in West Virginia, but during these three years West Virginia experienced 3,000 more deaths than births.

sentence: The annual Gallup-Healthways "State of American Well-Being" ranking indicates that 1,261 Western Virginians have classified themselves as "suffering" in categories such as quality of life, physical health, and access to basic needs.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Overall, the citizens of West Virginia have classified themselves as being more unhappy than people in all other states – for five years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In addition, the 2013 Gallup Well-Being index ranked Charleston, the capital of the state, and Huntington the last and last time out of 189 U.S. metropolitan statistical areas.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Annie E. Casey Foundation's National Children's Progress Index ranked West Virginia 43rd in the country for all children, and the last for white children.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Annie E. Casey Foundation's 2013 KIDS COUNT Data Book also ranked West Virginia's education system 47th in the country for the second consecutive year.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Charleston, West Virginia, has the worst divorce rate among 100 cities in the nation.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Stephen Smith, Managing Director of the West Virginia Healthy Kids and Families Coalition, said that bad job prospects are to be blamed: "The pressure to earn a living is putting a strain on a marriage, and right now it is infinitely harder to earn a living here than it was 40 years ago."

name: west_virginia
sentence: The United Health Foundation's 2013 "American Health Ranks" found that Americans are making considerable progress in key health measures.

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, West Virginia ranked last or second in 20 categories, including cancer, childhood immunization, diabetes, disability, drug-related deaths, tooth loss, low birth weight, missed work days due to health, overdoses of prescription drugs, preventable hospitalizations, and clinical care for seniors.

sentence: The Wisconsin Population Health Institute's annual "Health Rankings" 2012 showed that West Virginia spends $9,671 per capita on health care each year.

sentence: El Salvador spends only $467 but both have the same life expectancy.

sentence: In 2012, according to the Census Bureau, West Virginia was the only state where mortality rates exceed birth rates.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2010–2013, approximately 21,000 babies were born in West Virginia, but there were 24,000 deaths.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In demography, it is a "net mortality society".

name: west_virginia
sentence: According to the National Centre for Health Statistics, adolescent birth rates are historically low — during the period 2007-2010, adolescent birth rates fell by 17 per cent at the national level;

name: west_virginia
sentence: However, West Virginia ranked last, with a 3% increase in teenage birth rates.

sentence: A study by Marshall University of West Virginia showed that 19% of babies born in the state have evidence of exposure to drugs or alcohol.

name: west_virginia
sentence: A study by the Institute for Health Policy Research found that mortality rates in Appalachia are correlated with coal production.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In some 20 West Virginia coal counties with more than 1 million tons of coal per year and a total population of 850,000, there are approximately 10,100 deaths per year, of which 1,400 are statistically attributed to deaths from life-related heart, respiratory and kidney disease in an Appalachian coal county.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2015, McDowell County recorded the highest rate of drug-related deaths in any U.S. county, with 141 deaths per 100,000 people.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Four of the five counties with the highest drug death rates are West Virginia (McDowell County, Wyoming County, Cabell County, and Raleigh County).

name: west_virginia
sentence: The life expectancy of West Virginia residents is lower than the national average.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2014, life expectancy for both sexes was 76.0 years, compared with 79.1 years for the United States as a whole.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In 2014, men in Western Virginia had an average of 73.6 years compared to a national average of 76.7 years and women had an average of 77.5 years compared to a national average of 81.5 years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Men's life expectancy in West Virginia increased by 4.7 years between 1980 and 2014, compared to a national average of 6.7 years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In Western Virginia, women's life expectancy increased by 1.7 years between 1980 and 2014, compared to a national average of 4.0 years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Life expectancy for both sexes is one of the lowest in all States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Life expectancy in 2014 for both sexes in West Virginia counties ranged from 70.3 years low in McDowell County to 79.3 years high in Pendleton County.

name: west_virginia
sentence: McDowell and several other West Virginia counties are among the U.S. counties with the lowest life expectancy.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia's legislature is bicameral.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It consists of the Chamber of Delegates and the Senator, both housed in the Capitol of the State of Western Virginia.

name: west_virginia
sentence: It is a citizen legislature, which means that the legislative office is not a full-time job, but rather a part-time job.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As a result, legislators often work full-time in their community of residence.

name: west_virginia
sentence: As a rule, Parliament sits for 60 days between January and early April.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The last day of the ordinary session ended with a disconcerting fury of last-minute legislation to comply with a constitutional deadline of midnight.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For the rest of the year, monthly interim sessions are held in preparation for the regular session.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The legislators also meet periodically for "special" sessions upon appeal by the Governor.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The title of Lieutenant Governor is conferred by statute on the Speaker of the Senate.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The governor, who was elected every four years on the same day as the American presidential election, took the oath in the following January.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The governors of West Virginia may serve two consecutive terms, but they must hold a term of office before serving a third term.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The title of Lieutenant Governor is conferred by statute on the Speaker of the Senate.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is one of the 19 states that do not have the death penalty, and it is the only state in the southeastern United States that has abolished it.

name: west_virginia
sentence: For the purposes of the courts of general jurisdiction, the State is divided into 31 judicial channels.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Each circuit is composed of one or more counties.

name: west_virginia
sentence: Electoral district judges are elected in non-partisan elections for a term of eight years.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Supreme Court of Appeal of West Virginia is the highest court of appeal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeal is the most busy court of appeal of its kind in the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia is one of 11 states with a single Court of Appeal.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The constitution of the State allows the creation of an intermediate court of appeal, but the legislative power has never created one.

sentence: The Supreme Court is composed of five judges, elected in non-partisan elections for 12 years.

sentence: At the state level, West Virginia's politics were largely dominated by the Democratic Party of the Great Depression until the 2000s.

sentence: It was a legacy of West Virginia's strong trade union tradition.

sentence: After the mid-term elections of 2014, the Democrats controlled the government, the majority of state offices and a seat as US senator, while the Republicans held a seat as US senator, the three seats in the US House of State, and a majority in both chambers of the West Virginia Legislative Assembly.
